0.0: Mishnah: From when may one recite the Shema in the evening?
0.1: From the time when the kohanim (priests) enter to eat their terumah (agricultural gifts) [i.e., sundown] until the end of the first watch [of the night]; this is the view of Rabbi Eliezer.
0.3: [The Shema may be recited] until midnight.
0.5: [It may be recited] until the break of dawn.
0.6: It once happened that [Rabban Gamliel’s] sons came [home late at night] from a place of feasting. They said to [their father]:
0.9: “If dawn has not broken, you are obligated to recite it."
0.10: Not only in this case was this said; rather, in all cases where the Sages said that [some precept can be performed only] until midnight — the precept is [still in force] until the break of dawn.
0.11: [For example:] Burning the fats and organs [of the sacrifices, on the Temple altar] — this precept [can be performed] until the break of dawn. [Another example:] All [sacrifices] which may be eaten for one day — the precept [of eating them can be performed] until the break of dawn. "If so, why did the Sages say [that these precepts can be performed only] until midnight?
0.12: To keep a person away from sinning."
0.13: Gemara: What does the Tanna refer to, asking "From when"?
0.14: Furthermore, why does he deal with [the Shema reading] of the evening first,
0.15: rather than dealing with that of the morning first?
0.16: The Tanna refers to Scripture, which says, "…when you lie down and when you get up," (Deut. 6:7)
0.17: and he means to say thus:
0.18: What is the time of the reciting of the Shema at lying down? From the time when the priests enter to eat their terumah.
0.19: And if you want, you can say
0.20: that he learned [the order] from the creation of the world, thus: "…and it was evening and it was morning, day one." (Bereshit 1:5).
0.21: If so, in the concluding Mishnah, where it states: "In the morning
0.22: The Tanna started with the evening one first, and then one says two blessings before [the Shema] and one after it, while in the evening one says two blessings before it and two after it," he should have dealt with the evening first!
0.23: He started teaching with the evening one first; then continued and dealt with the morning one; while he was dealing with the morning one, he expounded the details of the morning one, and then expounded those of the evening one.
0.25: 'From the time when the priests enter to eat their terumah'- Seeing that when do the priests eat terumah? – from the emergence of the stars, it should have stated, "from the emergence of the stars"!
0.26: It teaches us something in passing: From when do priests eat terumah? – from the time of the emergence of the stars; this teaches us
0.27: that the atonement is not preclusive [of eating terumah],
0.28: as it is taught: "And the sun would set and he would become [ritually] pure" (lit.: and it would be pure) (Leviticus 22:7) – his sun-setting precludes him from eating terumah, but his atonement does not prevent him from eating teruma.
0.29: How do we know that this [Scriptural reference], "and the sun would set" (lit.: "and the sun would come") refers to sunset, and "…and it would be pure" means that the day would be cleared?
0.30: How is it to be known, however, that the phrase "When the sun is down" means the [complete] setting of the sun, and the phrase "It is clean" means the day is clean?

1.0: It means perhaps: And when the sun [of the next morning] appears, and ve-taher means the man becomes clean? —
1.1: Rabbah son of R. Shila explains: In that case, the text would have to read ve-yithar.
1.2: What is the meaning of ve-taher? The day clears away, conformably to the common expression,as people [commonly] say: the sun
1.3: has set and the day has cleared away. In the West, this explanation of Rabbah son of
1.4: R. Shila was unknown, and they raised the question:
1.5: This u'va hashemesh, does it mean the real setting of the sun, and ve-taher means
1.6: the day clears away? Or does it perhaps mean the appearance of the sun, and what is
1.7: ve-taher? the man becomes clean? They resolved it from a baraita,
1.8: for it was taught in a baraita: The sign of the thing is the appearance of the stars.
1.9: Hence you learn that it is the setting of the sun [which makes him clean] and the meaning of ve-taher is the clearing away
1.10: of the day. The Master said: From the time when the kohanim enter to eat
1.11: their terumah. They threw [a contradiction] against it: From what time may one recite the Shema
1.12: in the evening? From the time that the poor man. comes [home] to eat his bread with salt
1.13: till he rises from his meal. The last clause
1.14: certainly contradicts the Mishnah. Does the first clause also contradict
1.15: the Mishnah? — No. The poor man and the priest have one and the same time. They threw [a contradiction] against it:
1.16: From what time may one begin to recite the Shema’ in the evening?
1.17: From the time that the people come [home] to eat their meal on a Sabbath
1.18: eve. These are the words of Rabbi Meir. But the Sages say: From the time
1.19: that the priests are entitled to eat their terumah. A sign
1.20: for the matter is the appearance of the stars. And though there is no real proof of the matter, there is a hint
1.21: to the matter. For it is written: So we engaged in the work: and half of them
1.22: held the spears from the rise of the dawn till the appearance
1.23: of the stars. And it says further: That in the night they may be a guard for us, and in the day
1.24: may work. (Why this second citation? — If you object and say that with the setting
1.25: of the sun the night really begins , but that they left late and came early,
1.26: [I shall reply]: Come and hear [the other verse]: ‘That in the night they may be a guard to us, and in the day may labour ’). Now
1.27: it is assumed that the ‘poor man’ and ‘the people’ have the same time [for their evening meal.]
1.28: And if you say that the poor man and the priest also have the same time, then the Sages
1.29: would be saying the same thing as R. Meir? Hence you must conclude that the poor man has one time
1.30: and the priest has another time? — No; the ‘poor man’ and the priest have the same
1.31: time, but the ‘poor man’ and the ‘people’ have not the same time.
1.32: But have the ‘poor man’ and the priest really the same time? They threw [a contradiction] against it:
1.33: From what time may one begin to recite the Shema’ in the evening? From the time
1.34: that the [Sabbath] day becomes hallowed on the Sabbath eve. These are the words of Rabbi Eliezer.
1.35: Rabbi Yehoshua says: From the time that the priests are ritually clean
1.36: to eat their terumah. Rabbi Meir says: From the time
1.37: that the priests take their ritual bath in order to eat their terumah. (Said to him
1.38: Rabbi Yehudah: When the priests take their ritual bath it is still day-time!)
1.39: Rabbi Hanina says: From the time that the poor man comes [home] to eat his bread
1.40: with salt. Rabbi Ahai (some say: Rabbi Aha). says:
1.41: From the time that most people come home to sit down to their meal. Now, if
1.42: you say that the poor man and the priest have the same time, then Rabbi Hanina would be saying the same thing as
1.43: Rabbi Yehoshua ? From this you must conclude, must you not, that the poor man has one
1.44: time and the priest has another time. — Draw indeed that conclusion! Which
1.45: of them is later? — It is reasonable to conclude that the ‘poor man’ is later. For if
1.46: you say that the ‘poor man’ is earlier, R. Hanina would be saying the same thing as R. Eliezer.
1.47: Hence you must conclude that the poor man is later, must you not? — Draw indeed
1.48: that conclusion. The Master said: ‘Rabbi Judah said to him: Do not the priests take their ritual bath when it is still daytime!’ The objection of Rabbi Yehudah to Rabbi Meir seems well founded! And Rabbi Meir? Thus he may reply to him: Do you think that I am referring to the twilight [as defined] by you? I am referring to the twilight
1.49: [as defined] by Rabbi Yose. For Rabbi Yose says: The twilight is like the twinkling of an eye. This enters and that departs — and one cannot exactly fix it.
1.50: 'But do not the priests bathe while it is yet day?'"
1.51: R. Judah's question to R. Meir is a forcible one !
1.52: But R. Meir answered him thus :
1.53: Dost thou think that I agree with thy opinion of "twilight" ?
1.54: I agree with R, Jose's opinion.
1.56: The twilight is like a flicker of the eye ;
1.57: the night comes on and the day passes without anyone being able to perceive it.

2.0: This is a difficulty between Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Meir.
2.1: There are two contradictory Tanaaic teachings attributed to Rabbi Meir.
2.2: This is a difficulty between Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Eliezer.
2.3: There are two contradictory Tanaaic teachings attributed to Rabbi Eliezer.
2.4: And if you want, I say
2.5: the beginning (lit., i.e. the initial part of the Mishna) is not Rabbi Eliezer.
2.6: Mishna: "until the end of the watch." --- What does Rabbi Eliezer hold?
2.7: If he holds there are 3 watches in the night, he should say "until 4 hours."
2.8: If he holds there are 4 watches in the night, he should say "until 3 hours."
2.9: In actuality, he holds there are 3 watches in the night, and thus we learn from this
2.10: that there are watches in heaven and there are watches on earth, as it is taught:
2.12: "the night has three watches, and on each and every watch, The Holy One Blessed Be He sits and roars like a lion, as it is said,
2.13: "The LORD doth roar from on high, And utter His voice from His holy habitation; He doth mightily roar because of His fold (Jeremiah 25:30).", and a sign of this
2.14: The first watch, a donkey brays. The second watch, dogs bark. The third watch, children nurse from their mother's breasts, and a women converses with her husband.
2.15: Of what is R. Eliezer thinking ?
2.16: If he is thinking of the commencement of the watches, what need is there for a sign of the beginning of the first watch,
2.18: Should he be thinking of the end of the watches, what need is there for a sign of the end of the last watch,
2.21: he must be thinking of the end of the first watch, the beginning of the last watch, and the middle of the central watch.
2.22: Or if thou wilt, I can say that in every case he is thinking of the end of the watches ; and shouldest thou urge
2.23: that a sign of the end of the last watch is unnecessary,
2.24: and ask what is its purpose ? It is for the reading of the Shema' on the part of one who sleeps in a dark room and does not know when is the time for reading the Shema'. Therefore, when the woman converses with her husband and the child sucks at the breast of its mother, let him get up and read it.
2.25: R. Isaac b. Samuel said in the name of Rab:
2.26: The night is divided into three watches, and at each watch the Holy One, blessed be He, sits enthroned, roars like a lion and exclaims,
2.27: R. Jose says: "Once upon a time I was walking on a road and I entered
2.28: one of the ruins of Jerusalem to pray.
2.29: Elijah blessed be his memory! came and watched me at the door...
2.30: Elijah — may he be remembered for good ! — came, waited at the entrance for me, and stayed until I had concluded my prayer.
2.31: After I had finished my prayer he said to me,
2.32: " Peace be to thee, my master."
2.34: "Peace be to thee, my master and teacher."
2.36: "My son, why didst thou enter this ruin ?"
2.40: "Thou shouldest have prayed by the roadside."
2.44: " Thou shouldest have offered an abbreviated prayer."
2.45: On that occasion I learnt three things from him :
2.46: first, one should not enter ruins ; second, it is permissible to pray by the roadside ; third, one who prays by the roadside should offer an abbreviated prayer.
2.48: "My son, what sound didst thou hear in that ruin ?"
2.50: "I heard a Bat Kol moaning like a dove, crying,
2.51: 'Alas for My children for whose iniquities I destroyed My house, burnt My Temple, and exiled them
2.54: "By thy life and the life of thy head, not only at this hour does it so cry, but thrice daily it exclaims thus.
2.55: Moreover, whenever the Children of Israel enter their
2.56: Synagogues and Houses of Study and respond 'Let His great Name be blessed,' the Holy One, blessed be He, shakes His head and exclaims,
2.57: 'Happy the King Who is so praised in His house ! Alas for the Father Who has banished His children ! And alas for the children who have been banished from their Father's table ! '"
2.58: Our Rabbis have taught : For three reasons one should not enter ruins :
2.59: on account of suspicion, of falling fabric and evil spirits.
2.60: [Why mention] on account of suspicion, since thou canst derive [a sufficient reason] from the danger of falling fabric ?

3.1: Then derive it from the danger of evil spirits !
3.2: This would not apply when two men entered a ruin. But should there be two men, there would likewise be no ground for suspicion !
3.3: There would be in the case of two men of ill-repute.
3.4: [Why mention] on account of falling fabric, since thou canst derive [a sufficient reason] from the grounds of suspicion and evil spirits ?
3.5: No, not in the case of two men of good repute.
3.6: [Why mention] on account of evil spirits, since thou canst derive [a sufficient reason] from the grounds of suspicion and falling fabric ?
3.7: No, not in the case of new ruins and two men of good repute.
3.8: Is there no fear of evil spirits also when there are two men ?
3.9: In such places where evil spirits resort
3.11: Or if thou wilt, I can say that even in the case of a person alone and new ruins situated in a wild place there is no ground for suspicion, because a woman does not frequent such a spot ; but the fear of evil spirits remains.
3.13: The night is divided into four watches. These are the words of Rabbi.
3.17: Because it is written, "So Gideon, and the hundred men that were with him, came unto the outermost part of the camp in the beginning of the middle watch " (Judges vii 19). Hence he teaches that
3.18: there cannot be a "middle watch" unless one precedes and follows.
3.19: How does Rabbi explain the phrase "middle watch" ?
3.20: He takes it to mean one of the middle watches.
3.21: What reply does R. Nathan make to this? He asks,
3.22: Does Scripture state "one of the two middle watches"?
3.23: No; the "middle watch" is explicitly mentioned.
3.24: What is Rabbi's reason [for declaring there are four watches] ?
3.25: R. Zerika stated that R. Ammi said in the name of R. Joshua b. Levi :
3.26: One verse states, "At midnight I will rise to give thanks unto Thee because of Thy righteous ordinances" (Ps. cxix. 62) and another verse states,
3.27: "Mine eyes forestalled the night-watches" (ibid. 5:148). How is this?
3.28: There must be four watches in the night.
3.29: How does R. Nathan answer this argument?
3.30: He agrees with the opinion of R. Joshua ; for there is a Mishnaic teaching :
3.32: Until the third hour [in the day may the morning Shema' be read], for so is the custom of kings to rise at the third hour.
3.33: Six hours of the night and two of the day make two watches.
3.35: A watch and a half are also referred to as "watches."
3.36: R. Zerika also stated that R. Ammi said in the name of R. Joshua b. Levi :
3.37: In the presence of the dead, we should only speak of matters relating to the dead.
3.39: This applies only to words of Torah ; but as for worldly matters we can have no objection.
3.40: Another version is : R. Abba b. Kahana said :
3.41: This applies even to words of Torah ; how much more so to worldly matters !
3.45: "I arose early beneshef and cried" (Ps. cxix. 147). Whence is it learnt that neshef means evening ? Because it is written, "In the twilight [beneshef], in the evening of the day, in the blackness of night and the darkness" (Prov. vii. 9).
3.46: R. Osha'ya said in the name of R. Aha : Thus declared David,
3.47: "Midnight never passed me by in my sleep."
3.50: David used to slumber like a horse,
3.51: but from thence he grew strong like a lion.
3.53: Until midnight he was occupied with words of Torah, but from thence with psalms and praises.
3.55: Lo, it means the morning ; for it is written,
3.56: "And David smote them from the neshef even unto the evening ['ereb] of the next day" (I Sam. xxx. 17). Is this not to be understood to mean from the morning unto the evening?
3.58: If so, the text should have read "from the neshef unto the neshef" or "from the 'ereb unto the 'ereb" !
3.60: there are two occasions in the day called neshef; there is the neshef of the night followed by day, and the neshef of the day followed by night.
3.61: Did David know when it was [exactly] midnight,
3.62: since even Moses our teacher was not certain ; as it is written, "About mid-night will I go out into the midst of Egypt" (Exod. xi. 4) ? What means "about midnight" ?
3.63: Are we to suppose that the Holy One, blessed be He, used the phrase "about midnight" to Moses ?  Can there be any doubt in the mind of God ?
3.64: Nay ; God told him "At midnight"; but Moses came and said
3.65: "about midnight." Hence it is to be understood that Moses was in doubt, but David did know it !
3.66: He had a sign. For R. Hannah b. Bizna said in the name of R. Simeon Hasida :
3.67: There was a harp hanging above David's bed, and when the time of midnight arrived a North wind came and blew upon it, so that it produced melody. He used immediately to rise and occupy himself with Torah until the break of dawn.
3.68: At the rise of dawn, the wise men of Israel entered his presence and said to him,
3.69: "Our lord, the king, thy people Israel are in need of sustenance."
3.71: "Go, let each sustain himself from the other."
3.74: satisfy a lion, nor can a pit be filled with its own clods."
3.76: "Go, stretch forth your hands with the army."
3.77: At once they took counsel with Ahitophel, consulted the Sanhedrin, and inquired of the Urim and Tummim.
3.79: What is the Scriptural authority for this?
3.80: "And after Ahitophel was Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, and Abiathar ; and the captain of the king's host was Joab" (I Chron. xxvii. 34) —
3.81: "Ahitophel " was the counsellor, for thus it is stated, "Now the counsel of Ahitophel, which he counselled in those days, was as if a man inquired of the word of God" (2 Sam. xvi. 23).

4.0: "Benaiah the son of Jehoiada" refers to the Sanhedrin ; "Abiathar" denotes the Urim and Tummim. For so the Scriptures declare,
4.1: "And Benaiah the son of Jehoiada was over the Cherethites and over the Pelethites" (2 Sam. xx. 23).
4.2: Why were the members of the Sanhedrin called Kereti and Peleti ?
4.3: They were called Kereti because they were concise [koretim] with their words, and Peleti because they were "distinguished" [muflaim] with their words.
4.4: After them came "the captain of the king's host, Joab."
4.5: Rab Isaac b. Adda (another version : Rab Isaac b. Rab Iddi) said :
4.6: What Scriptural authority is there for the story of David's harp? "Awake, my glory ; awake, psaltery and harp; I will awake the dawn" (Ps. lvii. 9).
4.8: Moses certainly knew [the exact time of midnight], and David also knew it.
4.9: Since David knew it, why did he require a harp ?
4.10: In order that he may be aroused from his sleep.
4.11: And since Moses knew it, what object had he in saying "About mid-night" ?
4.13: that perhaps Pharaoh's astrologers would err and say, "Moses is a liar."
4.15: Teach thy tongue to say, "I do not know," lest thou be led to falsehoods and be apprehended.
4.17: It happened in the middle of the night of the thirteenth [of the first month] which is the beginning of the fourteenth ; and thus spake Moses to Israel,
4.18: "The Holy One, blessed be He, said, 'To-morrow, like the time of midnight, as it is now, I will go forth in the midst of Egypt.'"
4.19: David prayed, "Keep my soul, for I am godly" (Ps. Ixxxvi. 2). [R.] Levi and R. Isaac differ in their interpretation.
4.21: Thus spake David before the Holy One, blessed be He,
4.22: "Lord of the Universe, am I not godly,
4.23: seeing that all the kings of the East and West sleep unto the third hour of the day, but as for me, 'At midnight I rise to give thanks unto Thee' (Ps. cxix. 62)?"
4.25: Thus spake David before the Holy One, blessed be He,
4.26: "Lord of the Universe, am I not godly,
4.27: seeing that all the kings of the East and West sit in companies in all their pomp, whereas my hands are stained with the blood of a foetus or with the placenta in order to pronounce a woman clean to her husband ?
4.29: whatever I do I discuss with my teacher Mephibosheth, saying to him,
4.36: And I was not ashamed [so to do]."
4.37: R. Joshua b. Rab Iddi asked :
4.38: What is the Scriptural authority for this ? "I will also speak of Thy testimonies
4.39: before kings, and will not be ashamed" (Ps. cxix. 46).
4.41: His name was not Mephibosheth but Ishbosheth. Why, then, was he called Mephibosheth?
4.42: Because he used to put David to shame on questions of Halakah.
4.43: On that account David merited that Chileab should issue from him;
4.45: His pame was not Chileab but Daniel. Why, then, was he called Chileab? Because he put Mephibosheth to shame on questions of Halakah; and concerning him Solomon said in his wisdom,
4.46: "My son, if thy heart be wise, my heart will be glad, even mine" (Prov. xxiii. 15), and
4.47: "My son, be wise, and make mine heart glad, that I may answer him that taunteth me" (ibid, xxvii. 11).
4.48: But how could David describe himself as "godly"?
4.49: For behold it is written, "If I had not [lule'] believed to look upon the goodness of the Lord in the land of the living" (Ps. xxvii. 13); and it has been taught in the name of R. Jose :
4.50: Why are there dots over the word lule'?
4.51: David spake before the Holy One, blessed be He,
4.53: I am confident that Thou repayest a good reward to the righteous in the hereafter, but I know not whether I have a portion among them or not.
4.54: Perhaps my sin will cause [me not to]."
4.55: This is like the teaching of R. Jacob b. Iddi who asked: It is written,
4.56: "Behold, I am with thee, and will keep thee whithersoever thou goest" (Gen. xxviii. 15), and then it is written,
4.59: "Perhaps sin will cause [His protection to be withheld]." This is like the teaching:
4.60: "Till Thy people pass over, O Lord, till the people pass over that Thou hast gotten" (Exod. xv. 16).
4.61: — "Till Thy people pass over, O Lord" refers to the first entry [into Canaan]; "till the people pass over that Thou hast gotten" refers to the second entry.
4.63: The Israelites were worthy that a miracle should be performed for them in the days of Ezra
4.64: in the same way that it was performed for them in the days of Joshua, the son of Nun; but sin caused [the miracle to be withheld].
4.65: But the Sages say: Until midnight.
4.66: With whose opinion do the Sages agree?
4.67: If with R. Eliezer's, let them express themselves like R. Eliezer;

5.0: if with Rabban Gamaliel's, let them express themselves like Rabban Gamaliel!
5.1: They certainly agree with Rabban Gamaliel, and the reason they say Until midnight is to keep a man far from transgression.
5.3: The Sages made a "fence" to their words, so that a man shall not come from the field in the evening and say,
5.4: "I will go home, eat a little, drink a little, sleep a little, and after that I will read

5.10: If thou wilt, I can say

5.12: or if thou wilt, I can say

9.68: The first "Hear me" means : that fire may descend from heaven ; the second "hear me" means : that they may not say it is due to sorcery.
9.70: Also with the evening prayer [must a man be careful] ; as it is said,
9.71: "Let my prayer be set forth as incense before Thee, the lifting up of my hands as the evening sacrifice" (Ps. cxli. 2).
9.73: Also with the morning prayer [must a man be careful] ; as it is said,
9.74: "O Lord, in the morning shalt Thou hear my voice ; in the morning will I order my prayer unto Thee, and will look forward" (ibid. v. 4).
9.75: R. Helbo also said in the name of Rab Huna :
9.76: Whoever partakes of the festivity of a bridegroom without felicitating him transgresses the five "voices" ; as it is said,
9.77: "The voice of joy and the voice of gladness, the voice of the bridegroom and the voice of the bride, the voice of them that say. Give thanks to the Lord of Hosts" (Jer. xxxiii. 11).
9.78: If he does felicitate him, what is his reward ?
9.80: He is worthy of Torah which was given amidst five "voices"; as it is said,
9.81: "And it came to pass on the third day, when it was morning, that there were thunders and lightnings and a thick cloud upon the mount, and the voice of a horn exceeding loud... and when the voice of the horn waxed louder and louder, Moses spoke, and God answered him by a voice" (Exod. xix. 16 ff.).
9.83: for it is written, "And all the people perceived the thunderings" (Exod. 20:18)!
9.84: The "voices" referred to are those before the giving of the Torah.
9.86: [If he felicitates the bridegroom] it is as though he had brought a thanksgiving offering ; as it is said,
9.87: "Even of them that bring offerings of thanksgiving into the house of the Lord" (Jer. l.c.).
9.89: It is as though he had rebuilt one of the ruins of Jerusalem ; as it is said,
9.90: "For I will cause the captivity of the land to return as at the first, saith the Lord" (ibid.).
9.91: R. Helbo also said in the name of Rab Huna :
9.92: Every man in whom is the fear of God, his words are heard ; as it is said,
9.93: "The end of the matter, all having been heard, fear God, and keep His commandments, for this is the whole man" (Eccles. xii. 13).
9.94: What means "for this is the whole man"?
9.96: The Holy One, blessed be He, said, The whole universe was only created for his sake.
9.98: Such a man is equal in worth to the whole world.
9.99: R. Simeon b. 'Azzai (another version: R. Simeon b. Zoma) said :
9.100: The whole world has only been created to be subservient to him.
9.101: R. Helbo also said in the name of Rab Huna :
9.102: Whoever is in the habit of greeting his neighbour, and omits to do so a single day, transgresses the injunction
9.103: "Seek peace and pursue it" (Ps. xxxiv. 15).  Should his neighbour greet him and he does not respond, he is called a robber ; as it is said,
9.104: "It is ye that have eaten up the vineyard ; the spoil of the poor is in your houses" (Is. iii. 14).

10.0: Rabbi Yohanan said in the name of Rabbi Yosi:
10.1: How do we know that the Holy One, Blessed be He, prays?
10.2: Because it says: I will bring them to My holy mountain and make them joyful in the house of my prayer. It does not say, 'their prayer,' but 'My prayer': Hence [you learn] that the Holy One, Blessed be He, prays.
10.4: Said Rabbi Zutra ben Tuvia in the name of Rav:
10.5: May it be My will that my compassion will conquer my anger, that my compassion will prevail over my other attributes, that I behave towards my children according to the quality of compassion and that I enter before them within the line of the law.
10.8: Once I entered to offer incense in the innermost sanctuary and I saw Akatriel Yah, the Lord of Hosts. He was seated on an elevated and exalted throne, and he said to me:
10.11: May it be your will that your mercy will conquer your anger, that your mercy will prevail over your other attributes, that you behave towards your children according to the quality of compassion and that you enter before them within the line of the law. He nodded his head to me.
10.12: From here we learn that a blessing from a simple person should not be light in your eyes.
10.13: R. Johanan also said in the name of R. Jose :
10.14: Whence is it that we should not try to appease a man in the time of his wrath? As it is written,
10.15: "My face shall go and I will give thee rest" (Exod. xxxiii. 14).
10.16: The Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moses,
10.17: "Wait for Me until My wrathful countenance shall have passed away, then I will give thee rest."
10.18: Is there ever anger before the Holy One, blessed be He?
10.19: Yes ; as there is a teaching :
10.20: "A God that hath indignation every day" (Ps. vii, 12).
10.21: But how long does His anger last ?
10.23: And how long is a moment?
10.24: A moment is one 58,888th part of an hour ; and nobody has ever been able to fix upon just that moment with the exception of the wicked Balaam, of whom it is written,
10.25: "He knoweth the knowledge of the Most High" (Num. xxiv. 16).
10.26: Was Balaam, then, ignorant of the mind of his ass, and yet acquainted with the knowledge of the Most High?
10.28: it teaches that he knew how to fix upon that moment in which the Holy One, blessed be He, is wrathful. This is the intention of the statement which the prophet made to Israel :
10.29: "O My people, remember now what Balak king of Moab devised, and what Balaam the son of Beor answered him . . .that ye may know the righteous acts of the Lord" (Micah vi. 5).
10.30: What means "that ye may know the righteous acts of the Lord" ?
10.32: The Holy One, blessed be He, said to Israel,
10.33: "Know ye how many are the righteous acts which I have wrought on your behalf, that I was not wrathful in the days of the wicked Balaam ; for had I been wrathful, there would not have been left any remnant of the enemies of Israeli."
10.34: That is the meaning of what Balaam said to Balak,
10.35: "How shall I curse, whom God hath not cursed ? And how shall I execrate, whom the Lord hath not execrated?" (Num. xxiii. 8). This teaches that during all those days He did not execrate.
10.36: How long does His execration last?
10.38: And how long is a moment?
10.39: R. Abin (another version : R. Abina) said :
10.40: The moment lasts as long as it takes to utter the word.
10.41: Whence do we know that He is angry but for a moment?
10.43: "For His anger is but for a moment, His favour is for a life-time" (Ps. 30:6).
10.44: Or if thou wilt, I can say it may be deduced from the following :
10.45: "Hide thyself for a moment until the indignation be overpast" (Is. xxvi. 20).
10.48: During the first three hours of the day when the comb of the cock is white and it stands on one foot.
10.49: But the comb is white at all times !
10.50: During the rest of the day there are many red streaks in it, but not at the afore-mentioned time.
10.51: A certain Min, who lived in the neighbourhood of R. Joshua b. Levi, used to plague him with questions about [the interpretation of] the Scriptures.
10.52: One day R. Joshua took a cock and placed it between the feet of his bed and watched [the comb] closely.
10.53: His intention was to curse the heretic when the moment arrived [in which God was wrathful] ;
10.54: but when the moment arrived, he was sleeping.
10.56: Learn from this that it is not proper to act thus ; for it is written, "His tender mercies are over all His works" (Ps. cxlv. 9), and
10.57: "To punish is also not good for the righteous" (Prov. xvii. 26).
10.58: It has been taught in the name of R. Meir :
10.59: At the hour when the sun shines forth and all the kings of the East and West place their crowns upon their heads and worship it, at once the Holy One, blessed be He, is filled with wrath.
10.60: Further said R. Johanan in the name of R. Jose :
10.61: One chastisement in the heart of a man is better than many lashes ; as it is said,
10.62: "And she shall run after her lovers, but she shall not overtake them, and she shall seek them, but shall not find them ; then shall she say [in her heart], I will go and return to my first husband ; for then was it better with me than now " (Hos. ii. 9).
10.64: It is better than a hundred lashes ; as it is said,
10.65: "A rebuke entereth deeper into a man of understanding than a hundred stripes into a fool" (Prov. xvii. 10).
10.66: R. Johanan also said in the name of R. Jose :
10.67: Three things Moses sought of the Holy One, blessed be He, and He granted them.
10.68: He sought that the Shekinah should rest upon Israel, and He granted it ; as it is said,
10.69: "Is it not in that Thou goest with us?" (Exod. xxxiii. 16). He sought that the Shekinah should not rest upon the other peoples of the world, and He granted it ; as it is said,
10.70: "So that we are distinguished, I and Thy people " (ibid.). He sought that God should show him His ways, and He granted it ; as it is said,
10.74: why is there a righteous man enjoying prosperity and a righteous man afflicted with adversity ? Why is there a wicked man enjoying prosperity and a wicked man afflicted with adversity?"
10.76: "Moses, the righteous man who enjoys prosperity is the son of a righteous father ; the righteous man who is afflicted with adversity is the son of a wicked father ; the wicked man who enjoys prosperity is the son of a righteous father ; the wicked man who is afflicted with adversity is the son of a wicked father."
10.78: "The righteous man who enjoys prosperity is the son of a righteous father ; the righteous man who is afflicted with adversity is the son of a wicked father."
10.81: "Visiting the iniquity of the fathers upon the children" (Exod. xxxiv. 7) and it is also written,
10.82: "The children shall not be put to death for the fathers" (Deut. xxiv. 16)!
10.83: We set these verses one against the other and conclude there is no contradiction ; because the former passage refers to those children who continue in their fathers' ways, and the latter to those who do not continue in their fathers' ways.
10.84: But [we may suppose that] God answered Moses thus wise,
10.85: "The righteous man who enjoys prosperity is perfectly righteous ; the righteous man who is afflicted with adversity is not perfectly righteous ; the wicked man who enjoys prosperity is not perfectly wicked ; the wicked man who is afflicted with adversity is perfectly wicked."
10.86: This is opposed to the teaching of R. Meir ;
10.87: for R. Meir said that God granted two of Moses' requests and refused one. As it is said,
10.88: "I will be gracious to whom I will be gracious" (Exod. xxxiii. 19), i.e. although he may not be deserving; "And I will show mercy on whom I will show mercy" (ibid.), i.e. although he may not be deserving.
10.89: "And He said, Thou canst not see My face" (ibid. v. 20). It has been taught in the name of R. Joshua b. Karhah : Thus spake the Holy One, blessed be He, to Moses,
10.90: "When I was willing [that thou shouldest see My face] thou wert not willing ; so now that thou art willing, I am not willing."
10.91: This disagrees with the teaching of R. Samuel b. Nahmani in the name of R. Jonathan,
10.92: viz. By virtue of three [meritorious acts] Moses became worthy of three [favours].
10.93: By virtue of "Moses hid his face" (Exod. iii. 6), he was granted the shining of his countenance (cf.ibid. xxxiv. 29 f.).
10.94: By virtue of "For he was afraid" (ibid. iii. 6), he merited "And they were afraid to come nigh him" (ibid, xxxiv. 30). By virtue of "[He was afraid] to behold God" (ibid. iii. 6), he merited "The similitude of the Lord doth he behold" (Num. xii. 8).
10.95: "And I will take away My hand, and thou shalt see My back" (Exod. xxxiii. 23). Rab Hanna b. Bizna said in the name of R. Simeon Hasida :
10.96: This teaches that the Holy One, blessed be He, showed Moses the knot of the Tefillin.
10.97: R. Johanan also said in the name of R. Jose :
10.98: Any propitious utterance which issues from the mouth of the Holy One, blessed be He, though it be conditional, He does not retract [though the condition be not fulfilled].
10.100: From Moses our teacher; as it is said,
10.101: "Let Me alone, that I may destroy them, and blot out their name from under heaven ; and I will make of thee a nation mightier and greater than they" (Deut. ix. 14).
10.102: Although Moses supplicated God against this decree and averted it, nevertheless He fulfilled [the blessing contained therein] in his seed ; as it is said, "The sons of Moses : Gershom and Eliezer" (I Chron. xxiii. 15),
10.103: and then "And the sons of Eliezer were : Rehabiah the chief. And Eliezer had no other sons ; but the sons of Rehabiah were very [lema'alah] many" (ibid. v. 17).
10.105: They were upwards of [lema'alah] sixty myriads. One draws an analogy from the occurrence of the word rabah "many" in the following passages : here it is written, "they were very many," and elsewhere it is written, "And the children of Israel were fruitful, and increased abundantly, and became very many" (Exod. i. 7).

11.0: R. Johanan said in the name of R. Simeon b. Johai :
11.1: From the day that the Holy One, blessed be He, created the Universe, nobody called Him "Lord" until Abraham came and so called Him ; as it is said,
11.2: "And he said, O Lord God, whereby shall I know that I shall inherit it?" (Gen. xv. 8).
11.4: Also, Daniel was only answered because of Abraham ; as it is said,
11.5: "Now therefore, O our God, hearken unto the prayer of Thy servant, and to his supplications, and cause Thy face to shine upon Thy sanctuary that is desolate, for the Lord's sake" (Dan. ix. 17).
11.6: It should have read "for Thy sake" !
11.7: But [he means] "for the sake of Abraham, who called Thee 'Lord'."
11.8: R. Johanan also said in the name of R. Simeon b. Johai:
11.9: Whence is it that we should not try to appease a man in the time of his wrath?
11.11: "My face shall go, and I will give thee rest" (Exod. xxxiii. 14).
11.12: R. Johanan also said in the name of R. Simeon b. Johai:
11.13: From the day that the Holy One, blessed be He, created the Universe, nobody praised Him until Leah came and praised Him ; as it is said, "This time will I praise the Lord" (Gen. xxix. 35).
11.16: "See the difference between my son and the son of my father-in-law ;
11.17: for the son of my father-in-law, although he voluntarily sold his birthright — as it is written, 'And he sold his birthright unto Jacob' (ibid. xxv. 33) — see what is written of him,
11.19: and 'Is not he rightly called Jacob? for he hath supplanted me these two times' (ibid. 5:36).
11.20: But as for my son, although Joseph forcibly deprived him of his birthright — as it is written,
11.21: 'But, forasmuch as he defiled his father's couch, his birthright was given unto the sons of  Joseph' (I Chron. v. 1 ) —
11.22: nevertheless he was not jealous of him; for it is written,
11.23: 'And Reuben heard it, and delivered him out of their hand' (Gen. xxxrii. 21)."
11.26: Because she was worthy that David should issue from her, who delighted the Holy One, blessed be He, with songs and praises.
11.27: Whence do we learn that the name of a person affects his life?
11.30: "Come, behold the works of the Lord, Who hath made shammot ['desolations'] in the earth" (Ps. xlvi. 9). Read not shammot but shemot "names."
11.31: R. Johanan also said in the name of R. Simeon b. Johai :
11.32: More painful is filial impiety in a man's house than the wars of Gog and Magog; as it is said,
11.33: "A Psalm of David, when he fled from Absalom his son" (ibid. iii. 1), after which it is written,
11.34: "Lord, how many are mine adversaries become ! Many are they that rise up against me" (ibid. v. 2),
11.35: But in connection with the wars of Gog and Magog it is written,
11.36: "Why are the nations in an uproar? And why do the peoples mutter in vain?" (ibid. ii. 1); but it is not written, "How many are mine adversaries become!"
11.37: "A Psalm of David, when he fled from Absalom his son" (ibid. iii. 1). "A Psalm of David"!
11.38: Rather should we have expected "A Lament of David"!
11.40: A parable : To what is it like ?
11.41: To a man to whom it is said, "To-morrow a bill of debt will be issued against thee." Before he sees it, he worries; but having seen it, he rejoices. So was it likewise with David. When the Holy One, blessed be He, said to him, "Behold, I will raise up evil against thee out of thine own house" (II Sam. xii. 11), he grieved; for he said,
11.42: "Perhaps it refers to a slave or illegitimate child who will have no pity on me."
11.43: When, however, he found that it was Absalom, he rejoiced; and therefore he uttered a Psalm.
11.44: R. Johanan also said in the name of R. Simeon b. Johai :
11.45: It is permissible to contend with the wicked in this world; as it is said,
11.46: "They that forsake the law praise the wicked, but such as keep the law contend with him" (Prov. xxviii, 4).
11.47: There is a teaching to the same effect : R. Dostai b. R. Mattun said :
11.48: It is permissible to contend with the wicked in this world ; as it is said,
11.49: "They that forsake the law praise the wicked," etc.
11.50: Should a man try to mislead thee, saying,
11.51: Lo, it is written, "Contend not with evil-doers, neither be thou envious against them that work unrighteousness" (Ps. xxxvii 1),
11.53: Only he whose conscience pricks him speaks thus.
11.54: Nay, "Contend not with evil-doers" means, to emulate them; "be not envious against them that work unrighteousness" means, to be like them. And so it is stated,
11.55: "Let not thy heart envy sinners, but be in the fear of the Lord all the day" (Prov. xxiii. 17).
11.57: For behold, R. Isaac has said :
11.58: If thou seest a wicked man upon whom fortune smiles, do not contend with him ; as it is said,
11.59: "His ways prosper at all times" (Ps. x. 5).
11.60: More than that, [if thou contendest with him] he will be justified, in judgment; as it is said,
11.61: "Thy judgments are far above out of his sight" (ibid.).
11.62: More even than that, he will see his desire on his enemies; as it is said,
11.63: "As for his enemies, he puffeth at them" (ibid.)!
11.65: R. Isaac speaks of one who is wicked in his personal affairs, the other of one who is wicked in religious matters.
11.67: I can say that both refer to religious matters, and still there is no contradiction ;
11.68: for R. Isaac may be taken to mean the wicked upon whom fortune smiles, and the other the wicked upon whom fortune does not smile.
11.70: I can say that both refer to the wicked upon whom fortune smiles, and still there is no contradiction; for R. Johanan may be understood as speaking of a perfectly righteous man [contending with the wicked], and the other of one who is not perfectly righteous. For Rab Huna said :
11.71: What means that which is written, "Wherefore lookest Thou, when they deal treacherously, and holdest Thy peace, when the wicked swalloweth up the man that is more righteous than he"? (Hab. i. 13). Does, then, the wicked swallow up the righteous?
11.73: "The Lord will not leave him in his hand" (Ps. xxxvii. 33) and
11.74: "There shall no mischief befall the righteous" (Prov. xii. 21)!
11.76: "the wicked swalloweth up the man that is more righteous than he,"
11.77: but a perfectly righteous man he doth not swallow up.
11.78: Or if thou wilt, I can say that
11.79: when fortune smiles upon him, it is different.
11.80: R. Johanan also said in the name of R. Simeon b. Johai :
11.81: Whoever fixes a place for his prayer, his enemies fall beneath him; as it is said :
11.82: "And I will appoint a place for My people Israel, and will plant them, that they may dwell in their own place, and be disquieted no more ; neither shall the children of wickedness afflict them any more as at the first" (II Sam. vii. 10).
11.84: It is written here "to afflict them," but in the parallel passage (I Chron. xvii. 9) it is written "to exterminate them"! The answer is: At first "to afflict them" and finally "exterminate them."
11.85: R. Johanan also said in the name of R. Simeon b. Johai :
11.86: Greater is the service of Torah than its study : as it is said,
11.87: "Elisha the son of Shaphat is here, who poured water on the hands of Elijah" (II Kings iii. 11). It is not mentioned that he studied [with Elijah] but that he poured water.
11.88: That teaches that its service is greater than its study.
11.90: "Why does not the master come to the Synagogue to pray ?"
11.94: "Then the master should gather ten together and pray [with a quorum]."
11.96: "It is too great a trouble for me."
11.97: "Then the master should tell the messenger of the congregation at the time when the congregation prays to come and inform him."
11.101: "Because R. Johanan said in the name of R. Simeon b. Johai :

12.0: What means that which is written, 'But as for me, let my prayer be unto Thee, O God, in an acceptable time' (Ps. Ixix. 14)?
12.1: When is an 'acceptable time'? At the time when the congregation prays."
12.2: R. Jose b. R. Hannina derived it from the following :
12.3: "Thus saith the Lord, In an acceptable time have I answered thee" (Is. xlix. 8).
12.4: R. Aha b. R. Hannina derived it from the following :
12.5: "Behold, God despiseth not the mighty" (Job xxxvi. 5); and it is written,
12.6: "He hath redeemed my soul in peace so that none came nigh me ; for they were many with me" (Ps. Iv. 19).
12.7: There is a teaching to the same effect : R. Nathan said :
12.8: Whence is it that the Holy One, blessed be He, does not reject the prayer offered by many? As it is said,
12.9: "Behold, God despiseth not the mighty"; and it is written,
12.10: "He hath redeemed my soul in peace so that none came nigh me ; for they were many with me."
12.11: The Holy One, blessed be He, said, "Whoever occupies himself with Torah, practises benevolent acts and prays with the congregation, I ascribe it to him as though he had redeemed Me and My son [Israel] from [exile] among the peoples of the world."
12.13: Whoever has a Synagogue in his town, and does not enter it to pray, is called "an evil neighbour"; as it is said,
12.14: "Thus saith the Lord, As for all Mine evil neighbours, that touch the inheritance which I have caused My people Israel to inherit" (Jer. xii. 14).
12.15: More than that, he causes exile to come upon himself and his sons ; as it is said,
12.16: "Behold, I will pluck them up from off their land, and will pluck up the house of Judah from among them" (ibid.).
12.17: It was said to R. Johanan,
12.18: "There are old men to be found in Babylon."
12.20: "It is written 'that your days may be multiplied, and the days of your children, upon the land' (Deut. xi. 21); but not outside the land [of Israel] !"
12.22: [that the old men are in the Synagogue early and late,] he said,
12.23: "It is this which helps them [to live long]."
12.24: This is like what R. Joshua b. Levi said to his sons :
12.25: Rise early and stay up late to enter the Synagogue, so that you may prolong your life.
12.26: R. Aha b. R. Hannina asked,
12.27: What is the Scriptural authority for this ? "Happy is the man that hearkeneth to Me, watching daily at My gates, waiting at the posts of My doors" (Prov. viii. 34), after which it is written,
12.28: "For whoso findeth me findeth life" (ibid. v. 35).
12.30: A man should always enter two doors in the Synagogue and then pray ; as it is said, "Waiting at the posts of My doors."
12.33: A man should penetrate into the Synagogue a distance which equals the width of two doors, and then offer prayer.
12.34: "For this let every one that is godly pray unto Thee in the time of finding" (Ps. xxxii. 6). R. Hannina said:
12.35: "In the time of finding" refers to [the choice of] a wife ; as it is said,
12.36: "Whoso findeth a wife findeth a great good" (Prov. xviii. 22).
12.37: In the West when a man marries, they say to him,
12.39: Masa', as it is written, "Whoso findeth [masa'] a wife findeth a great good"; Mose', as it is written,
12.40: "And I find [mose'] more bitter than death the woman" etc. (Eccles. vii. 26).
12.42: "In the time of finding" refers to Torah; as it is said,
12.43: "For whoso findeth me findeth life, and obtaineth favour of the Lord" (Prov. viii. 35).
12.45: "In the time of finding [meso']" refers to death ; as it is said, "The issues [tosa'ot] of death" (Ps. Ixviii. 21).
12.46: There is a teaching to the same effect :
12.47: Nine hundred and three varieties of death have been created in the world ; as it is said,
12.48: "The issues of death." Tosa'ot has that numerical value.
12.49: The severest of them all is croup, and the lightest is the kiss of death.
12.50: Croup is like a thorn in a ball of clipped wool which tears backwards. Others say
12.51: it is like the whirling waters at the entrance of a canal.
12.52: The kiss of death is like taking a hair out of milk.
12.54: "In the time of finding" refers to burial.
12.56: What is the Scriptural authority for this? "Who rejoice unto exultation and are glad, when they can find the grave" (Job iii. 22).
12.57: Rabbah b. Rab Shela said : Hence the popular saying :
12.58: "Let a man pray for peace even to the last shovelful of earth."
12.60: "In the time of finding" refers to a privy.
12.61: In the West, they said that
12.62: the interpretation of Mar Zotra was the best of all.
12.63: Raba said to Rafram b. Pappa :
12.64: Let the master tell us some of those excellent things which thou reportest in the name of Rab Hisda, relating to the Synagogue.
12.65: He replied, Thus said Rab Hisda :
12.66: What means that which is written, "The Lord loveth the gates of Zion [Siyyon] more than all the dwellings of Jacob" (Ps. Ixxxvii. 2)? The Lord loveth the gates distinguished [mesuyyanim] for Halakah more than Synagogues and Houses of Study.
12.67: That agrees with what R. Hiyya b. Ammi said in the name of 'Ulla :
12.68: Since the day the Temple was destroyed, there is left to the Holy One, blessed be He, in His Universe the four cubits of Halakah alone.
12.70: At first I used to study at home and pray in Synagogue, but after hearing the statement of R. Hiyya b. Ammi in the name of 'Ulla —
12.71: "Since the day the Temple was destroyed, there is left to the Holy One, blessed be He, in His Universe the four cubits of Halakah alone" I only pray where I study.
12.72: R. Ammi and R. Assi, although there were thirteen Synagogues in Tiberias, used to pray only between the pillars where they studied.
12.73: R. Hiyya b. Ammi said in the name of 'Ulla :
12.74: Greater is he who enjoys the fruit of his labour than the fearer of Heaven ; for with regard to the fearer of Heaven it is written,
12.75: "Happy is the man that feareth the Lord" (ibid. cxii. 1), but with regard to him who enjoys the fruit of his labour it is written,
12.76: "When thou eatest the labour of thy hands, happy shalt thou be, and it shall be well with thee" (ibid, cxxviii. 2) — "happy shalt thou be" in this world, "and it shall be well with thee" in the world to come. It is not written, "and it shall be well with thee" about the fearer of Heaven.
12.77: R. Hiyya b. Ammi also said in the name of 'Ulla :
12.78: A man should always reside in the same place as his teacher, for so long as Shimei the son of Gera lived, Solomon did not marry the daughter of Pharaoh.
12.80: A man should not reside [in the same place as his teacher]!
12.82: the former referring to the pupil who submits to his master, the latter to him who does not.
12.83: Rab Huna b. Judah stated that R. Menahem said in the name of R. Ammi :
12.84: What means that which is written, "They that forsake the Lord shall be consumed" (Is. i. 28)?  This refers to one who leaves a Scroll of the Law [unrolled] and goes out [from the Synagogue].
12.85: R. Abbahu used to go out between man and man.
12.87: How is it between verse and verse [may one go out]?
12.89: Rab Sheshet used to turn his face [away from the Scroll] and study, saying,
12.91: Rab Huna b. Judah stated that R. Menahem said in the name of R. Ammi :
12.92: A person should always complete his [study of the] Torah portion with the congregation, [by reading the] verses twice and translation once.

13.1: "Ataroth and Dibon" (Num. xxxii. 3) — for whoever finishes his Parashah with the congregation, his days and years are prolonged.
13.2: Rab Bebai b. Abbai thought to complete the Parashot of the whole year on the eve of the Day of Atonement;
13.3: but Hiyya b. Rab of Difti taught him :
13.4: It is written, "Ye shall afflict your souls, in the ninth day of the month at even" (Lev, xxiii. 32). Do we fast on the ninth ?
13.5: Surely it is on the tenth that we fast !
13.6: But the intention is to tell thee that
13.7: whoever eats and drinks on the ninth, the Scriptures ascribe it to him as though he fasted on the ninth and tenth.
13.8: He then thought to anticipate [the reading of the Parashot]; but a certain Elder said to him ; We have learnt that
13.9: one should neither anticipate nor postpone [the reading of the Parashot];
13.10: as R. Joshua b. Levi said to his sons,
13.11: "Finish your Parashot with the congregation, twice the Hebrew text and once the Targum; and also be careful to sever the jugular vein [of a bird when slaughtering] in accord with the opinion of R. Judah —
13.12: for there is a Mishnaic teaching :
13.14: [One must cut] until he severs the jugular vein —
13.15: and be careful [to honour] an old man, who has forgotten his learning involuntarily: for we say that
13.16: both the whole tables of stone and the pieces of the broken tables were placed in the Ark."
13.18: When you cut meat, do not cut it upon your hand —
13.22: on account of spoiling the meal —
13.23: and do not sit upon the bed of an Aramaean woman ; and do not pass behind a Synagogue at the time when the congregation is at prayer.
13.24: [He advised them] not to sit upon the bed of an Aramaean woman.
13.26: Do not lie down to sleep without first reading the Shema';
13.30: he really meant an Aramaean woman, because of what happened to Rab Pappa.
13.31: For Rab Pappa went to the house of an Aramaean woman, who brought out a couch for him and told him
13.34: "I will not sit down until thou raisest up the couch."
13.35: They lifted it up and found a dead child there.
13.36: On this account the Sages say :
13.37: It is forbidden to sit upon the bed of an Aramaean woman.
13.38: [His advice] "Do not pass behind a Synagogue at the time when the congregation is at prayer" supports the teaching of R. Joshua b. Levi who said:
13.39: It is forbidden a man to pass behind a Synagogue at the time when the congregation is at prayer,
13.41: This only applies when the building has no other entrance ; but should it have another entrance, we can have no objection ;
13.42: further it applies only when there is no other Synagogue [in the town], but should there be another Synagogue, we can have no objection ;
13.43: further it applies only to one who is not carrying a load, or is not running, or is not wearing Tefillin ; but in any of such cases, we can have no objection.
13.44: There is a teaching : R. 'Akiba said :
13.45: For three things I admire the Medes :
13.46: When they cut up meat, they only do so upon the table ; when they kiss, they only kiss on the hand ; and when they hold a consultation, they only do so in a field.
13.48: What Scriptural authority is there for this ? "And Jacob sent and called Rachel and Leah to the field" (Gen. xxxi. 4).
13.49: There is a teaching : Rabban Gamaliel said :
13.50: For three things I admire the Persians :
13.51: They are temperate with their food, modest in the privy, and modest in another matter.
13.52: "I have commanded My consecrated ones" (Is. xiii. 3).
13.54: These are the Persians who are consecrated and destined for Gehinnom.
13.55: Rabban Gamaliel said : Until the rise of dawn.
13.56: Rab Judah said in the name of Samuel :
13.57: The Halakah is in accord with Rabban Gamaliel.
13.58: There is a teaching : R. Simeon b. Johai said :
13.59: There are times when a man reads the Shema twice in a night, once before the rise of dawn and once after the rise of dawn, and thereby fulfils his obligation both for the day and night.
13.61: Thou sayest, "There are times when a man reads the Shema' twice in a night"; consequently, after the rise of dawn is still night ! And it continues,
13.62: "The man thereby fulfils his obligation both for the day and night" ; consequently, it is day !
13.63: No ; it is certainly still night ; and that he calls it "day" is because there are people who rise at that early hour.
13.64: Rab Aha b. Hannina said in the name of R. Joshua b. Levi :
13.65: The Halakah is in accord with R. Simeon b. Johai.
13.66: There are some who apply the statement of Rab Aha b. Hannina to the following : There is a teaching : R. Simeon b. Johai said in the name of R. 'Akiba :
13.67: There are times when a man reads the Shema' twice in a day, once before sunrise and once after sunrise, and thereby fulfils his obligation both for the day and night.
13.69: Thou sayest, "There are times when a man reads the Shema' twice in a day"; consequently, before sunrise is day ! And it continues,
13.70: "The man thereby fulfils his obligation [[fol. 9a.]] both for the day and night" ; consequently it is still night !

14.0: No ; it is certainly day, and that he calls it "night" is because there are people who retire to rest at that hour.
14.1: Rab Aha b. R. Hannina said in the name of R. Joshua b. Levi :
14.2: The Halakah is in accord with R. Simeon who spoke in the name of R. 'Akiba.
14.4: This is so, only one does not say, "Cause us, O Lord our God, to lie down."
14.5: When Rab Isaac b. Joseph came [from Palestine], he said :
14.6: The statement of Rab Aha b. R. Hannina in the name of R. Joshua b. Levi was not explicitly said but was inferred.
14.7: For it happened that two Rabbis became intoxicated at the marriage feast of R. Joshua b. Levi's son, and they omitted to read the Shema'. They came before R. Joshua b. Levi who said :
14.8: R. Simeon is worthy that one should rely upon bis opinion in a time of emergency.
14.9: It once happened that his sons returned from a feast, etc.
14.10: Before then, had they never heard this teaching of Rabban Gamaliel ?
14.11: But they spoke to him thus :
14.12: The Rabbis differ from thee, and where an individual differs
14.13: from the many, the Halakah is in accord with the many. Or perhaps, the Rabbis agree with thee, and the reason that they declare [that the evening Shema' may be read] "Until midnight" is in order to keep a man far from transgression ?
14.15: The Rabbis hold the same view as myself, and you are under the obligation [to read the Shema'];
14.16: and the reason they say "Until midnight" is to keep a man far from transgression.
14.17: And not only in this connection do they so decide.
14.18: But did Rabban Gamaliel say "Until midnight" that he teaches "and not only in this connection do they so decide"?
14.19: Nay, thus spake Rabban Gamaliel to his sons :
14.20: Even according to the Rabbis who say "Until midnight," the obligation continues until the rise of dawn ; and the reason they say "Until midnight" is to keep a man far from transgression.
14.21: The duty of burning the fat, etc.
14.22: But he does not mention the eating of the Paschal offering!
14.23: And I quote against the Mishnah:
14.24: The reading of the evening Shema', and Hallel on the Passover night, and the eating of the Paschal offering — their obligation continues until the rise of dawn !
14.25: Rab Joseph said : There is no contradiction ; the statement of the Mishnah being the view of R. Eleazar b. 'Azariah, the other the view of R. 'Akiba.
14.27: "And they shall eat the flesh in that night" (Exod. xii. 8). R. Eleazar b. 'Azariah said,
14.28: "Here it is stated, 'in that night' and the same phrase occurs in 'For I will go through the land of Egypt in that night' (ibid. 5:12) ; as in the latter passage it means 'until midnight', so also in the former it means 'until midnight'."
14.30: "But has it not already been stated, 'Ye shall eat it in haste' (ibid. v. 11) — i.e. until the time of hastening?"
14.31: R. Eleazar b. 'Azariah asked, "If so, why is there a teaching to state 'in that night'?" R. 'Akiba answered, "One might otherwise have thought that the Paschal offering could be eaten like the other holy offerings during the day ; therefore there is a teaching to state 'in that night,' meaning
14.32: it must be eaten at night, not during the day."
14.33: According to R. Eleazar b. 'Azariah who uses the argument of Gezerah Shawah, it is quite right that it was necessary to state "in that night"; but how does R. 'Akiba explain the word "that"?
14.34: [He declares] that its purpose is to exclude the following night ;
14.35: for it might have occurred to thee to say that since the Paschal offering belongs to the class of things holy in a minor degree, and peace offerings are in the same category, as the peace offerings might be eaten within two days and a night, so also the Paschal offering might be eaten two nights instead of two days, and therefore might be eaten any time during two nights and one day ! Therefore it informs us "in that night," i.e. it must be eaten that night and no other.
14.36: And R. Eleazar b. 'Azariah? He deduces that from
14.37: "And ye shall let nothing of it remain until the morning" (Exod. xii. 10).
14.39: If one deduced it from this passage, I might have said,
14.43: "Morning," used generally, means only the first morning.
14.44: These Tannaim are like those other Tannaim; for there is a teaching :
14.45: "There shalt thou offer the Passover-offering at even, at the going down of the sun, at the season that thou camest forth out of Egypt" (Deut. xvi. 6).
14.47: "At even" thou shalt sacrifice ; "at the going down of the sun" thou shalt eat it ; "at the season that thou camest forth out of Egypt" thou shalt burn [the remainder].
14.49: "At even" thou shalt sacrifice ; "at the going down of the sun" thou shalt eat it ; and how long mayest thou continue eating it? Until "the season that thou camest forth out of Egypt."
14.51: Everybody admits that the Israelites were only redeemed from Egypt at even ; as it is said, "The Lord thy God brought thee forth out of Egypt by night" (ibid. v. I); but they actually left Egypt by day ; as it is said, "On the morrow after the Passover, the children of Israel went out with a high hand " (Nam. xxxiii. 3).
14.52: What is the point of disagreement? The time of "hastening."
14.54: it refers to the haste of the Egyptians; but R. 'Akiba holds that
14.55: it refers to the haste of the Israelites.
14.56: There is a teaching to the same effect :
14.57: "The Lord thy God brought thee forth out of Egypt by night" (Deut. xvi. 1). Was it in the night they went out?
14.58: Surely they went out during the day ; as it is said,
14.59: "On the morrow after the Passover the children of Israel went out with a high hand" (Num. xxxiii. 3) !
14.61: this teaches that the redemption began for them at even.
14.62: "Speak now [na'] in the ears of the people" etc. (Exod. xi. 2). In the school of R. Jannai they said :
14.63: The word [na'] always expresses a request. The Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moses,
14.64: "I request thee. Go and say to the Israelites :
14.65: I beg of you to ask of the Egyptians vessels of silver and vessels of gold, so that the righteous one shall not say,

15.1: 'And they shall serve them, and they shall afflict them' (Gen. xv. 13) He did fulfil in them, but 'and afterward shall they come out with great substance' (ibid. v. 14) He did not fulfil in them."
15.3: "Would that we could escape with our lives!"
15.4: A Parable: [It may be likened] to a man who was imprisoned in a dungeon, and people came to tell him,
15.5: "To-morrow thou wilt be released from the dungeon and be presented with a large sum of money." He replies to them,
15.6: "I beg of you to release me to-day, and I ask for nothing more."
15.7: "They let them have what they asked" (Exod. xii. 36).
15.9: This teaches that they let them have what they asked against their will.
15.11: Against the will of the Egyptians;
15.13: Against the will of the Israelites.
15.14: Those who say it was against the will of the Egyptians,
15.15: because it is written, "And she that tarrieth at home divideth the spoil" (Ps. Ixviii. 13).
15.16: Those who say it was against the will of the Israelites, because of the burden.
15.19: This teaches that they made it like a fort without provisions,
15.21: They made it like a pond without fish.
15.23: R. Ammi said: The Holy One, blessed be He, spake to Moses,
15.25: I was with you in this servitude, and I will be with you in the servitude of the kingdoms."
15.28: sufficient is the evil in its time."
15.29: The Holy One, blessed be He, said to him,
15.30: "Go say to them, I am hath sent me unto you" (ibid.).
15.31: "Hear me, O Lord, hear me " (I Kings xviii. 37).
15.33: Why did Elijah exclaim "Hear me" twice?
15.34: This teaches that Elijah spake before the Holy One, blessed be He,
15.36: hear me, that fire may descend from heaven and consume all that is upon the altar; and hear me, that Thou mayest divert their mind so that they say not it was the effect of sorcery; as it is said,
15.37: 'For Thou didst turn their heart backward' (ibid.)."
15.38: MISHNAH  II From what time may the Shema' be read in the morning ?
15.39: From the time that one can distinguish between blue and white.
15.41: Between blue and green. And he may finish it any time until sunrise.
15.43: Until the third hour, for so is the custom of kings to rise at the third hour.
15.44: He who reads from that time onward incurs no loss, for he is to be regarded as one reading in the Torah.
15.45: GEMARA What is to be understood by "between blue and white"?
15.46: Is it to be supposed between a lump of white wool and a lump of blue wool ? That can be distinguished also at night !
15.48: between the blueness in it and the whiteness in it.
15.49: There is a teaching : R. Meir says :
15.50: [The morning Shema' is to be read] from the time one can distinguish between a wolf and a dog.
15.52: Between an ass and a wild ass.
15.54: When he can see an associate of his at a distance of four cubits and recognise him.
15.56: The Halakah is in accord with the "others."
15.58: [The Halakah is] in accord with the "others" with respect to the Tefillah; but with respect to the Shema' it is in accord with the Wetikin. For R. Johanan said:
15.59: The Wetikin used to conclude it with the sunrise.
15.60: There is a teaching to the same effect :
15.61: The Wetikin used to conclude it with the sunrise in order to unite the Geullah with the Tefillah, and consequently pray in the day.
15.63: What is the Scriptural authority foe this? "They shall fear Thee with the sun, and before the moon, throughout all generations" (Ps. Ixxii. 5).
15.64: R. Jose b. Eliakim testified in the name of the Holy Congregation of Jerusalem:
15.65: Whoever unites the Ge'ullah with the Tefillah will meet with no mishap all that day.
15.68: For lo, I united them but mishap befel me!"
15.71: That thou didst carry myrtle into the king's palace? Why, thou shouldest even have offered some reward to be privileged to behold a king. For R. Johanan has said :
15.72: A man should always be eager to run to meet a king of Israel ; and not only to meet an Israelite king, but even a king of the other nations, for if he be worthy, he will distinguish between the kings of Israel and the kings of other peoples."
15.74: When thou goest up there [to Palestine], make inquiries about the welfare of my brother, Rab Berona, in the presence of the whole college ; for he is a great man and rejoices in [the performance of] the commandments.
15.75: On one occasion he united the Ge'ullah with the Tefillah, and laughter did not cease from his mouth all that day.
15.76: How was he able to unite them?
15.77: For lo, R, Johanan has said :
15.78: At the commencement of the Tefillah one should say
15.79: "O Lord, open Thou my lips" (Ps. li. 17) and at the conclusion "Let the words of my mouth etc." (ibid. xix. 15) !
15.81: [R. Johanan's statement] refers to the Tefillah of the evening.
15.83: Who will inherit the world to come? He who unites the Ge'ullah of the evening to the Tefillah of the evening!
15.85: Then it must refer to the Tefillah of the afternoon service.
15.87: Thou mayest even suppose that it refers to all of them ; for, since the Rabbis instituted it in the Tefillah it is to be considered as part thereof. If thou dost not admit this, how could one unite them in the evening,
15.88: since one has to say the prayer "Cause us, O Lord our God, to lie down"!
15.89: But since the Rabbis instituted that prayer, it is considered part of the Ge'ullah ; and so here also, since the Rabbis instituted "O Lord, open etc." in the Tefillah, it is to be considered part thereof.
15.90: Since the verse : "Let the words of my mouth be acceptable before Thee" might with equal propriety be said at the conclusion or the commencement [of the Tefillah],
15.91: why did the Rabbis institute it at the end of the Eighteen Benedictions?
15.92: Let it be said at the commencement!
15.93: R. Judah, the son of R. Simeon b. Pazzi, answered :
15.94: Since David only says this verse after eighteen Psalms, therefore the Rabbis arranged it at the end of the Eighteen Benedictions.
15.95: How so eighteen Psalms — there are nineteen!
15.96: "Happy is the man" (Ps. i. 1) and "Why are the nations in an uproar" (ibid. ii. 1) form one Psalm.
15.97: For R. Judah, the son of R. Simeon b. Pazzi, has said :
15.98: David composed one hundred and three Psalms, and did not say Hallelujah until he had seen the overthrow of the wicked ; as it is said,
15.99: "Let sinners cease out of the earth, and let the wicked be no more. Bless the Lord, O my soul. Hallelujah" (ibid, civ, 35).
15.100: How so one hundred and three Psalms — there are one hundred and four!
15.102: "Happy is the man" and "Why are the nations in an uproar" are one Psalm.
15.103: For R. Samuel b. Nahmani said in the name of R. Jonathan:

16.0: Every Psalm which was dear to David he opened with "Happy" and concluded with "Happy."
16.1: He opened with "Happy" as it is written, "Happy is the man" (ibid. i. 1 ) and concluded with "Happy" as it is written, "Happy are all they that take refuge in Him" (ibid. ii. 12).
16.2: There were some lawless men living in the neighbourhood of R. Meir, and they used to vex him sorely. Once R. Meir prayed that they should die.
16.5: Is it because it is written,
16.6: 'Let sinners cease out of the earth'?  But has the text hoteim?
16.8: Glance also at the end of the verse,
16.9: 'And let the wicked be no more' — i.e. when 'sins will cease,' then 'the wicked will be no more.'
16.10: Rather shouldest thou pray that they repent and they be no more wicked."
16.11: R. Meir offered prayer on their behalf and they repented.
16.13: : It is written, "Sing, O barren, thou that didst not bear" (Is. liv. 1 ). Is the woman to sing because she did not bear?
16.16: glance at the end of the verse ; for it is written,
16.17: 'For more are the children of the desolate than the children of the married wife, saith the Lord.'
16.18: But what means, 'barren woman, thou that didst not bear '? Sing, O community of Israel, who art like a barren woman that hath not borne children for Gehinnom — like you."
16.19: A Min said to R. Abbahu : It is written "A Psalm of David, when he fled from Absalom his son" (Ps. iii. 1)
16.20: and also "Of David, Michtam ; when he fled from Saul, in the cave" (ibid. Ivii. 1). Which incident happened first?
16.21: Surely the incident of Saul happened first ; then he should record it first !
16.23: For you who do not use the rule of juxtaposition it is a difficulty, but not for us who do make use of it. For R. Johanan said :
16.24: Whence is the rule of juxtaposition derived from the Torah? As it is said :
16.25: "Semukim for ever and ever, they are done in truth and righteousness" (ibid. cxi. 8).
16.26: Why, then, is the Psalm concerning Absalom (Ps. iii) next to the Psalm concerning Gog and Magog (Ps. ii)? So that should anybody ask thee,
16.27: "Is there a slave that rebels against his master?"
16.29: "Is there a son who rebels against his father?"
16.30: The latter has happened, and similarly will the former happen.
16.31: R. Johanan said in the name of R. Simeon b. Johai : What means that which is written,
16.32: "She openeth her mouth with wisdom, and the law of kindness is on her tongue" (Prov. xxxi. 26) ? Of whom does Solomon say this?
16.33: He said it of no one else than David his father, who dwelt in five worlds and composed songs [in each].
16.34: He dwelt in the womb of his mother and composed a song ; as it is said,
16.35: "Bless the Lord, O my soul, and all that I am within, bless His holy name" (ibid. ciii. 1).
16.36: He issued forth into the air of the world, gazed at the stars and planets, and composed a song; as it is said,
16.37: "Bless the Lord, ye angels of His, ye mighty in strength, that fulfil His word, hearkening unto the voice of His word. Bless the Lord, all ye His hosts, etc." (ibid. vv. 20 f.).
16.38: He sucked at his mother's breast, gazed at her nipples, and composed a song ; as it is said,
16.39: "Bless the Lord, O my soul, and forget not all His benefits" (ibid. v. 2).
16.42: [It means] that He placed her breast in the place of understanding.
16.45: So that [the child] may not gaze at the place of nakedness.
16.47: So that it should not have to suck from a part of the body which is foul.
16.48: David looked upon the overthrow of the wicked and composed a song ; as it is said,
16.49: "Let sinners cease out of the earth, and let the wicked be no more. Bless the Lord, O my soul. Hallelujah" (ibid. civ. 35).
16.50: He reflected on the day of death and composed a song ; as it is said, "Bless the Lord, O my soul : O Lord my God, Thou art very great, Thou art clothed with glory and majesty" (ibid. v. 1).
16.51: How is it understood that this verse speaks of the day of death?
16.53: From the continuation ; as it is written,
16.54: "Thou hidest Thy face, they vanish ; Thou withdrawest their breath, they perish, and return to the dust" (ibid. v. 29).
16.55: Rab Shimi b. 'Ukba (another version : Mar 'Ukba) was frequently in the company of R. Simeon b. Pazzi who used to arrange the Aggadah in the presence of R. Joshua b. Levi.
16.57: What means that which is written, "Bless the Lord, O my soul, and all that is within me, bless His holy name" (ibid. ciii. I)?
16.58: He replied : Come and see that the attribute of man is not like the attribute of the Holy One, blessed be He.
16.59: It is an attribute of man to draw a figure on a wall, but he is unable to endow it with breath and soul, with inward parts and bowels.
16.60: But with the Holy One, blessed be He, it is not so. He draws a figure within a figure, and endows it with breath and soul, with inward parts and bowels.
16.62: "There is none holy as the Lord, for there is none beside Thee ; neither is there any rock like our God" (I Sam. ii, 2).
16.63: What means "there is no rock [sur] like our God"?
16.64: [It means] "there is no designer [sayyar] like our God."
16.65: What means "for there is none beside Thee"?
16.67: Read not en bilteka" there is none beside Thee," but en Ieballoteka "there is none to outlast Thee." For not like the attribute of the Holy One, blessed be He, is the attribute of the human being.
16.68: With the human being, his works outlast him ; but the Holy One, blessed be He, outlasts His works.
16.71: These five "Bless the Lord, O my soul" — with reference to whom did David compose them ?
16.72: He composed them with reference to none other than the Holy One, blessed be He, and the soul.
16.73: As the Holy One, blessed be He, fills the whole world, so also the soul fills the whole body.
16.74: As the Holy One, blessed be He, sees but cannot be seen, so also the soul sees but cannot be seen.
16.75: As the Holy One, blessed be He, nourishes the whole world, so also the soul nourishes the whole body.
16.76: As the Holy One, blessed be He, is pure, so also the soul is pure.
16.77: As the Holy One, blessed be He, dwells in the inmost part [of the Universe], so also the soul dwells in the inmost part [of the body].
16.78: Let him in whom are these five qualities come and praise Him Who possesses these five qualities.
16.80: What means that which is written,
16.81: "Who is as the wise man? and who knoweth the interpretation [pesher] of a thing?" (Eccles. viii. 1)?
16.82: [It means]. Who is like the Holy One, blessed be He, Who knows how to make a reconciliation [pesharah] between the two righteous men, Hezekiah and Isaiah.
16.84: "Let Isaiah come to me, for so we find that Elijah went to Ahab ; as it is said,
16.85: 'And Elijah went to show himself unto Ahab' (I Kings xviii. 2)."
16.87: "Let Hezekiah come to me, for so we find that Jehoram, son of Ahab, went to Elisha" (II Kings iii. 12).
16.88: What did the Holy One, blessed be He, do? He brought sufferings upon Hezekiah and said to Isaiah,
16.91: "In those days was Hezekiah sick unto death. And Isaiah, the prophet, the son of Amoz came to him and said to him.
16.92: Thus saith the Lord, Set thy house in order; for thou shalt die, and not live" (Is. xxxviii. 1).
16.93: What means "For thou shalt die, and not live"? — "for thou shalt die" in this world, "and not live" in the world to come.
16.94: He asked him, "Why all this [severe punishment]?"
16.96: "Because thou hast not performed the duty of begetting children.
16.98: "The reason is that I have seen by the aid of the Holy Spirit, that worthless children will issue from me."
16.100: "What hast thou to do with the secrets of the All-merciful?
16.101: What thou hast been commanded thou shouldest perform, and let the Holy One, blessed be He, do whatever is pleasing to Him."
16.103: "Then give me thy daughter; perhaps my merit and thine will have effect, and worthy children will issue from me."
16.105: ["Lo, I have brought thee the message 'Set thy house in order' and thou sayest to me 'Give me thy daughter'!] The verdict [of death] has already been decreed against thee!"
16.107: "Son of Amoz, end thy prophecy and go!
16.108: For thus has it been handed down to me from my forefather: Even if a sharp sword be laid upon a man's neck, let him not despair of [the divine] mercy."
16.109: It has been similarly reported : R. Johanan and R. Eleazar both said :
16.110: Even if a sharp sword be laid upon a man's neck, let him not despair of [the divine] mercy, as it is said,
16.111: "Though He slay me, yet will I trust in Him" (Job xiii. 15).

17.1: Even if the lord of dreams inform a man that he will die on the morrow, he should not despair of [the divine] mercy; as it is said,
17.2: "For through the multitude of dreams and vanities there are also many words ; but fear thou God" (Eccles. v. 6),
17.4: "Then Hezekiah turned his face to the wall [kir] and prayed unto the Lord" (Is. xxxviii. 2).
17.7: [He prayed] from the chambers [kirot] of his heart; as it is said,
17.8: "My bowels, my bowels! I writhe in pain! the chambers of my heart, etc." (Jer. iv. 19).
17.12: "Lord of the Universe, if Thou didst bring back to life the child of the Shunammite woman who but made 'a little chamber on the roof,' how much more so [shouldest Thou spare my life], seeing that my forefather Solomon overlaid the whole Temple with silver and gold!"
17.13: "Remember now, O Lord, I beseech Thee, how I have walked before Thee in truth and with a whole heart, and have done that which is good in Thy sight" (Is. xxxviii. 3). What means "I have done that which is good in Thy sight"?
17.14: Rab Judah said in the name of Rab :
17.15: He joined the Ge'ullah to the Tefillah.
17.17: He hid the Book of Remedies.
17.19: Six acts did King Hezekiah perform ; of three [the Rabbis] approved, and of three they disapproved.
17.21: viz. he hid the Book of Remedies, and they approved; he broke the brazen serpent, and they approved; he dragged his father's bones upon a bed of ropes, and they approved.
17.22: But of three of his acts they disapproved,
17.23: viz. he stopped up the waters of Gihon, and they disapproved ; he cut down the doors of the Temple and sent them to the King of Assyria, and they disapproved ; he intercalated Nisan in Nisan, and they disapproved.
17.24: Did not Hezekiah know of the teaching,
17.25: "This month shall be unto you the beginning of months" (Exod. xii, 2), i.e. this month and none other shall be Nisan?
