17.26: But he erred in the teaching of Samuel
17.28: We do not intercalate the year on the 30th day of Adar, since that day may possibly be fixed as Nisan. Hezekiah thought
17.29: that we do not say "since that day may possibly be fixed as Nisan."
17.30: R. Johanan said in the name of R. Jose b. Zimra :
17.31: Whoever refers to his own merit [when praying], the merit of others is referred to [in the answer to the petition]; and whoever refers to the merit of others, his own merit is referred to.
17.32: Moses referred to the merit of others; as it is said,
17.33: "Remember Abraham, Isaac and Israel, Thy servants" (ibid, xxxii. 13),
17.34: and his own merit was referred to ; as it is said,
17.35: "Therefore He said that He would destroy them, had not Moses His chosen stood before Him in the breach, to turn back His wrath, lest He should destroy them" (Ps. cvi. 23).
17.36: Hezekiah referred to his own merit; as it is written,
17.37: "Remember now, O Lord, I beseech Thee, how I have walked before Thee" (Is. xxxviii. 3), and the merit of others was referred to ; as it is said,
17.38: "For I will defend this city, for Mine own sake, and for My servant David's sake" (ibid, xxxvii. 35).
17.39: This agrees with the statement of R. Joshua b. Levi
17.40: who said : What means that which is written,
17.41: "Behold, for my peace I had great bitterness" (Is. xxxviii. 17)?
17.42: Even when the Holy One, blessed be He, sent him peace, it was bitter for him.
17.43: "Let us make, I pray thee, a little chamber on the roof" (II Kings iv. 10).
17.44: Rab and Samuel [discuss its meaning]. One says :
17.45: It was an open chamber which they roofed in ; the other says :
17.46: It was a large verandah  which they divided into two [by erecting a wall].
17.47: This is all very well according to him who says it was a verandah, since it is written kir "a wall" ; but for him who says it was an upper chamber, what means kir?
17.48: He takes it to mean "they roofed it."
17.49: It is all very well according to him who says it was an upper chamber, since it is written 'aliyyah "upper chamber" ; but for him who says it was a verandah, what means 'aliyyah?
17.50: He takes it to mean the finest [me'ullah] of the rooms.
17.51: "And let us set for him there a bed, and a table, and a stool and a candlestick" (ibid.).
17.53: Whoever wishes to take advantage [of an offer of hospitality] may do so like Elisha ; and whoever does not wish to accept may do so like Samuel of Ramah ;
17.55: "And his return was to Ramah, for there was his house" (I Sam. vii. 17),
17.57: Wherever he went, he took his house with him.
17.58: "And she said to her husband. Behold now, I perceive that this is a holy man of God" (II Kings iv. 9).
17.59: R. Jose b. R. Hannina said :
17.60: From here [we learn] that a woman can better estimate [the character of] a guest than a man.
17.61: "A man of God." How did she know it?
17.62: Rab and Samuel [offer explanations]. One says:
17.63: She never saw a fly pass over his table;
17.65: She spread a linen sheet upon his bed and never found it stained with seminal emission.
17.66: "A holy man." R. Jose b. R. Hannina said :
17.67: He is holy, but not his servant : as it is said,
17.68: "Gehazi came near to thrust her away" (ibid. v. 27).
17.70: He seized her by the breast.
17.71: "That passeth by us continually" (ibid. v. 9). R. Jose b. R. Hannina said in the name of R. Eliezer b. Jacob :
17.72: Whoever invites a disciple of the wise as a guest to his house and lets him enjoy his possessions, the Scriptures ascribe it to him as though he had brought continual offerings.
17.73: R. Jose b. R. Hannina also said in the name of R. Eliezer b. Jacob :
17.74: Let not a man stand on an elevated place and pray, but let him pray in a lowly place;
17.75: as it is said, "Out of the depths have I called Thee, O Lord" (Ps. cxxx. 1 ).
17.76: There is a teaching to the same effect :
17.77: Let not a man stand upon a chair, or a stool, or any elevated place to pray, but let him pray in a lowly place, because there can be no haughtiness before the Omnipresent ; as it is said, "Out of the depths have I called Thee, O Lord," and it is said,
17.78: "A prayer of the afflicted, when he fainteth" (ibid. cii. 1).
17.79: R. Jose b. R. Hannina also said in the name of R. Eliezer b. Jacob :
17.80: Whoever prays must direct his feet ; as it is said,
17.81: "And their feet were straight feet" (Ezek. i. 7).
17.82: R. Jose b. R. Hannina also said in the name of R. Eliezer b. Jacob :
17.83: What means that which is written,
17.84: "Ye shall not eat with the blood" (Lev. xix, 26)? [It means], Ye shall not eat before you have prayed for your life.
17.85: There are some who declare that R. Isaac stated that R. Johanan said in the name of R. Eliezer b. Jacob :
17.86: Whoever eats and drinks and afterwards otFers his prayers, concerning him the Scriptures say,
17.87: "Thou hast cast Me behind thy back" (I Kings xiv. 9). Read not geweka "thy back," but geeka "thy pride."
17.88: The Holy One, blessed be He, says,
17.89: "After this person has exalted himself, he receives upon himself the kingdom of Heaven."
17.90: R. Joshua said : Until the third hour.
17.91: Rab Judah said in the name of Samuel :
17.92: The Halakah is in accord with R. Joshua.
17.93: He who reads from that time onward incurs no loss.
17.94: Rab Hisda said in the name of Mar 'Ukba : Provided he does not say "Blessed... Who formest light."
17.95: Against this view I quote : He who reads [the Shema'] from that time onward incurs no loss ; he is regarded as one reading in the Torah, but he must precede it with two benedictions and follow it with one ! This refutation of Rab Hisda's view remains unshaken.
17.97: Rab Hisda said in the name of Mar 'Ukba :
17.98: What means he incurs no loss? He loses none of the benedictions.
17.99: There is a teaching to the same effect :
17.100: He who reads [the Shema'] from that time onward incurs no loss ; he is regarded as one reading in the Torah, but he must precede it with two benedictions and follow it with one.
17.102: Greater is he who reads the Shema' in its proper time than one who occupies himself with Torah ; for the Mishnah states :
17.103: He who reads from that time onward incurs no loss, he is regarded as one reading in the Torah ; hence it is to be deduced that he who reads [the Shema'] in its proper time is superior.
17.105: In the evening a man should recline and read [the Shema'], and in the morning he should stand up [to read it] ; as it is said,
17.106: "When thou liest down and when thou risest up" (Deut. vi. 7).
17.108: A man reads it after his own manner; as it is said,
17.109: "And when thou walkest by the way" (ibid.).
17.110: If so, why is it said,
17.111: "When thou liest down and when thou risest up" ?
17.112: [That means], At the time when people lie down and rise up.
17.114: I was once journeying by the way and I reclined to read [the Shema'], according to the view of Bet Shammai, and I placed myself in danger on account of robbers.
17.116: Thou didst justly incur a penalty for thyself, in that thou didst transgress the view of Bet Hillel.

18.0: GEMARA It is all very well that Bet Hillel explain their reasons and the reason of Bet Shammai ; but why do not Bet Shammai agree with Bet Hillel?
18.2: In that case, the text should read, "In the morning and at even" ; what means "When thou liest down and when thou risest up" ? At the time of lying down, there should be actual lying down [to read the Shema'], and at the time of rising up, there should be actual rising up.
18.3: What, then, do Bet Shammai make of the phrase "and when thou walkest by the way"?
18.4: This is required in accordance with the teaching : "
18.5: When thou sittest in thy house" excludes one occupied with a religious duty; "and when thou walkest by the way" excludes a bridegroom. Hence they say :
18.6: He who takes a virgin to his house as wife is exempt [from the obligation of reading the Shema' on the night of his marriage] ; but if he marry a widow, he has that obligation.
18.9: Because [the text uses the word] "way" [we argue], Just as the way is voluntary, so all is voluntary.
18.10: Are we not here dealing with one who is on his way to perform a religious duty, and even so, the All-merciful requires of him the reading [of the Shema']?
18.11: In that case, the All-merciful should have written "when sitting and when walking." What means "when thou sittest and when thou walkest"?
18.12: When sitting for thine own purpose and when walking for thine own purpose, thou art under the obligation [to read the Shema'] ;
18.13: but when it is the performance of a religious duty, thou art exempt.
18.14: If so, even one who takes a widow as wife should also [be exempt] !
18.15: The man [who marries a virgin] is anxious; the other is not.
18.16: Should the reason [of exemption] be on account of anxiety, then it ought also to apply to one whose ship has sunk at sea !
18.17: Shouldest thou say that he likewise is exempt, why does R. Abba b. Zabda declare in the name of Rab :
18.18: A mourner is under the obligation to observe all the commandments mentioned in the Torah except Tefillin, because they are called an adornment ; as it is said,
18.20: [No, there is a difference]; the former is troubled by the anxiety of a religious duty; but as for the latter, his anxiety is caused by some voluntary affair.
18.22: They require it for the exclusion of messengers sent out in connection with a religious duty.
18.24: They answer that it is self-evident that they may read [the Shema'] while even on a journey.
18.25: The Rabbis have taught : Bet Hillel say :
18.26: When standing they may read [the Shema'], when sitting they may read, when reclining they may read, when walking by the way they may read, when doing work they may read.
18.27: It once happened that R. Ishmael and R. Eleazar b. 'Azariah were dining in a certain place, the former reclining and the latter sitting upright.
18.28: When the time for reading the Shema' arrived, R. Eleazar reclined and R. Ishmael sat up.
18.29: R. Eleazar b. 'Azariah said to R. Ishmael,
18.30: "[Ishmael] My brother, I will narrate a parable for thee. To what is this like?
18.32: who is told 'Thy beard is well grown' and he answers,
18.33: 'Then it shall be taken in hand by the barbers.
18.34: ' So art thou ; all the time that I was sitting up thou wert reclining, but now that I have reclined thou hast sat up !"
18.36: "I have acted according to the teaching of Bet Hillel, and thou according to the teaching of Bet Shammai.
18.37: Not only that, [I sat up] lest the disciples see this and fix the Halakah for future generations."
18.39: Shouldest thou say, "Bet Hillel also hold [that the Shema' may be read] in a reclining position!" that is so, but only when one was reclining from the first ; but in thy case, since hitherto thou has been sitting up and now thou reclinest, they will say, "We have to infer that [our teachers] agree with the opinion of Bet Shammai," and there is a fear, that the disciples seeing this, will fix the Halakah accordingly for future generations.
18.41: If a man acted in accordance with the view of Bet Shammai, he has done [rightly] ; if in accordance with the view of Bet Hillel, he has done [rightly].
18.42: Rab Joseph said : If he acted in accordance with the view of Bet Shammai, he has done nothing at all. For there is a Mishnaic teaching :
18.43: If the head and greater part of a man's body be in a Sukkah and his table inside his house, Bet Shammai pronounce it invalid, but Bet Hillel declare it valid.
18.44: Bet Hillel said to Bet Shammai,
18.45: "It once happened that the Elders of Bet Shammai and the Elders of Bet Hillel went to visit R. Johanan b. ha-Horanit
18.46: and they found him with his head and the greater part of his body in the Sukkah and his table inside his house, but they said nothing to him."
18.48: "Is proof to be drawn from this?
18.50: 'If this be thy practice, never hast thou in thy life-time properly observed the commandment of Sukkah!' "
18.52: If one acted according to the view of Bet Shammai, he is worthy of death ; for we have learnt in our Mishnah: R. Tarphon said:
18.53: I was once journeying by the way and I reclined to read [the Shema'] according to the view of Bet Shammai, and I placed myself in danger on account of robbers.
18.55: Thou didst justly incur a penalty for thyself, in that thou didst transgress the view of Bet Hillel.
18.56: MISHNAH IV  In the morning [the reading of the Shema'] is preceded by two benedictions and followed by one ; in the evening it is preceded by two and followed by two, one long and one short. Where [the Rabbis] order to say a long benediction, it is not permissible to say a short one ;
18.57: [where they order] to say a short benediction, it is not permissible to say a long one. [Where they order] to "seal " a benediction, it is not permissible not to "seal" ; [where they order] not to "seal," it is not permissible to "seal."
18.58: GEMARA  Which benedictions does one say [in the morning]?
18.59: R. Jacob [[fol. 11b.]] said in the name of R. Osha'ya :

19.0: "[Blessed].... Who formest light and createst darkness."
19.1: Surely one ought rather to say : "Who formest light and createst brightness"!
19.2: As it is written, so we say it.
19.3: But in the case of the words
19.4: "I make peace and create evil" (Is. xlv. 7), do we say them as they are written?
19.5: It is written "evil," but [in the prayer] we say "all things" ! It is an euphemism. Then in the former instance, let us [in the prayer] also use "brightness" [instead of "darkness"] as an euphemism !
19.7: The purpose is to mention the characteristic of day at night and the characteristic of night in the day.
19.8: It is quite right [about mentioning] the characteristic of night in the day, since we say
19.9: “Who formest light and createst darkness" ; but where is [the mention of] the characteristic of day at night?
19.11: [We say] "Thou rollest away the light from before the darkness, and the darkness from before the lights."
19.12: Which is the other [blessing to be recited before the morning Shema']?
19.13: Rab Judah said in the name of Samuel :
19.15: and so R. Eleazar taught his son R. Pedat to say
19.17: There is a teaching to the same effect :
19.18: We do not say "With everlasting love," but "With abounding love."
19.20: "With everlasting love" [is to be recited] ; for so it is said, "Yea, I have loved thee with an everlasting love ; therefore with affection have I drawn thee" (Jer. xxxi. 3).
19.21: Rab Judah said in the name of Samuel :
19.22: When one rises early to study [Torah], if he had not yet read the Shema', he must utter a benediction [prefatory to study] ; but should he have read the Shema', it is not necessary to utter a benediction, for he has freed himself from the obligation by having recited "With abounding love."
19.24: For the study of the Scriptures a benediction is necessary, but not for the study of Midrash.
19.26: For the study of the Scriptures and Midrash a benediction is required, but not for the study of the Mishnah.
19.28: For the Mishnah it is also required, but not for the study of Talmud.
19.30: Also for the study of Talmud it is necessary to recite a benediction.
19.31: For Rab Hiyya b. Ashe said :
19.32: On many occasions have I stood before Rab to study the chapters of the Sifra debe Rab ; he first washed his hands, uttered a benediction, and then taught us the chapters.
19.34: Rab Judah said in the name of Samuel:
19.35: "[Blessed art Thou, O Lord our God, King of the Universe], Who hast sanctified us by Thy commandments and commanded us to occupy ourselves with the words of Torah."
19.36: R. Johanan used to conclude thus :
19.37: "Make pleasant, therefore, we beseech Thee, O Lord our God, the words of Thy Torah in our mouth and in the mouth of Thy people, the house of Israel, so that we with our offspring and the offspring of Thy people, the house of Israel, may all know Thy name and occupy ourselves with Thy Torah. Blessed art Thou, O Lord, Who teachest Torah to Thy people Israel."
19.38: Rab Hamnuna said : "[Blessed]... Who hast chosen us from all nations and given us Thy Torah.
19.39: Blessed art Thou, O Lord, Who givest the Torah."
19.41: This is the choicest of benedictions.
19.42: Rab Pappa said : Therefore let one say them all.
19.43: We have learnt elsewhere in the Mishnah : The Temple-super-intendent said [to the priests]
19.45: and they did so. They then read the Decalogue, "Hear, O Israel" etc. (Deut. vi. 4 ff.), "And it shall come to pass if ye shall hearken diligently" etc. (ibid. xi. 13 ff.), "And the Lord said" etc. (Num. xv, 37 ff.). After that they uttered with the people three benedictions,
19.46: viz, "True and firm," "Accept, O Lord our God" and the Priestly Benediction. On the Sabbath they added a benediction for the outgoing guard.
19.48: It so happened that R. Abba and R.Jose b. Abba came to a certain place and were asked :
19.51: so they went and questioned Rab Mattena, and he could not answer.
19.52: They thereupon asked Rab Judah. He replied :
19.53: Thus said Samuel : It is "With abounding love."
19.54: But R. Zerika stated that R. Ammi said in the name of R. Simeon b. Lakish :
19.56: When Rab Isaac b. Joseph came [from Palestine], he said :
19.57: The statement of R. Zerika was not explicitly made but was inferred ; for what R. Zerika stated that R. Ammi said in the name of R. Simeon b. Lakish was :
19.58: This teaches that the benedictions do not invalidate one another.
19.59: Now it is quite right if thou maintainest that [the priests] recited "Who formest light" ;
19.60: then it would follow that the benedictions do not invalidate one another, for they omitted "With abounding love."

20.0: Shouldest thou, on the other hand, maintain that they recited "With abounding love," how would it follow that the benedictions do not invalidate one another?
20.1: Perhaps the reason they omitted "Who formest light" was because it was not yet time for that prayer, and when the proper time arrived, they said it!
20.2: And if this be an inference, what then?
20.3: It might have been inferred that it was certainly "With abounding love" that [the priests] recited, and when the proper time for reciting "Who formest light" arrived, they said it; and what means "The benedictions do not invalidate one another"?
20.5: [The Mishnah quoted above states :] Then they read the Decalogue, "Hear, O Israel," "And it shall come to pass, if ye shall hearken diligently," "And the Lord said," "True and firm," "Accept, O Lord our God," and the Priestly Benediction.
20.6: Rab Judah said in the name of Samuel :
20.7: Also beyond the confines of the Temple they wished to read [the Decalogue with the Shema'] but it had long been abolished because of the murmuring of the Minim.
20.8: There is a teaching to the same effect : R. Nathan said :
20.9: Outside the Temple they wished to read [the Decalogue with the Shema'] but it had long been abolished because of the murmuring of the Minim.
20.10: Rabbah b. Rab Huna thought to establish it in Sura ; but Rab Hisda told him
20.11: it had been previously abolished because of the murmuring of the Minim.
20.12: Amemar thought to establish it in Nehardea; but Rab Ashe told him
20.13: it had previously been abolished because of the murmuring of the Minim.
20.14: [The Mishnah-quotation continues :] On the Sabbath they added a benediction for the outgoing guard.
20.17: The outgoing guard said to the incoming guard,
20.18: "May He Who caused His name to dwell in this house make love and brotherhood, peace and comradeship, to abide amongst you."
20.19: Where [the Rabbis] order to say a long benediction, it is not permissible to say a short one.
20.20: It is evident that one who took a cup of wine, and thinking that it was beer, commenced saying the benediction on the supposition that it was beer, and then concluded the benediction for wine, has complied with the requirements of the law ; because even if he had said "[Blessed]... by Whose word all things exist," he would also have complied with the requirements of the law. For there is a Mishnaic teaching :
20.22: If one has uttered the benediction "By Whose word all things exist" over any kind of liquor, he has fulfilled his obligation.
20.23: But if one took a cup of beer, and thinking it was wine began the benediction for wine and concluded with the benediction for beer, how is it then ?
20.24: Do we follow the main theme of the benediction or its conclusion ?
20.26: In the morning service, if one commences with "Who formest light" but concludes with "Who bringest on the evening twilight," he has not complied with the requirements of the law. If he opened with "[ Blessed] . . . Who at Thy word bringest on the evening twilight" and concluded with "Creator of the luminaries," he has so complied.
20.27: In the evening service, if he opened with "Who at Thy word bringest on the evening twilight" and concluded with "Creator of the luminaries," he has not so complied. If he opened with "Who formest light" and concluded with "Who bringest on the evening twilight," he has so complied.
20.28: The general rule in this matter is, therefore,
20.29: that it depends upon the conclusion of the benediction.
20.30: But it is different here, because he has said
20.31: "Blessed art Thou, O Lord, Creator of the luminaries."
20.32: That is quite right according to Rab who declares that a benediction which does not contain the Divine Name is no benediction. But, according to R. Johanan who holds that
20.33: a benediction which does not contain a reference to the Divine Kingship is no benediction, what is there to say?
20.34: But since Rabbah b. 'Ulla has declared :
20.35: "The purpose is to mention the characteristic of day at night and the characteristic of night in the day," having uttered the benediction and the reference to the Divine Kingship from the commencement, he said them of both.
20.36: Come and hear : From the latter clause [of the quoted Baraita]
20.37: "The general rule in this matter is that it depends upon the conclusion of the benediction" —
20.38: what does "the general rule in this matter" intend to include? Is it not to include what we have mentioned?
20.39: No ;  it is to include the instance of bread and dates.
20.40: How is this to be understood ?
20.41: Are we to suppose that it refers to one who ate bread and thinking that it was dates he had eaten, commences the benediction on the supposition it was dates, but concludes with the benediction for bread ? This is the same as the last-mentioned case!
20.42: No, [the "general rule"] is necessary for the following :
20.43: If, for instance, one ate dates, and thinking it was bread, commenced with the benediction for bread but concluded with the benediction for dates, he has complied with the requirements of the law ; for even if he had concluded with the benediction for bread, he would also have so complied.
20.44: What is the reason ? Because dates likewise nourish.
20.46: b. Hinnana the Elder said in the name of Rab :
20.47: Whoever does not recite "True and firm" in the morning and "True and trustworthy" in the evening has not fulfilled his obligation ; as it is said,
20.48: "To declare Thy lovingkindness in the morning and Thy faithfulness in the night-seasons" (Ps. xcii. 3).
20.49: Rabbah b. Hinnana [the Elder] also said in the name of Rab :
20.50: When one prays [the Tefillah] and has to bow, he should bow at the word "Blessed" ; and when returning to the erect position, he should do so on mentioning the Divine Name.
20.52: What is Rab's reason ? Because it is written,
20.53: "The Lord raiseth up them that are bowed down" (ibid, cxlvi. 8).
20.55: "And from before My name he is afraid" (Mal. ii. 5)!
20.57: No, "from before My name" is written.
20.58: Samuel said to Hiyya b. Rab :
20.59: O son of the Law, come and let me tell thee an excellent thing which thy father once said.
20.61: When one bows, he should do so at the word "Blessed" ; and when he returns to the erect position, he should do so on mentioning the Divine Name.

21.0: When Rav Sheshet would bow, he would bow like a rod. When he would straighten (from his bow), he would straighten like a snake.
21.1: And Rabba Bar Chinena Sabba said in the name of Rav...
21.2: The entire year completely man prays, "The Holy G-d", "King that loves righteousness and justice", besides for the 10 days between Rosh HaShanah and Yom HaKippurim, that he will pray "The Holy King", and "The King of Justice."
21.4: Even if he said "The Holy G-d" he has fulfilled his obligation, as it says,
21.5: ..."The Lord of Hosts shall be uplifted with justice, the Holy G-d shall be sanctified with righteousness(Isaiah 5:16)."
21.6: ..When will "The Lord of Hosts shall be uplifted with justice"? The 10 days from Rosh HaShanah through Yom HaKippurim. And yet it says "The Holy G-d"?
21.7: ...What is it that goes up(lit.)?  (i.e. what is the outcome?)
21.9: "The Holy G-d", and "King that loves righteousness and justice."
21.11: "The Holy King", and "The King of Justice"
21.12: And the law goes according to Rabbah.
21.13: Rabbah b. Hinnana the Elder also said in the name of Rab :
21.14: Whoever has it in his power to pray" on behalf of his neighbour and fails to do so is called a sinner ;
21.16: "Moreover as for me, far be it from me that I should sin against the Lord in ceasing to pray for you" (I Sam. xii. 23).
21.18: If [the neighbour] be a disciple of the wise, then it is necessary to grieve on his behalf [should he be in trouble].
21.20: Are we to suppose it is because it is written, "There is none of you that is sorry for me or discloseth unto me" (ibid. xxii. 8)? Perhaps it is different in the case of a king! Nay,
21.22: "But as for me, when they were sick, my clothing was sackcloth, I afflicted my soul with fasting ; and my prayer, may it return into mine own bosom" (Ps. xxxv. 13).
21.23: Rabbah b. Hinnana the Elder also said in the name of Rab :
21.24: Whoever commits a transgression and is filled with shame thereby, all his sins are forgiven him; as it is said,
21.25: "That thou mayest remember and be confounded, and never open thy mouth any more, because of thy shame; when I have forgiven thee all that thou hast done, saith the Lord God" (Ezek. xvi. 63).
21.26: Perhaps it is different with a community? Nay,
21.28: "And Samuel said to Saul, Why hast thou disquieted me, to bring me up? And Saul answered, I am sore distressed ; for the Philistines make war against me, and God is departed from me, and answereth me no more, neither by prophets, nor by dreams; therefore I have called thee, that thou mayest make known unto me what I shall do" (I Sam. xxviii. 15). Saul did not mention [having inquired through] the Urim and Tummim, because he put Nob, the city of the priests, to the sword.
21.29: Whence do we know that he was forgiven by God ? As it is said, "(And Samuel said unto Saul), Tomorrow shalt thou and thy sons be with me" (ibid. 5:19); upon which R. Johanan comments,
21.31: The Rabbis [find that Saul was forgiven] in the following :
21.32: "We will hang them up unto the Lord in Gibeah of Saul, the chosen of the Lord" (II Sam. xxi. 6). A Bat Kol issued forth and proclaimed
21.34: R. Abbahu b. Zutarti said in the name of R. Judah b. Zebida:
21.35: It was sought to include the Parashah of Balak in the reading of the Shema'. Why did they not do so? Because of the trouble [its length would cause] to the congregation.
21.36: On what ground [did they wish to include it] ?
21.37: Was it because it is written therein,
21.38: "God Who brought them forth out of Egypt" (Num. xxiii. 22) ? Then let one say the Parashah of usury or of weights which likewise contains a reference to the exodus from Egypt !
21.39: Nay ; R. Jose b. Abin said :
21.40: [The reason is] because it is written therein,
21.41: "He couched, he lay down as a lion, and as a lioness ; who shall rouse him up?" (ibid. xxiv. 9).
21.42: Then let him say that verse and no more
21.44: We have a tradition that any Parashah which Moses our teacher divided off, we may divide off; but a Parashah which he had not divided off, we may not.
21.45: Why was the Parashah of Fringes included [in the Shema']?
21.47: Because there are five things contained therein :
21.48: the command of fringes ; the exodus from Egypt ; the yoke of the commandments ; [a warning against] heretical opinions [Minut] ; lustful imagination and idolatrous longing.
21.49: Quite right that three of these are explicitly stated therein ;
21.50: viz. : the yoke of the commandments, as it is written,
21.51: "That ye may look upon it and remember all the commandments of the Lord" (ibid. xv. 39) ; the command of Fringes, as it is written,
21.52: "That they make for themselves fringes" (ibid. v. 38) ; the exodus from Egypt, as it is written,
21.53: "I am the Lord your God, Who brought you out of the land of Egypt to be your God ; I am the Lord your God" (ibid. 5:41). But where is there reference to heretical opinions and lustful imagination and idolatrous longing ?
21.55: "After your heart" (ibid. v. 39) means heresy; for thus the Scriptures state,
21.56: "The fool hath said in his heart, There is no God" (Ps. xiv, 1). "After your own eyes" (Num. I.c.) means lustful imagination ; as it is said,
21.57: "And Samson said unto his father. Get her for me, for she is pleasing in my eyes" (Judg. xiv. 3). "After which ye use to go astray" (Num. I.c.) means idolatrous longing;
21.58: for thus the Scriptures state, "The children of Israel again went astray after the Baalim " (Judg. viii. 33).
21.59: Mishnah: We recall the exodus from Egypt during the nights
21.61: "Behold, it is as if I am seventy years of age and I have not merited (to explain how it is) that it (the Exodus) should be said [recalled] at night, until Ben Zoma taught
21.63: "so that you will recall the exodus from Egypt all the days of your life"
21.64: "the days of your life" refers to the day time, "all the days of your life" comes to include the nights
21.66: "the days of your life" refers to this world, "all the days of your life" comes to include the days of the Messianic era.
21.67: GEMARA There is a teaching : Ben Zoma said to the Sages :
21.68: Will the exodus from Egypt be mentioned in the days of the Messiah ?
21.69: Has it not long ago been declared,
21.70: "Therefore behold, the days come, saith the Lord, that they shall no more say. As the Lord liveth, that brought up the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt ; but, as the Lord liveth, that brought up and that led the seed of the house of Israel out of the north country, and from all the countries whither I had driven them" (Jer. xxiii. 7f.)?
21.72: [This passage does not mean] that the memory of the exodus from Egypt is to be obliterated, but that [the memory of the release from] the servitude of the kingdoms will be fundamental and the exodus of Egypt secondary to it.
21.73: Take the following as an analogy:
21.74: "Thy name shall no more be called Jacob, but  Israel shall be thy name" (Gen. xxxv. 10).

22.0: It is not intended that the name Jacob shall be obliterated, but that Israel will be fundamental and Jacob secondary.
22.2: "Remember ye not the former things, neither consider the things of old" (Is. xliii. 18) — "Remember ye not the former things," i.e. the servitude of the kingdoms, "neither consider the things of old," i.e. the exodus from Egypt. "Behold I will do a new thing ; now shall it spring forth" (ibid. 5:19). Rab Joseph taught :
22.3: This refers to the war of Gog and Magog.
22.4: A parable : to what is this like ? To a man walking by the way, when a wolf attacked him and he was rescued from it ; then he is fond of relating his adventure with the wolf.
22.5: [Later on] a lion attacked him and he was rescued from it ; so he is fond of relating his adventure with the lion.
22.6: [After that] a serpent attacked him and he was rescued from it ; so he forgets his two previous adventures, and relates the incident of the serpent.
22.7: So is it also with Israel ; later troubles cause the former to be forgotten.
22.8: "Abram, the same is Abraham" (I Chron. i. 27). At first he was made the father of Aram, but subsequently the father of all the universe.
22.9: Sarai, the same is Sarah. At first she was made princess of her own people, but subsequently princess of all the universe
22.11: Whoever calls Abraham " Abram " transgresses a command ; as it is said,
22.14: He transgresses a prohibition ; as it is said,
22.15: "Thy name shall no more be called Abram" (ibid.).
22.16: But now, can this also apply to one who calls Sarah "Sarai"?
22.17: In her case the Holy One, blessed be He, said to Abraham,
22.18: "As for Sarai thy wife, thou shalt not call her name Sarai, but Sarah shall her name be" (ibid. v. 15).
22.19: Does it likewise apply to one who calls Jacob "Jacob"?
22.20: No; it is different here, because the Scriptures afterwards repeat [his old name] ; as it is written, "And God spoke unto Israel in the visions of the night, and said, Jacob, Jacob" (ibid. xlvi. 2).
22.21: R. Jose b. Abin (others declare it was R. Jose b. Zebida) quoted in objection :
22.22: "Thou art the Lord the God, Who didst choose Abram" (Neh. ix. 7) !
22.24: In this passage the prophet narrates the praise of the All-merciful by reviewing what had happened from the beginning.
22.25: May we return to thee : From what time.
22.26: MISHNAH  Should a man be reading in the Torah [the section of the Shema'] and the time of reciting the Shema' arrived, if he directed his heart, he has fulfilled his obligation.
22.27: Between the sections, he may greet a man out of respect for him and return a salutation ; but in the middle [of the sections] he may greet a man because of fear for him and return a salutation. These are the words of R. Meir.
22.29: In the middle, he may greet a man because of fear for him, and return a salutation out of respect ; and between the sections, he may greet a man out of respect for him and return the salutation of any person.
22.30: II. The following are "between the sections" :
22.31: Between the first benediction and the second ; between the second and "Hear, O Israel" ; between "Hear, O Israel" and "And it shall come to pass if ye shall hearken" ; between "And it shall come to pass if ye shall hearken" and "And the Lord spake" ; between "And the Lord spake" and "True and firm."
22.33: One must make no interruption between "And the Lord spake" and "True and firm."
22.35: Why does the section "Hear, O Israel" precede "And it shall come to pass if ye shall hearken"? So that a man shall first receive upon himself the yoke of the kingdom of heaven, and afterwards receive upon himself the yoke of the commandments.
22.36: And why does "And it shall came to pass if ye shall hearken" precede "And the Lord spake" ? Because the former applies both during the day and night, but the latter during the day only.
22.37: GEMARA Is the conclusion to be drawn [from the opening sentence of the Mishnah] that
22.38: the performance of the commandments requires Kawwanah?
22.39: No; for] what means If he directed his heart to read ?
22.40: Just to read [in the Torah for the sake of study].
22.42: [It is to differentiate him] from one who is reading [the Torah] for the purpose of correcting.
22.44: The Shema' must be read as it is written: These are the words of Rabbi;
22.46: may be read] in any language.
22.48: The text states, "And these words shall be" (Deut. vi. 6); i.e. as they are, so must they remain.
22.49: And what is the reason of the Sages?
22.51: "Hear, O Israel" (ibid. v. 4); i.e. in any language which thou hearest.
22.52: But for Rabbi also it is written "Hear, O Israel" !
22.53: He requires it to establish the rule.
22.54: Cause thine ear to hear what thou utterest with thy lips.
22.56: They agree with him who says that
22.57: if one does not read [the Shema'] audibly, he has still fulfilled his obligation.
22.58: But for the Sages also it is written "And these words shall be" !
22.59: They require it to establish the rule that one must not read [the sentences of the Shema'] out of order.
22.60: Whence does Rabbi find authority for the rule that the Shema' may not be read out of order?
22.61: He derives it from the fact that the text states "these words shall be" and not "the words shall be."
22.63: [what do they make of this distinction between "these words" and "the words"]?
22.64: They draw no conclusion from it at all. It is possible to say that Rabbi holds that the whole Torah can be read in any language. For if thou maintainest that it may be read only in the holy tongue, what are we to make of the phrase "and these words shall be" which the All-merciful wrote?
22.65: It is necessary because it is written "Hear, O Israel."
22.66: It is likewise possible to say that the Sages hold that the whole Torah must be read in the holy tongue. For if thou maintainest that it can be read in any language, what are we to make of the phrase "Hear, O Israel" which the All-merciful wrote?
22.67: It is necessary because it is written "And these words shall be."
22.69: "And these words shall be" means that one must not recite [the sentences of the Shema'] out of order.
22.70: "These words... upon thine heart" — one might suppose that the whole Parashah requires Kawwanah; therefore there is a teaching to state, "These words... [shall be upon thine heart]," that is to say,
22.71: up to this point Kawwanah is required, but from this point onward it is not necessary. These are the words of R. Eliezer. [[fol. 13 b.]] R. 'Akiba said to him :

23.0: "Which I command thee this day... upon thine heart." Hence thou learnest that the whole Parashah requires Kawwanah !
23.1: Rabbah b. Bar Hannah said in the name of R. Johanan:
23.2: The Halakah is in accord with R. 'Akiba.
23.3: There are some who connect [the statement of Rabbah b. Bar Hannah] with the following. There is a teaching :
23.4: Who recites the Shema' must direct his heart thereto.
23.5: R. Aha says in the name of R. Judah :
23.6: If one directed his heart in the first paragraph, it is no longer necessary [in the succeeding paragraphs].
23.7: Rabbah b. Bar Hannah said in the name of R. Johanan :
23.8: The Halakah is in accord with the view of R. Aha which he reported in the name of R. Judah.
23.10: "And these words... shall be" means one must not read [the sentences of the Shema'] out of order. "Upon thine heart" — R. Zotra says:
23.11: Up to here the law of Kawwanah applies, but from here onward the commandment to recite applies.
23.13: Up to here the commandment to recite applies, but from here onward the law requiring Kawwanah applies.
23.14: What is the distinction that from here onward the commandment to recite applies ? Because it is written, "talking of them." But in the first Parashah it is likewise written "and shalt talk of them" !
23.15: What he means to say is,
23.16: Up to here the law of Kawwanah and reciting applies, but from here onward, reciting without Kawwanah is sufficient.
23.17: And what is the distinction that up to [the end of the first paragraph] the law of Kawwanah and reciting applies ? Because it is written "upon thine heart" and "and shalt talk of them." But in the next paragraph it is likewise written "Upon your heart" and "talking of them" !
23.19: is required for that which R. Isaac said :
23.20: "Therefore shall ye lay up these My words upon your heart" (Deut. xi. 18) is necessary [to teach that the Tefillin] must be placed over against the heart.
23.21: The teacher stated above : "R. Josiah says :
23.22: Up to here the commandment to recite applies, but from here onward the law requiring Kawwanah applies.
23.23: " What is the distinction that from here onward the law requiring Kawwanah applies ? Because it is written "upon your heart." But in the first Parashah it is likewise written "upon thine heart" !
23.24: What he means to say is,
23.25: Up to here the law of reciting and Kawwanah applies, but from here onward Kawwanah without reciting is sufficient.
23.26: And what is the distinction that up to [the end of the first paragraph] the law of reciting and Kawwanah applies ? Because it is written "upon thine heart" and "thou shalt talk of them." But in the next paragraph it is likewise written "upon your heart" and "talking of them"!
23.27: That refers to the words of
23.28: Torah; and thus spake the All-merciful,
23.29: "Teach your children Torah so that they can read therein."
23.31: "Hear, O Israel, the Lord our God, the Lord is one" (Deut. vi. 4) — up to here Kawwanah is required. These are the words of R. Meir.
23.33: The Halakah is in accord with R. Meir.
23.34: There is a teaching : Symmachus says :
23.35: Whoever prolongs the pronunciation of the word ehad "one," his days and years are prolonged for him.
23.39: Only he must not slur over the letter H. R.
23.40: Jeremiah was sitting in the presence of R. Hiyya b. Abba, and noticed that he prolonged [the word ehad] exceedingly.
23.42: So long as thou hast proclaimed His Kingship above and below and the four winds of heaven, more than that is not required of thee.
23.43: Rab Nathan b. Mar 'Ukba said in the name of Rab Judah :
23.45: Dost thou imagine that applies only to the words "Upon thine heart"?
23.47: [From the commencement of the Shema'] up to "upon thine heart" is to be recited standing, but not from there onward.
23.49: The whole paragraph should be recited standing ;
23.50: and R. Johanan hereby follows out his opinion [expressed in the statement ;] Rabbah b. Rab Hannah said in the name of R. Johanan :
23.51: The Halakah is in accord with the view of R. Aha which he reported in the name of R. Judah.
23.53: "Hear, O Israel, the Lord our God, the Lord is one" — that was the reading of the Shema' of R. Judah ha-Nasi'.
23.55: "I have never seen Rabbi receive the yoke of the kingdom of heaven upon himself."
23.58: at the time when he passed his hands across his face, he received upon himself the yoke of the kingdom of heaven."
23.59: Did he afterwards finish the Shema' or did he not?
23.61: He did not afterwards finish it.
23.64: Bar Kappara said to R. Simeon b. Rabbi ;
23.65: It is quite right according to me when I declare he did not afterwards finish it, because Rabbi used [every day] to deal with a theme in which the exodus from Egypt was mentioned; but according to thee who sayest that he did afterwards finish it, why did he [daily] deal with such a theme?
23.66: [He replied] : For the purpose of mentioning the exodus from Egypt in its proper time.
23.67: R. Ila b. Rab Samuel b. Marta said in the name of Rab:
23.68: [If one recited only the verse] "Hear, O Israel, the Lord our God, the Lord is one" and was then overcome by sleep, he has fulfilled his obligation.
23.69: Rab Nahman said to Daro his servant :
23.70: With the first verse worry me [to keep awake], but do not so after that.
23.71: Rab Joseph asked Rab Joseph b. Raba,
23.74: "With the first verse he took pains [to keep awake], but he did not so after that."
23.76: One who lies on his back should not read the Shema'.
23.77: Is it only he may not read [the Shema' in this position] ; but is it right for him to sleep [in this position]?
23.78: For lo, R. Joshua b. Levi cursed anyone who slept lying on his back !
23.80: To sleep thus is right if he incline a little to one side,
23.81: but to read the Shema' is forbidden, though he incline to one side.
23.82: But R. Johanan inclined to one side and read the Shema' !
23.83: It is different with him, because he was corpulent.
23.84: Between the sections he may greet a man out of respect for him and return a salutation.
23.85: He may return a salutation ; but on what ground ? If it is supposed out of respect, since he is allowed to greet, surely he ought to be permitted to respond !
23.87: He greets a man out of respect, and returns a salutation to any person.
23.89: In the middle [of the sections] he may greet a man because of fear for him and return the salutation. On what ground may he respond ?
23.90: If it is supposed because of fear, since he is allowed to greet, surely he ought to be permitted to respond ! But [the meaning is.
23.91: He may return the salutation] out of respect.
23.92: But that is the view of. R. Judah!
23.94: R. Judah says : In the middle of a section, he may greet a man because of fear for him and return a salutation out of respect ; and between the sections, he may greet a man out of respect and return the salutation of any person!
23.95: [The text of the Mishnah] is defective and should read thus :
23.96: "Between the sections, he may greet a man out of respect for him, and there is no need to state that he may return the salutation ; and in the middle [of the sections], he may greet a man because of fear for him, and there is no need to state that he may return a salutation. These are the words of R. Meir.
23.98: In the middle, he may greet [[fol. 14a.]] because of fear and return a salutation out of respect;

24.0: and between the sections he may greet out of respect and return the salutation of any person."
24.1: There is a teaching to the same effect :
24.2: If one is reading the Shema', and his teacher or one greater than himself meet him, between the sections he may greet him out of respect, and there is no need to state that he may return a salutation; and in the middle [of the sections], he may greet one because of fear, and there is no need to state that he may return a salutation. These are the words of R. Meir.
24.4: In the middle, he may greet because of fear and return a salutation out of respect ; and between the sections, he may greet out of respect and return the salutation of any person.
24.6: a Tanna of the school of R. Hiyya, asked R. Hiyya :
24.7: May one interrupt the Hallel or the Megillah [to greet a person] ?
24.9: If with the reading of the Shema', which is an ordinance of the Torah, one may interrupt, how much more so should it be permitted in the case of the Hallel or the Megillah, which is only a Rabbinical ordinance ! Or is it perhaps that the proclamation of a miracle is superior [to the reading of the [Shema'] ?
24.11: One may interrupt, and there is nothing in that [point you raise].
24.13: On those days when the individual  completes the Hallel, he may interrupt between the paragraphs, but in the middle of a paragraph he may not interrupt ;
24.14: and on the days when the individual does not complete the Hallel, he may interrupt even in the middle of a paragraph.
24.15: But it is not so ! For behold, Raba b. Rab Shaba visited Rabina on one of those days when the individual does not complete the Hallel, and Rabina did not interrupt [to greet him]!
24.16: It is different with Raba b. Shaba, since he was not highly esteemed by Rabina.
24.18: Ashyan, a Tanna of the school of R. Ammi, asked R. Ammi :
24.19: May one who is undergoing a fast taste anything?
24.20: If he has taken upon himself [to abstain from] eating and drinking, it comes under the heading of neither ; or is it that he has taken upon himself [to abstain from] any kind of gratification, and [tasting] is to be so regarded?
24.22: He may taste and there is nothing in that [point you raise].
24.23: There is a teaching to the same effect :
24.24: A woman who tastes [her cooking] is not required to utter a benediction, and she who is undergoing a fast may taste and there is nothing in it.
24.25: What is the maximum quantity [he may taste]?
24.26: R. Ammi and R. Assi tasted up to a fourth [of a log].
24.28: Whoever greets his neighbour before he prays is as though he accounted him as an idolatrous altar [bamah] ; as it is said,
24.29: "Cease ye from man, in whose nostrils is a breath ; for how little [bammeh] is he to be accounted" (Is. ii. 22). Read not bammeh but bamah.
24.31: Why do you esteem this person [whom you greet first] and not God ?
24.32: Rab Sheshet quoted the following in objection ;
24.33: Between the sections one may greet out of respect and return a salutation !
24.35: [the statements of Rab Samuel to refer] to one who goes first to the door of his neighbour.
24.36: R. Jonah said in the name of R. Zera:
24.38: his personal affairs before offering his prayers is as though he had erected an idolatrous altar.
24.42: No, I only mean it is prohibited; and it is in accordance with the statement of Rab Iddi b. Abin
24.43: who said in the name of Rab Isaac b. Ashyan :
24.44: It is forbidden a man to attend to his personal affairs before offering his prayers ; as it is said,
24.45: "Righteousness shall go before him, and shall make his footsteps a way" (Ps. Ixxxv. 14).
24.46: Rab Iddi b. Abin also said in the name of Rab Isaac b. Ashyan :
24.47: Whoever prays and afterwards goes on his way [to attend to his affairs], the Holy One, blessed be He, attends to them for him ; as it is said,
24.48: "Righteousness shall go before him, and He shall make his footsteps a way."
24.49: R. Jonah also said in the name of R. Zera :
24.50: Whoever sleeps for seven nights without a dream is called evil; as it is said,
24.51: "He shall abide satisfied [sabea'] he shall not he visited with evil" (Prov. xix. 23). Read not sabea', but sheba' "seven."
24.52: R. Abba, son of R. Hiyya b. Abba, said to him : Thus declared R. Hiyya in the name of R. Johanan :
24.53: Whoever satisfies himself with words of Torah and then sleeps will not receive evil tidings [in a dream]; as it is said,
24.54: "He shall abide satisfied [with Torah], he shall not be visited with evil."
24.55: The following are between the sections, etc.
24.56: R. Abbahu said in the name of R. Johanan :
24.57: The Halakah is in accord with R. Judah who maintains that one may not interrupt between "I am the Lord your God" and "True and firm."
24.58: R. Abbahu [also] said in the name of R. Johanan:
24.59: What is R. Judah's reason? Because it is written,

25.0: "The Lord God is the true God" (Jer. x. 10).
25.1: Should one repeat the word "true" or not?
25.2: R. Abbahu said in the name of R. Johanan:
25.6: Somebody descended in the presence of Rabbah ; and when the latter heard him say emit "true" twice,
25.8: "Every emet has seized hold of this fellow !"
25.10: How excellent is the teaching which, when Rab Samuel b. Judah came [from Palestine], he reported, viz. :
25.11: In the West they say in the evening, "Speak unto the children of Israel and say unto them I am the Lord your God. True."
25.13: What is there excellent in this?
25.14: Behold, Rab Kahana has said in the name of Rab :
25.15: One need not commence [the third paragraph at all] ; but if he has commenced it, he must finish it !
25.17: thou argue that [to say the words] "And thou shalt say unto them" is not commencing, behold Rab Samuel b. Isaac has declared in the name of Rab :
25.18: "Speak unto the children of Israel" is not considered a commencement, but "And thou shalt say unto them" is to be so regarded !
25.20: In the West they hold that "And thou shalt say unto them" is likewise not considered a commencement, until one adds "And they shall make for themselves fringes."
25.22: Therefore we commence as they commence in the West, and since we have commenced, we also complete it ; for Rab Kahana said in the name of Rab :
25.23: One need not commence it ; but if he has commenced it, he must finish it.
25.25: If one has said "I am the Lord your God," he must continue "True" ; if he has not said "I am the Lord your God," it is not necessary to add "True."
25.26: Yes; but he is required to mention the exodus from Egypt!
25.28: "We give thanks unto Thee, O Lord our God, that Thou hast brought us forth from the land of Egypt and redeemed us from the house of bondage, and performed miracles and mighty deeds for us by the Red Sea ; to thee do we sing."
25.29: R. Joshua b. Karhah said: Why does the section "Hear O Israel" precede "And it shall come to pass if ye shall hearken"?
25.30: There is a teaching : R. Simeon b. Johai says :
25.31: It is right that precedence should be given to "Hear O Israel" over "And it shall come to pass," because the former speaks of learning, the latter of teaching;
25.32: and to "It shall come to pass" over "And the Lord spake," because the former speaks of teaching and the latter of performing.
25.33: Do you mean to say that in "Hear O Israel" there is a reference to learning, but not to teaching and performing?
25.35: "Thou shalt teach them diligently... thou shalt bind them... thou shalt write them"!
25.36: And further [do you mean to say that] "And it shall come to pass" contains a reference to teaching, but not to performing?
25.39: Nay; but this is what he means to say :
25.40: It is right that precedence should be given to "Hear O Israel" over "And it shall come to pass," because the former contains a reference to learning, teaching and performing ; and to "And it shall come to pass" over "And the Lord spake," because the former contains a reference to teaching and performing, whereas "And the Lord spake" refers only to performing.
25.41: But derive the reason [for the order of the paragraphs] from the statement of R. Joshua b. Karhah!
25.42: [He gave] one reason and now another is added; viz. :
25.43: [the first is] in order that a man shall first receive upon himself the yoke of the kingdom of heaven and afterwards receive upon himself the yoke of the commandments ; and the second reason is because the first paragraph contains these other references.
25.44: Rab washed his hands, read the Shema', put on the Tefillin and then offered his prayers.
25.46: For lo, there is a teaching :
25.47: One who is digging a cavity for a corpse is exempt from the obligation of reading the Shema', the Tefillah, Tefillin and all the commandments mentioned in the Torah ; but when the time of reading the Shema' arrives, he ascends, washes his hands, puts on the Tefillin, reads the Shema' and offers his prayers?
25.49: The first clause declares such a man to be exempt from the obligation, and the latter imposes the obligation upon him !
25.51: the latter clause referring to where there are two, the former to one.
25.52: Nevertheless it presents a difficulty to Rab.
25.53: [The solution is :] Rab holds the view of R. Joshua b. Karhah who says :
25.54: First there must be the yoke of the kingdom of heaven, and afterwards the yoke of the commandments.
25.55: R. Joshua b. Karhah certainly said that the reading [of the yoke of heaven, i.e. "Hear O Israel"] is to precede the reading [of the yoke of the commandments, i.e. "And it shall come to pass"] ; but hast thou heard him say that the reading [of the Shema'] should precede the performance [of the duty of Tefillin] ?
25.56: Further, how could Rab be considered as holding the same opinion as R. Joshua b. Karhah ?
25.57: For Rab Hiyya b. Ashe has said :
25.58: On many occasions have I stood before Rab, who first washed his hands, uttered the benediction, taught us the chapters, laid Tefillin, and after that read the Shema' !
25.59: Shouldest thou argue that the time for reading the Shema' had not yet arrived, in that case what purpose is there in the testimony of Rab Hiyya b. Ashe?
25.60: [The object was] to refute him who declared that it is unnecessary to utter a benediction over the study of the Mishnah ; hence we are informed that likewise for the Mishnah it is necessary to utter a benediction.
25.61: Still the difficulty against Rab remains!
25.64: Whoever reads the Shema' without Tefillin is as though he spoke false testimony against himself.
25.65: R. Hiyya b. Abba said in the name of R. Johanan : It is as though he had offered a burnt-offering without a meal-offering (cf. Num. xxviii. 5) and a sacrifice without drink-offerings (ibid. v. 14).
25.67: Whoever wishes to receive upon himself the yoke of the kingdom of heaven in perfection

26.0: should first have evacuation, then wash his hands, lay Tefillin, read the Shema' and offer his prayers — that is receiving the kingdom of heaven in perfection.
26.1: R. Hiyya b. Abba said in the name of R. Johanan :
26.2: Whoever has evacuation, washes his hands, lays Tefillin, reads the Shema' and offers his prayers, the Scriptures ascribe it to him as though he had erected an altar and brought a sacrifice thereon ; as it is written,
26.3: "I will wash my hands in cleanliness ; so will I compass Thine altar, O Lord" (Ps. xxvi. 6).
26.5: Does not the master think that it is as though he had bathed his whole body?
26.7: "I will wash [in cleanliness]" not simply "I will cause [mine hands] to be washed."
26.9: Has the master seen the Rabbinical scholar who has come from the West and said,
26.10: "Who has no water wherewith to wash his hands should rub them with earth or pebbles or sawdust"?
26.12: Well has he spoken ; for is it written, "I will wash with water"?
26.13: No; it is written, "I will wash in cleanliness," i.e. with anything that cleanses.
26.14: And lo, Rab Hisda cursed anyone who went about in search of water at the time of prayer. This, however, applies only to the reading of the Shema', but for the Tefillah one may go for water.
26.15: How far may one go for it ?
26.17: But this applies only in front of him ; in the rear he may not go even a Mil,
26.18: [from which it is to be deduced] he may not go in the rear a Mil, but less than that distance is permissible.
26.19: MISHNAH  Who reads the Shema' without making it audible to his ear has complied with the requirements of the law.
26.22: If he read it without distinctly pronouncing its letters — R. Jose says :
26.23: He has complied with the requirements of the law ;
26.26: If one reads it in the wrong order of its paragraphs, he has not complied with the requirements of the law.
26.27: If one has read it but made a mistake, he returns to the place where he erred.
26.28: GEMARA What is R. Jose's reason [for declaring that unless the Shema' is read audibly the requirements of the law have not been fulfilled]? Because it is written,
26.29: "Hear O Israel," i.e. let thine ear hear what thou issuest from thy mouth.
26.30: And the first Tanna ? He holds that
26.31: "Hear" [means that the Shema' may be read] in any language which thou hearest.
26.32: And R. Jose [ — where does he find a basis in the Torah for this regulation] ? Both are to be derived from the word "Hear."
26.33: We have learnt elsewhere in the Mishnah :
26.34: A deaf man who speaks but cannot hear may not separate the Terumah ; but if he has done so, his Terumah is valid.
26.35: Who is the authority for the teaching : [The Terumah separated by] a deaf man who speaks but cannot hear is post factum valid, but not ab initio?
26.37: It is R. Jose ; because we have learnt in our Mishnah :
26.38: Who reads the Shema' without making it audible to his ear has complied with the requirements of the law. These are the words of R. Judah.
26.42: Only in the matter of the reading of the Shema, which is an ordinance of the Torah, does R. Jose say that the man has not fulfilled his obligation ; but in the matter of Terumah [the deaf man would have fulfilled it], because it is a question of saying the benediction and the saying of the benediction is ordained by the Rabbis, and [the validity of the Terumah] is not dependent upon the benediction.
26.43: But how [do we know that the teaching in the quoted Mishnah] is R. Jose's?
26.45: and he means to say with reference also to the reading of the Shema' that having read it inaudibly he has complied with the requirements of the law,
26.46: but ab initio he should not read it so ?
26.47: Thou mayest find proof for this in the fact that he states Who reads [the Shema' without making it audible], i.e. post factum it is valid, but not ab initio !
26.49: that the fact that our Mishnah states Who reads is intended to show how extreme is the view of R. Jose, for he means to say
26.50: that even post factum it is not valid; since were it R. Judah, even ab initio it would still be valid.
26.51: Having demonstrated that [the Mishnah about Terumah] is in accord with R. Jose, what, however, of the following ? There is a teaching:
26.52: A man must not say the Grace after meals
26.53: in his heart [inaudibly] ; but if he has done so, he has fulfilled his obligation. Whose view is this?
26.54: It can be neither R. Jose's nor R. Judah's.
26.55: For were it R. Judah's, if the man had said [Grace inaudibly]
26.56: ab initio he would also have fulfilled his duty ; if R. Jose's, even post factum it cannot be considered that he has done so. How is it then?
26.57: It must be R. Judah's, and [his opinion is] post factum it is allowed, but not ab initio.
26.58: What, however, of the following? R. Judah, the son of R. Simeon b. Pazzi, taught :
26.59: A deaf person who can speak but cannot hear may separate the Terumah ab initio. In accordance with whose view is this ?
26.60: It can be neither R. Judah's nor R. Jose's.
26.61: If R. Judah's, he permits it
26.62: post factum, but not ab initio; if R. Jose's,
26.63: he does not allow it even post factum.
26.64: It is certainly in agreement with R. Judah, even though it be ab initio ; and there is no contradiction.
26.65: The latter is his own opinion, the other the opinion of his teacher.  For there is a teaching : R. Judah says in the name of R. Eleazar b. 'Azariah :
26.66: When one reads the Shema' he must make it audible to his ear ; as it is said,
26.67: "Hear, O Israel, the Lord our God, the Lord is one" (Deut. vi. 4).
26.69: Behold the Scriptures state, "And these words which I command thee this day shall be upon thy heart" (ibid. v. 6), i.e. the words depend on the Kawwanah of the heart. Since thou hast reached so far, thou mayest even suppose that
26.70: R. Judah agrees with his teacher's opinion, and there is no contradiction, one being R. Meir's view and the other R. Judah's.
26.71: We have learnt elsewhere in the Mishnah :
26.72: All are fit and proper persons to read the Megillah, except a deaf person, a mentally defective, and a minor. R. Judah allows a minor to read.
26.73: Who is the authority for the teaching that if a deaf person has read it, his recital is even post factum invalid?
26.75: that it is R. Jose ; for we have learnt in our Mishnah :
26.76: Who reads the Shema' without making it audible to his ear has complied with the requirements of the law. These are the words of R. Judah.
26.79: How can we know that [this quoted Mishnah] is R. Jose's view [and means that the reading of the Megillah by a deaf person] is also invalid post factum ;

27.0: perhaps it is R. Judah's view and ab initio it is not permitted, but post factum it is valid ?
27.1: This cannot enter thy mind ; because the Mishnah refers to a deaf person exactly as to the mentally defective and minor ;
27.2: and therefore, as in the case of a mentally defective and minor even post factum [the reading of the Megillah] is invalid,
27.3: so also if a deaf person has read it, it is likewise invalid.
27.4: But perhaps the two have to be kept distinct!
27.5: Still thou canst not possibly maintain that it is in accord with R. Judah ; because from what is stated in the sequel,
27.6: "R. Judah allows a minor to read [the Megillah]" it is to be inferred that the first part is not R. Judah's view !
27.7: But perhaps the whole of it is R. Judah's view, there being two kinds of "minor," and [the wording of the Mishnah] is defective and should read thus :
27.8: "All are fit and proper persons to read the Megillah except a deaf person, a mentally defective person and a minor. Of whom does this speak ? Of a minor who has not yet reached Initiation; but a minor who has reached Initiation is fit to read it even ab initio. These are the words of R. Judah, for R. Judah permits a minor to read."
27.9: Having demonstrated that [the Mishnah about the reading of the Megillah] is in accord with R. Judah and post factum it is permissible, but not ab initio, what, however, of the teaching of R. Judah, the son of R. Simeon b. Pazzi :
27.10: A deaf person who speaks but cannot hear may separate the Terumah ab initio ? Whose view is that?
27.11: It cannot be R. Judah's, nor R. Jose's.
27.12: If R. Judah's, post factum it should be allowed, but not ab initio; if R. Jose's, even post factum it should be invalid. Whose view is it then ?
27.13: R. Judah's and even ab initio it is permissible.
27.14: What, however, of the following ? There is a teaching :
27.15: A man must not say Grace after meals in his heart ; but if he has done so, he has complied with the requirements of the law. Whose view is that ?
27.16: It is not R. Judah's, nor R. Jose's.
27.17: If R. Judah's, he would allow that to act thus ab initio likewise complies with the requirements of the law ; if R. Jose's, even post factum it is not valid.
27.18: It is certainly R. Judah's view, and even ab initio it is valid. Nor is there any contradiction ;
27.19: the latter being R. Judah's own opinion, the other that of his teacher. For there is a teaching : R. Judah says in the name of R. Eleazar b. 'Azariah :
27.20: He who reads the Shema' must make it audible to his ear ; as it is said,
27.22: R. Meir said to him : Behold the Scriptures state,
27.23: "And these words which I command thee this day shall be upon thy heart," i.e. the words depend upon the Kawwanah of the heart.
27.24: Since thou hast reached so far, thou mayest even suppose that
27.25: R. Judah agrees with his teacher's opinion ; and there is no contradiction, one being R. Judah's view, the other R. Meir's.
27.26: Rab Hisda said in the name of Rab Shela:
27.27: The Halakah is in accord with R. Judah's view which he reported in the name of R. Eleazar b. 'Azariah, and the Halakah is in accord with R. Judah.
27.28: It is necessary [to state it in this way] ; for if he had informed us only that the Halakah is in accord with R. Judah, I might have supposed
27.29: [the Shema' need not be read audibly] ab initio ; therefore he tells us that
27.30: the Halakah is in accord with R. Judah's view which he reported in the name of R. Eleazar b. 'Azariah.
27.31: And if he had informed us only that the Halakah is in accord with R. Judah's view which he reported in the name of R. Eleazar b. 'Azariah, I might have supposed
27.32: that it is essential [for the Shema' to be read audibly ab initio] and there was no rectification [if this had not been done]. Therefore he informs us that
27.33: the Halakah is in accord with R. Judah.
27.35: The dispute is only over the reading of the Shema', but with other commandments all agree that [if inaudible] he has not complied with the requirements of the law ; for it is written,
27.37: But it is quoted in objection :
27.38: One may not say the Grace after meals in his heart ; but if he has done so, he has complied with the requirements of the law !
27.39: But if [the statement of Rab Joseph] was reported, it must have been reported as follows :
27.41: The dispute is only over the reading of the Shema' ; for it is written,
27.42: "Hear O Israel" ; but with other commandments all agree that [if inaudible] he has complied with the requirements of the law.
27.43: But it is written, "Attend and hear, O Israel" !
27.44: That refers to reading the Scriptures.
27.45: If he had read it without distinctly pronouncing its letters.
27.46: R. Tabi said in the name of R. Josiah : The Halakah is in accord with the more lenient view in both instances.
27.47: R. Tabi also said in the name of R. Josiah : What means that which is written,
27.48: "There are three things that are never satisfied... the grave, and the barren womb," etc. (Prov, xxx. 15 f.) — what is the connection between "the grave" and "the barren womb"?
27.49: Its intention is to tell thee that
27.50: as the womb receives and yields up, so the grave receives and yields up.
27.51: And may we not use the a fortiori argument ?
27.52: As the womb receives [the seed] in silence and yields up [the child] with loud cries, how much more so will the grave, which receives [the body] with loud cries [of lament], yield up with loud cries !
27.53: Hence a refutation of those who assert that the resurrection of the dead is not taught in the Torah.
27.54: Rab Josiah taught in the presence of Raba :
27.55: "And thou shalt write them" (Deut. vi. 9) means that the whole [of the first two paragraphs of the Shema'] must be written [in the Tefillin], even the words of the commands.
27.57: Should one ask thee whose teaching this is, it is R. Judah's; for he stated with reference to the woman suspected of adultery : One writes the curses but not the words of the command,
27.58: because in this connection it is written,
27.59: "And the priests shall write these curses in a scroll" (Num. v. 23), but here [in connection with Tefillin] it is written, "And thou shalt write them," i.e. even the words of the command.
27.60: Dost thou suppose that R. Judah's reason is because the text states, "[And the priest] shall write"?
27.61: His reason is because the text states, "[And the priest shall write] these curses," i.e. the curses shall be written, but not the words of the command.
27.62: It is necessary [to mention this point] ;
27.63: because it might have entered thy mind that I mean we can draw an analogy from the use of the verb "to write" in the former instance, thus : As there [with reference to the woman suspected of adultery] the curses were to be written and not the words of the command, so here likewise [with the Tefillin] the words of the command were not to be written! Therefore the All-merciful wrote, "And thou shalt write them" i.e. even the words of the command.
27.64: Rab Obadiah taught in the presence of Raba :
27.65: "And ye shall teach" (Deut. xi. 19), i.e. let thy teaching be perfect — let one make a brief pause between words which are liable to be jumbled together,
27.67: For instance 'al lebabeka "upon thy heart" ; 'al lebabekem "upon your heart" ; bekol lebabeka "with all thy heart" ; bekol lebabekem "with all your heart" ; 'eseb besadeka "grass in thy field" ; wa'abadtem meherah "and ye will perish speedily" ; hakkanaph petil "the corner, a thread" ; etkem me'eres "you from the land."
27.68: R. Hamma b. R. Hannina said :
27.69: Whoever reads the Shema' with distinct pronunciation of its letters, Gehinnom is cooled for him ; as it is said,
27.70: "When the Almighty scattereth kings therein, it snoweth in Zalmon" (Ps. Ixviii. 15). Read not bephares "[When the Almighty] scattereth," but read bepharesh "When one uttereth [the name of the Almighty] distinctly" ; and read not beZalmon "in Zalmon," but besalmawet "in the shadow of death."
27.71: R. Hamma b. R. Hannina also said :

28.1: "As streams  stretched out, as gardens by the river-side, as tents planted by the Lord, as cedars beside the waters" (Num. xxiv. 6)? Its intention is to tell thee that
28.2: as streams bring a man up from impurity to purity, so do "tents" bring a man up from the scale of guilt to the scale of merit.
28.3: If one read it in the wrong order of its paragraphs, he has not complied with the requirements of the law.
28.4: R. Ammi and R. Assi were once decorating the bridal-chamber for R.Eleazar. He said to them,
28.5: "In the meanwhile I will go and listen to the teaching in the House of Study, and will come back and report it to you."
28.6: He went and found a Tanna expounding in the presence of R. Johanan:
28.7: Should one have read the Shema' and erred without knowing for certain where he made the mistake, if this occurred in the middle of the first paragraph he must return to the commencement ; if between two paragraphs, he must return to the first of them ; if between "and thou shalt write them" and "ye shall write them," he must return to the first.
28.9: This latter only applies if he has not started "That your days may be multiplied" ; but should he have commenced that sentence, [he may assume that] he followed on from force of habit.
28.10: [R. Eleazar] returned and reported it to them.
28.12: "If we had come for nothing else than to hear this, it would be sufficient for us."
28.13: MISHNAH Workmen may read the Shema' on the top of a tree or on top of scaffolding, but this they may not do with the Tefillah.
28.14: A bridegroom is exempt from the obligation of reading the Shema' on the first night [of his marriage],
28.15: and until the termination of the ensuing Sabbath, if he has not consummated the marriage.
28.16: It happened that when Rabban Gamaliel married, he read the Shema' on the first night.
28.18: "Our teacher ! thou hast taught us that a bridegroom is exempt from the obligation of reading the Shema'."
28.20: "I will not hearken to you to annul the kingdom of heaven from myself even a single hour."
28.22: Workmen may read [the Shema'] on the top of a tree or on the top of scaffolding. They may likewise say the Tefillah on top of an olive-tree or fig-tree ; but with all other trees they must descend to the ground to say the Tefillah.
28.23: The employer must in every instance descend to the ground to say the Tefillah, because his mind is not settled.
28.24: Rab Mari, the son of Samuel's daughter, asked Raba : Our Mishnah states :
28.25: Workmen may read [the Shema'] on the top of a tree or on the top of scaffolding ; hence it is to be inferred that
28.28: Who reads the Shema' must direct his heart; as it is said,
28.30: "Attend and hear, O Israel " (ibid, xxvii. 9) ; as here "attention" is required so also there !
28.33: Hast thou heard anything on this point ?
28.36: [Kawwanah is demanded of workmen] only if they stop their work to read it.
28.37: But lo, there is a teaching : Bet Hillel say :
28.38: Workmen may remain at their work and read it !
28.40: the former refers to the first paragraph [of the Shema'], the latter to the second.
28.42: Labourers who are working for an employer should read the Shema', say the benedictions before and after, eat their meal with Grace before and after, and then pray the Eighteen Benedictions; but they cannot descend before the Ark nor raise their hands.
28.43: But lo, there is a teaching:
28.44: [Such men are to say] an abstract of the Eighteen Benedictions!
28.45: Rab Sheshet said : There is no contradiction ;
28.46: the first being Rabban Gamaliel's view, the latter R. Joshua's.
28.47: If it be R. Joshua's view, why does he mention labourers specially, since it holds good of anybody ?
28.48: But [we have to assume that] both are Rabban Gamaliel's,
28.50: the latter treating of one who works for a wage, the former of one who works for his keep.
28.51: And so there is a teaching :
28.52: Labourers who are working for an employer should read the Shema' say the Tefillah, then eat their meal, but should not say Grace before it, only two benedictions after it. How is this meant? The first benediction as ordained; the second commences with the benediction of "the land," and they include "Who... rebuildest Jerusalem" in the benediction of "the land."
28.53: To whom does this apply ? To those who work for a wage ; but should they work for their keep or their employer take his meals with them, they say the [entire] Grace after meals as ordained.
28.54: A bridegroom is exempt from the obligation of reading the Shema'.
28.56: "When thou sittest in thy house" (Deut. vi. 7) excludes one occupied with a religious duty ; "and when thou walkest by the way" (ibid.) excludes a bridegroom. Hence they say :
28.57: He who takes a virgin to his house as wife is exempt ; but if he marry a widow, he has that obligation.
28.60: Because [the text uses the word] "way" [we argue]: Just as the way is voluntary, so all is voluntary.
28.61: Are we not here dealing with one who is on his way to perform a religious duty, and even so the All-merciful requires of him the reading [of the Shema'] ?
28.62: In that case, the All-merciful should have written "when walking." What means "when thou walkest"? Deduce from this, [it means]
28.63: when walking for thine own purpose thou art under the obligation [to read the Shema'] ; but when it is the performance of a religious duty, thou art exempt.

29.0: If so,  why especially mention, "He who takes a virgin to his house as wife" ? Even one who takes a widow to wife should also [be exempt] !
29.1: The man [who marries a virgin] is anxious ; the other is not.
29.2: Should the reason [of exemption] be on account of anxiety, then it ought to apply also to one whose ship has sunk at sea !
29.3: Why, then, does R. Abba b. Zabda declare in the name of Rab :
29.4: A mourner is under the obligation to observe all the commandments mentioned in the Torah except Tefillin, because they are called an adornment; as it is said,
29.6: The answer is : [There is a difference] ;.
29.7: the latter being troubled by anxiety of some voluntary matter, whereas the former has anxiety in connection with a religious duty.
29.8: MISHNAH [Rabban Gamaliel] bathed on the first night of his wife's death. His disciples said to him,
29.9: "Our master! Thou hast taught us that a mourner is forbidden to bathe !"
29.11: "I am not like other men ; I am in delicate health."
29.12: When his slave, Tabi, died, lie accepted condolence on his behalf.
29.14: "Our master ! Thou hast taught us that one may not accept condolence on the death of slaves" !
29.16: "My slave, Tabi, was not like other slaves; he was a worthy man."
29.17: If a bridegroom wishes to read the Shema' on the first night [of his marriage], he may do so.
29.19: "Not everybody who wishes to assume the name may do so."
29.20: GEMARA What was Rabban Gamaliel's reason?
29.21: He was of the opinion that the application of the laws of mourning in the night is a Rabbinical injunction; for it is written,
29.22: "And the end thereof as a bitter day" (Amos viii. 10); and in the case of a person in delicate health, the Rabbis do not so decree.
29.23: When his slave, Tabi, died, etc.
29.25: [At the burial of] male and female slaves, we do not stand in a row for them, nor do we pronounce
29.26: over them the benediction of mourners and the condolence of mourners.
29.27: It happened that R. Eliezer's female slave died and his disciples went in to comfort him.
29.28: When he saw them, he ascended to an upper room, but they ascended after him.
29.29: He went into the court-way, but they went after him. He entered the guest-chamber, but they entered after him.
29.31: I imagined you would be scalded with tepid water; but now you are not scalded even with hot water.
29.33: [On the death of] male and female slaves, we do not stand in a row for them, nor do we pronounce over them the benediction of mourners and the condolence of mourners?
29.34: What, however, do we say over them ? As we say to a man on the death of his ox or ass,
29.35: "May the Omnipresent repair thy loss," so do we say to a man on the death of his slaves,
29.38: We do not speak a funeral oration over male and female slaves.
29.40: If he was a worthy man, we say of him,
29.41: "Alas, the good and faithful man who derived pleasure from his work !"
29.43: "In that case, what hast thou left to be said over worthy men [who are not slaves]?"
29.45: We restrict the name "Patriarch" to three, and "Matriarch" to four.
29.46: Why is the name "Patriarch" [restricted to three]?
29.47: Is it because we are not certain whether we are descended from Reuben or Simeon ? If so, in the case of the Matriarchs we are not certain whether we are descended from Rachel or Leah !
29.49: up to here they were esteemed sufficiently [to be called "Patriarchs"] ; their successors were not so esteemed.
29.51: We do not call male and female slaves "Father so-and-so" or "Mother so-and-so." But Rabban Gamaliel's [slaves] used to be called in this manner.
29.52: This is an actual fact to upset [the teaching just quoted] !
29.53: [No; it is different with them,] because they were highly esteemed.
29.55: what means that which is written,
