29.56: "So will I bless Thee as long as I live ; in Thy name will I lift up my hands" (Ps. Ixiii. 5)? "So will I bless Thee as long as I live" refers to the reading of the Shema' ; "in Thy name will I lift up my hands" refers to Tefillah.
29.57: If one act thus, of him the text saith,
29.58: "My soul is satisfied as with marrow and fatness" (ibid. v. 6) ; and not only that, but he will inherit two worlds, this world and the world to come, as it is said,
29.59: "And my mouth will praise Thee with joyful lips" (ibid.).
29.60: R. Eleazar used to add at the conclusion of his prayer :
29.61: May it be Thy will, O Lord our God, to cause love and brotherhood, peace and comradeship, to abide in our lot, to enlarge our border with disciples, to prosper our goal with a [happy] end and with hope, to set our portion in the Garden of Eden, and fortify us with good companionship and the good impulse in Thy universe, so that we rise up and find the longing of our heart to fear Thy name ; and may the satisfaction of our soul come before Thee for good.
29.62: R. Johanan used to add at the conclusion of his prayer:
29.63: May it be Thy will, O Lord our God, to glance at our shame and look upon our evil plight ; and do Thou clothe Thyself in Thy mercy, cover Thyself with Thy might, enfold Thyself with Thy piety and gird Thyself with Thy grace, and may Thy attribute of goodness and gentleness come before Thee.
29.64: R. Zera used to add at the conclusion of his prayer :
29.65: May it be Thy will, O Lord our God, that we sin not ; neither may we be put to shame nor be confounded before our fathers.
29.66: R. Hiyya used to add at the conclusion of his prayer :
29.67: May it be Thy will, O Lord our God, that Thy Torah be our occupation ; and let not our heart grow faint nor our eyes dim.
29.68: Rab used to add at the conclusion of his prayer :
29.69: May it be Thy will, O Lord our God, to grant us long life, a life of peace, a life of good, a life of blessing, a life of sustenance, a life of bodily vigour, a life marked by the fear of sin, a life free from shame and reproach, a life of prosperity and honour, a life in which the love of Torah and the fear of Heaven shall cleave to us, a life wherein Thou fulfillest all the desires of our heart for good.
29.70: Rabbi used to add at the conclusion of his prayer :
29.71: May it be Thy will, O Lord our God and God of our fathers, to deliver me from arrogant men and from arrogance, from a bad man, and from any mishap, from the evil impulse, from a bad companion, from a bad neighbour, and from the adversary that destroyeth ; from a hard judgment, and from a hard opponent, whether he be a son of the covenant or be not a son of the covenant.
29.72: [Thus did Rabbi pray], although eunuchs were standing by him.
29.73: Rab Saphra used to add at the conclusion of his prayer :
29.74: May it be Thy will, O Lord our God, to grant peace

30.0: in the household above and the household below, and among the students who occupy themselves with Thy Torah, whether they devote themselves thereto for its own sake or not for its own sake; and as for them that devote themselves thereto not for its own sake, may it be Thy will that they do devote themselves thereto for its own sake.
30.1: R. Alexander used to add at the conclusion of his prayer :
30.2: May it be Thy will, O Lord our God, to place us in a corner of light and not in a corner of darkness ; and may not our heart grow faint nor our eyes dim.
30.4: this was Rab Hamnuna's prayer ; and R. Alexander used to add at the conclusion of his prayer :
30.5: Lord of the universe ! It is revealed and known before Thee that it is our will to perform Thy will ; but what stands in the way?
30.6: The leaven that is in the dough and the servitude of the kingdoms.
30.7: May it be Thy will to deliver us from their hand, so that we may again perform the statutes of Thy will with a perfect heart.
30.8: Raba used to add at the conclusion of his prayer :
30.9: O my God, before I was formed I was nothing worth, and now that I have been formed I am but as though I had not been formed. Dust am I in my life ; how much more so in my death. Behold I am before Thee like a vessel filled with shame and confusion. O may it be Thy will, O Lord my God, that I may sin no more; and as to the sins I have committed, purge them away in Thine abounding compassion though not by means of affliction and sore diseases.
30.10: That is the confession of Rab Hamnuna Zuta on the Day of Atonement.
30.11: Mar b. Kabina used to add at the conclusion of his prayer :
30.12: O my God ! (Guard my tongue from evil and my lips from speaking guile ; and to such as curse me let my soul be dumb, yea, let my soul be unto all as the dust. Open my heart to Thy Torah, and let my soul pursue Thy commandments. And do Thou deliver me from mishap, from the evil impulse, and from an evil woman and all evil which breaks forth to come upon the world. If any design evil against me, speedily make their counsel of none effect, and frustrate their designs. Let the words of my mouth and the meditation of my heart be acceptable before Thee, O Lord my Rock and Redeemer.
30.13: Rab Sheshet, when observing a fast, used to add at the conclusion of his prayer :
30.14: Lord of the universe ! It is revealed before Thee that when the Sanctuary was in existence, a man sinned and brought an offering, of which they sacrificed only the fat and the blood, and atonement was made for him.
30.15: But now, I observe a fast, and my fat and blood are diminished. May it be Thy will, that my fat and blood which have been diminished may be accounted as though I had offered them before Thee upon the altar, and do Thou favour me.
30.16: R. Johanan said : R. Meir, on concluding the reading of the Book of Job, used to say:
30.17: It is the fate of man to die and of cattle to be slaughtered, and all are destined to die.
30.18: Happy is he who has grown in Torah and whose labour has been in Torah ; who has caused tranquillity of spirit to his Creator, advanced in good repute, and departed from the world with a good name. Of him said Solomon, "A good name is better than precious oil, and the day of death than the day of one's birth " (Eccles. vii. 1).
30.19: It was a favourite saying of R. Meir :
30.20: Learn with all thy heart and with all thy soul to know My ways and watch at the doors of My Torah. Guard My Torah in thy heart and let the fear of Me be before thine eyes. Keep thy mouth from all sin, and purify and sanctify thyself from all guilt and iniquity. Then shall I be with thee everywhere.
30.21: It was a favourite saying of the Rabbis of Jabneh :
30.22: I am a creature [of God] and my neighbour is also His creature ; my work is in the city and his in the field ; I rise early to my work and he rises early to his. As he cannot excel in my work, so I cannot excel in his work. But perhaps thou sayest,
30.23: "I do great things and he small things"! We have learnt that [it matters not whether]
30.24: one does much or little, if only he direct his heart to Heaven.
30.25: It was a favourite saying of Abbai:
30.26: A man should always be cunning in the fear [of God], giving the soft answer that turneth away wrath (cf. Prov. xv. 1), increasing peace with his brethren and relatives and with all men, even the heathen in the street ; so that he may be beloved above and popular on earth, and acceptable to his fellow-creatures.
30.27: They say of Rabban Johanan b.
30.28: Zakkai that nobody ever greeted him first, not even the heathen in the street.
30.29: It was a favourite saying of Raba :
30.30: The goal of wisdom is repentance and good works;
30.31: so that a man shall not read [Torah] and study [Mishnah] and then contradict his father or mother or teacher or anybody greater than he in knowledge and number [of years]; as it is said,
30.32: "The fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom, a good understanding have all that do thereafter" (Ps. cxi. 10).
30.33: "All that learn" is not said here, but "all that do thereafter," i.e. they that practise Torah for its own sake, but not they that practise Torah not for its own sake.
30.34: As for him who does not fulfil the Torah for its own sake, it were better had he never been created.
30.35: It was a favourite saying of Rab :
30.36: Not like this world is the world to come. In the world to come there is neither eating nor drinking; no procreation of children or business transactions; no envy or hatred or rivalry ; but the righteous sit enthroned, their crowns on their heads, and enjoy the lustre of the Shekinah; as it is said,
30.37: "And they beheld God, and did eat and drink" (Exod. xxiv. ll).
30.38: Our Rabbis have taught : Greater is the promise given by the Holy One, blessed be He, to women than to men ; as it is said, "Rise up, ye women that, are at ease, and hear My voice ; ye confident daughters, give ear unto My speech" (Is. xxxii. 9).
30.40: Wherewith do women acquire merit? By sending their children to learn [Torah] in the Synagogue and their husbands to study in the schools of the Rabbis, and waiting for their husbands until they return from the schools of the Rabbis.
30.41: As the Rabbis departed from the school of R. Ammi (another version: R. Hannina's school), they said to him:
30.42: Mayest thou see thy world in thy life-time, and may thine end be in the life of the world to come and thy hope throughout the generations.
30.43: May thy heart meditate in understanding, thy mouth speak wisdom, thy tongue abound in joyful songs, thine eyelids set thy glance straight before thee, thine eyes be illumined with the light of the Torah, thy countenance shine like the splendour of the firmament, thy lips utter knowledge, thy reins exult with up-rightness, and thy feet run to hear the words of the Ancient of days.
30.44: As the Rabbis departed from the school of Rab Hisda (another version : the school of R. Samuel b. Nahmani) they said to him :
30.45: "Our leaders are well laden ; with no breach, and no going forth, and no outcry in our broad places" (Ps. cxliv. 14).
30.46: "Our leaders are well laden" — Rab and Samuel (another version : R. Johanan and R. Eleazar) [differ in interpretation] ; one says,
30.47: "Our leaders" in Torah "are well laden" with religious duties ;
30.49: "Our leaders" in Torah and religious duties "are well laden" with sufferings.

31.0: "With no breach" — may not our company be like the company of David from which issued Ahitophel ; "and no going forth" — may not our company be like the company of Saul from which issued Doeg the Edomite; "and no outcry" — may not our company be like the company of Elisha from which issued Gehazi ; "in our broad places" — that we may not have a son or disciple who spoiled his food in public, like the Nazarene.
31.1: "Hearken unto Me, ye stout-hearted, that are far from righteousness" (Is. xlvi. 12).
31.2: Rab and Samuel (another version : R. Johanan and R. Eleazar) [differ in interpretation]. One says :
31.3: The whole world is nourished through righteousness, but the "stout-hearted" are nourished by the arm.
31.5: The whole world is nourished through their merit, but they are not nourished even by their own merit.
31.6: This is like the statement of Rab Judah who says in the name of Rab :
31.7: Every day a Bat Kol issues from Mount Horeb and proclaims :
31.8: "All the world is nourished for the sake of My son, Hannina, but My son, Hannina, is satisfied with a Kab of locusts from the Sabbath-eve to the next Sabbath-eve."
31.9: This contradicts the statement of Rab Judah who says :
31.10: Who are the "stout-hearted"? They are the foolish Gobeans.
31.12: Thou canst know [that the "stout-hearted" are the Gobeans] because not one of them has ever been made a proselyte.
31.14: [The "stout-hearted" are] the inhabitants of Mata Mehasya, for they beheld the glory of the Torah twice yearly, but not one of them has ever been made a proselyte.
31.15: If a bridegroom wishes to read the Shema', etc.
31.16: It is to be inferred that Rabban Simeon b. Gamaliel is concerned lest a charge of presumption [be brought against a bridegroom who reads the Shema' on the first night of his marriage and therefore forbids it], whereas the Rabbis have no such concern [and permit it]. But we understood just the opposite of them !
31.17: For there is a Mishnaic teaching :
31.18: In a place where they are accustomed to work on the ninth of Ab, we may work ; but in a place where they are not accustomed to work, we may not. Disciples of the wise must cease work in every place.
31.20: Everyone should regard himself as a disciple of the wise.
31.21: Here is an inconsistency of the Rabbis and an inconsistency of Rabban Simeon b. Gamaliel !
31.24: but Rab Shesha b. Rab Iddi said :
31.25: Thou hast surely no need to reverse the statement, because the Rabbis do not here contradict themselves.
31.26: In the case of the reading of the Shema' which everybody reads, if [the bridegroom] also reads it, it would not seem presumptuous ; but in the latter instance, since everybody works [on the ninth of Ab] and he does not, it would appear presumptuous.
31.27: Likewise, Rabban Simeon b. Gamaliel does not contradict himself.
31.28: In the case of the reading of the Shema', its validity depends on Kawwanah, and we testify that [the bridegroom] would not be able to concentrate his mind ;
31.29: but here, if one saw [a man not working on the ninth of Ab] he would merely say
31.30: "He has no work to do." Go out and see how many idle men there are in the street.
31.31: May we return to thee : Who reads.
31.32: MISHNAH  He whose dead is lying before him [unburied] is exempt from the reading of the Shema', from Tefillah, Tefillin and all the commandments mentioned in the Torah.
31.33: The bearers of the bier and they who relieve them, and they who relieve these latter — such as are before the bier and such as are behind it —
31.34: they who are before it, whose services will be required, are exempt ; but they who are behind it, whose services may still be required, are under the obligation. But both are exempt from the Tefillah.
31.35: Having buried the dead and returned [from the grave], if they have sufficient time to begin and finish [the Shema'] before arriving at the row, they should commence it ; but if they have not sufficient time, they should not commence it.
31.36: As for those who stand in the row, the inner line is exempt, the outer line under the obligation.
31.37: Women and slaves and minors  are exempt from reciting Kriyat Shma and from wearing Tefilen and they are obligated in prayer and in Mezuzah and in grace after meals
31.38: GEMARA When the body is lying before him, he is exempt; [it is consequently to be inferred that] when it is not lying before him, he is not exempt !
31.41: before him should eat his meal in another room, and if he has no other room he should eat in a neighbour's house ; if such be not available, he should put up a partition and have his meal ; if he has nothing wherewith to make a partition, he should turn his face away [from the body] and eat. But he must not have his meal in a reclining position, or partake of meat or drink wine ; nor does he say Grace or arrange Zimmun,

32.0: nor do others say Grace on his behalf or include him for Zimmun. He is likewise exempt from the reading of the Shema', from Tefillah, Tefillin, and all the commandments mentioned in the Torah.
32.1: On the Sabbath, however, he may recline at his meal, eat meat and drink wine, say Grace and arrange Zimmun, and others may say Grace on his behalf and include him for Zimmun ; and he is under the obligation of reading the Shema' and Tefillah, and all the commandments mentioned in the Torah.
32.3: Since he is under the obligation of these, he has obviously the obligation of them all !
32.5: What is the point of divergence between them? The question of connubial intercourse.
32.6: It is here at any rate taught that [the mourner, although he is not in the same room as the body,] is exempt from reading the Shema', from Tefillah, Tefillin, and all the commandments mentioned in the Torah !
32.8: [The Baraita] is to be interpreted as referring to one who turns his face from the body and eats.
32.10: Since the duty of burying rests upon him, it is to be regarded as though the body was lying before him; as it is said,
32.11: "And Abraham rose up from before his dead" (Gen. xxiii. 3) and it is said
32.12: "That I may bury my dead from before me" (ibid. v. 4), i.e. so long as the duty of burial rested upon him, it was as though the body was actually before him.
32.13: He whose dead [is lying before him] is exempt, but [so it may The be inferred,] not the watcher. But lo, there is a teaching :
32.14: Who watches the body, although it is not his dead, is exempt from reading the Shema', from Tefillah, Tefillin, and all the commandments mentioned in the Torah !
32.15: "Who watches the body, although it is not his dead" [so stated the Baraita ; therefore it is to be inferred] if it is his dead, although he does not watch the body, [he is exempt].
32.16: If it be his dead or if he watches it, he is exempt ; but [so it may be inferred] one who walks in a cemetery is not ! But lo, there is a teaching :
32.17: A man must not walk in a cemetery with his Tefillin on his head or holding a scroll of the Torah and reading therein ; should he do so, he commits a transgression because of the injunction : "Whoso mocketh the poor blasphemeth his Maker" (Prov. xvii. 5) !
32.18: In this latter case, within four cubits [of the grave] it
32.19: is forbidden, but beyond that limit, he is under the obligation ; for the teacher has said :
32.20: A dead body affects four cubits with regard to the reading of the Shema'. But here [in the case of a mourner or watcher], even beyond the limit of four cubits he is exempt.
32.21: It was stated above [in the Baraita] :
32.22: "Who watches the body, although it is not his dead, is exempt from reading the Shema', from Tefillah, Tefillin, and all the commandments mentioned in the Torah."
32.23: Should there be two [watchers], they take it in turn to watch and read.
32.25: Should they be bringing the body in a boat, they place it in one corner and they both pray in another corner !
32.26: What is the point of divergence between them ?
32.28: They differ whether we have fear of mice [gnawing the body] ;
32.30: there is such fear, the other
32.33: He who is removing bones from one place to another must not put them into a saddle-bag and set them upon an ass and ride upon them, because this is disrespectful treatment ;
32.34: but if he is afraid of heathens or robbers, he may do so. What they say of bones applies also to a scroll of the Torah.
32.35: To which [clause in this teaching does this last statement refer] ?
32.36: If to the first clause, it is self-evident ; for is a scroll of the Torah less than bones?
32.37: Nay; it refers to the second clause.
32.38: Rahbah said in the name of R. Judah :
32.39: Whoever sees a body [being conveyed to burial] and does not accompany it commits a transgression because of [the injunction] "Whoso mocketh the poor blasphemeth his Maker" (Prov. xvii. 5).
32.40: If he accompany it, what is his reward ?
32.41: Rab Assi said : Of him the Scriptures state,
32.42: "He that is gracious to the poor lendeth unto the Lord" (ibid. xix. 17) and "he that is gracious unto the needy honoureth Him" (ibid. xiv. 31).
32.43: R. Hiyya and R. Jonathan were conversing as they walked in a cemetery, and the "fringes" belonging to R. Jonathan fell upon the graves.
32.45: "Lift them up, so that [the dead] shall not say, 'To-morrow they will come to us, but to-day they revile us'."
32.51: "If thou hast read [this verse], thou hast not read it a second time ; if a second time, then not a third time ; and if a third time, its meaning has not been explained to thee.
32.52: 'For the living know that they shall die' (ibid.) — this refers to the righteous who are called living even in their death ; as it is said,
32.53: 'And Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, the son of a living man of Kabzeel, who had done mighty deeds, he smote the two altar-hearths of Moab ; he went down also and slew a lion in the midst of a pit in time of snow' (II Sam. xxiii. 20).

33.0: — 'Son of a living man !' Are there, then, in the whole world sons [born of! dead men ?
33.1: But, 'son of a living man' [means] even in his death he is called 'living.'
33.2: 'Of Kabzeel, who had done mighty deeds' — [he is so described] because he multiplied and gathered labourers for the Torah.
33.3: 'He smote the two altar-hearths of Moab' — i.e. he left nobody like him, neither [in the time of] the first Temple nor the Second Temple. 'He went down also and slew a lion in the midst of a pit in time of snow' — some say :
33.4: He cut a hole in the ice into which he descended to bathe; others say : He learnt the Sifra debe Rab in a winter's day.
33.5: 'But the dead know not anything' — this refers to the wicked who are called dead in their life-time; as it is said,
33.6: 'And thou, O wicked one, thou art slain, the prince of Israel' (Ezek. xxi. 30)."
33.7: Or if thou wilt, derive it from the following :
33.8: "At the mouth of two witnesses, or three witnesses, shall the dead be put to death" (Deut. xvii. 6).
33.11: he is accounted as dead from the beginning.
33.12: The sons of R. Hiyya went out on to the land; their studies had been difficult for them, and they had had considerable trouble to remember them.
33.14: "Does our father know of this trouble?"
33.18: 'His sons come to honour him, and he knoweth it not' (Job xiv. 21)!"
33.22: 'But his flesh grieveth for him, and his soul mourneth over him' (ibid. v. 22)? And R. Isaac has said :
33.23: The worm is as painful to the flesh of the dead as a needle in the flesh of the living !"
33.25: The dead know of their own troubles, but not of the troubles of others.
33.26: Do they not [know of the troubles of others]?
33.28: It once happened that a pious man gave a denarius to a beggar on the New Year's eve in a time of drought. His wife upbraided him ; so he went and spent the night in the cemetery.
33.29: He heard two spirits conversing. One said to the other,
33.30: "Come, friend, let us wander in the world and hear behind the curtain what visitation is to come upon the world."
33.32: "I cannot, because I am buried in a matting of reeds; but go thou and report to me what thou hearest."
33.33: She went, and having wandered about returned.
33.35: "What didst thou hear, friend, behind the curtain ?"
33.37: "I heard that if one sows in the first rainfall, the hail will smite it."
33.38: This man thereupon went and sowed in the second rainfall.
33.39: [The hail] destroyed everybody's crops but not his.
33.40: The following year, he again spent the [New Year's] night in the cemetery, and heard the same two spirits conversing.
33.42: "Come, let us wander in the world and hear behind the curtain what visitation is to come upon the world."
33.45: that I cannot, because I am buried in a matting of reeds?
33.46: But go thou and come and tell me what thou hearest."
33.47: She went, and wandered about and returned.
33.49: "What didst thou hear behind the curtain ?"
33.51: "I heard that if one sows in the second rainfall, it will be smitten by the blast."
33.52: This man went and sowed in the first rainfall.
33.53: What everybody else sowed was smitten by the blast, but not his.
33.55: "How is it that last year everybody's crop was destroyed by hail, but not thine ; and this year everybody's crop was blasted except thine ?"
33.56: He told her the whole story.
33.58: that very soon afterwards a quarrel broke out between the wife of that pious man and the mother of the girl.
33.59: The former said to the other,
33.60: "Come, I will show thee that thy daughter is buried in reed-matting."
33.61: The following year the same man went and spent the [New Year's] night in the cemetery, and he heard those spirits conversing.
33.63: "Come, friend, let us wander in the world and hear behind the curtain what visitation is to befall the world."
33.65: "Leave me alone, friend ; what has passed between me and thee has been overheard by the living."
33.66: Infer from this that the dead do know !
33.67: [No ;] it is possible that some other person died and went and informed them.
33.69: Ze'iri left a sum of money in charge of his landlady. During the time he went to the school of his master and returned, she died.
33.70: He followed her to the court of death
33.74: "Go and take it from beneath the door-socket in such and such a place ; and tell my mother to send me my comb and tube of eye-paint through so-and-so who will arrive here to-morrow,"
33.75: Conclude from this that the dead do know !
33.78: The father of Samuel was entrusted with some money belonging to orphans. At the time that he passed away, Samuel was not with him.
33.79: People afterwards called him, "Son of the consumer of the orphans' money."
33.80: He went after his father to the court of death
33.84: "There are many of that name here."
33.88: "There are also many of that name here."
33.90: "I want Abba b. Abba, the father of Samuel ; where is he?"
33.92: "He has gone up to the heavenly seminary."
33.93: In the meantime he noticed Levi who was seated apart.
33.95: "Why sittest thou apart? Why hast thou not gone up [to the heavenly seminary]?"
33.98: 'The number of years thou didst not attend the seminary of R. Aphes and didst grieve him on that account, we will not permit thee to ascend to the heavenly seminary'."
33.99: In the meantime his father arrived ; and Samuel noticed that he wept and laughed.
33.105: "Because thou art very highly thought of in this world." Samuel said to him,
33.106: "If I am so esteemed, let them allow Levi to enter" ; and they permitted him to enter.
33.110: "Go, take it from the enclosure of the mill. The upper and lower sums of money belong to us, the middle sum belongs to the orphans."
33.112: "Why didst thou act in this manner?"
33.114: "Should thieves come to steal, they would steal ours ; should the earth destroy, it would destroy ours."
33.115: Conclude from this that the dead do know!
33.116: [No ;] perhaps it was different with Samuel ; being a man so highly esteemed, it may have been announced in advance "Make way for him."
33.117: R. Jonathan likewise retracted; for R. Samuel b. Nahmani said in the name of R. Jonathan :
33.118: Whence do we learn that the dead converse one with the other?
33.120: "And the Lord said unto him, This is the land which I swore unto Abraham, unto Isaac, and unto Jacob, saying" (Deut. xxxiv. 4). What means "saying"? The Holy One, blessed be He, spake to Moses,
33.121: "Go, tell Abraham, Isaac and Jacob, The oath which I swore unto you have I fulfilled for your children."

34.0: If thou shouldest imagine that they were not cognisant [of what transpires on earth], what use would it be to tell them ?
34.2: if they were cognisant, what need was there for him to inform them ?
34.3: To give the credit to Moses.
34.5: Whoever speaks [evil] of the dead is as though he spoke it of a stone.
34.7: they are not aware [of what is spoken],
34.9: they are aware but it does not trouble them.
34.12: [evil] of Mar Samuel [after his death], and a pole fell from the roof and split his skull !
34.13: It is different with a Rabbinical scholar, because the Holy One, blessed be He, defends his honour.
34.15: Whoever talks [evil] after the bier of disciplas of the wise will fall into Gehinnom ; as it is said,
34.16: "But as for such as turn aside unto their crooked ways, the Lord will lead them away with the workers of iniquity. Peace be upon Israel" (Ps. cxxv. 5) — i.e. even at a time when "there is peace upon Israel," "the Lord will lead them away with the workers of iniquity."
34.17: It was taught by the school of R. Ishmael :
34.18: If thou seest a scholar committing an offence at night, do not criticise him for it by day ; perhaps he has repented by then.
34.19: Dost thou imagine perhaps he has repented?
34.22: This refers only to an offence concerned with his person ; but in a matter involving money, [he may be criticised] until he refunds it to its owner.
34.23: R. Joshua b. Levi also said :
34.24: In twenty-four places [it is taught] that the Bet Din excommunicates a man for [lack of] respect to a teacher, and we learn them all in our Mishnah.
34.28: Search and thou wilt find them.
34.29: He accordingly went and searched and found three —
34.30: Who despises the washing of the hands, who talks [evil] after the bier of the disciples of the wise, and who acts arrogantly towards the Most High.
34.31: "Who talks after the bier of disciples of the wise" ; where is this to be found ?
34.33: ['Akabya b. Mahalalel] used to say : We may not administer the waters of a woman suspected of adultery to a female proselyte or freed woman ;
34.38: freed handmaid of Jerusalem, and Shemayah and Abtalion did administer the waters to her!"
34.40: "It was for show that they made her drink."
34.41: Thereupon the Sages excommunicated him and he died under the ban, and the Bet Din stoned his coffin.
34.42: "Whoever despises the washing of the hands" ; where is this found ?
34.43: There is a Mishnaic teaching : R. Judah said :
34.44: God forbid that we should suppose that 'Akabya b. Mahalalel was excommunicated, for the Temple-court was not locked upon any man of Israel equal to him in knowledge, purity and fear of sin. But who was it they excommunicated? It was Eleazar b. Hanok, because he made light of the washing of the hands ;
34.45: and when he died the Bet Din sent and placed a large stone upon his coffin,
34.47: that whoever is excommunicated and dies under the ban, the Bet Din stones his coffin.
34.48: "Who acts arrogantly towards the Most High" ; where is this to be found?
34.49: There is a Mishnaic teaching : Simeon b. Shetah sent to Honi Hamme'aggel :
34.50: "Thou art deserving of excommunication, and wert thou not Honi, I would pronounce the ban against thee ; but what can I do seeing that thou art petulant with the Omnipresent, and nevertheless He fulfils thy desires as a father gratifies a petulant child ; and concerning thee the Scriptures state, 'Let thy father and thy mother be glad, and let her that bore thee rejoice ' (Prov. xxiii. 25)." Is there no other instance [of arrogance towards God]?
34.53: Theodosius of Rome accustomed the Jews in Rome to eat kids roasted in their entirety on the Passover night.
34.55: "If thou wert not Theodosius, I would have issued a ban against thee, for thou hast induced Israelites to eat the holy things outside [Jerusalem]."
34.56: But we are speaking of instances mentioned in our Mishnah ; and this is a Baraita !
34.57: Is there none in the Mishnah ?
34.58: Yes, there is ; for there is a Mishnaic teaching :
34.59: If one has cut [a portable earthenware oven] into layers and placed sand between each layer, R. Eliezer declares it clean, but the Sages declare it unclean ; and this is what is known as "the oven of the serpent."
34.61: Rab Judah said in the name of Samuel :
34.62: This teaches that the Sages wound it round with discussions as a serpent [winds itself round something] and proved that the oven was unclean.
34.64: That day they brought everything that R. Eliezer had proclaimed clean and burnt it in his presence, and finally they excommunicated him.
34.65: Despite this, we have not learnt a case of excommunication in the Mishnah !
34.66: And where are the twenty-four places to be found?
34.67: R. Joshua b. Levi compares one thing with another, but R. Eleazar does not.
34.68: The bearers of the bier and they who relieve them.
34.70: We should not carry out a body [for burial] near the time of reading the Shema' ; but if they have commenced to do so, we should not stop them.
34.72: For lo, Rab Joseph was borne out near the time of reading the Shema' !
34.73: With a highly esteemed man it is different
34.74: Such as are before the bier and stich as are behind it.
34.76: Those who are occupied with the funeral oration at the time when the body is lying before them should slip away one by one and read the Shema'; but if the body is not present, they sit and read the Shema' and the orator sits in silence ; they stand and say the Tefillah, and he justifies the divine decree, saying :
34.77: "Lord of the Universe, I have often sinned before Thee, and Thou hast not exacted punishment from me for one in a thousand. May it be Thy will, O Lord our God, to repair our breaches and the breaches of all Thy people, the house of Israel, in mercy."
34.79: A man ought not to speak thus ; for R. Simeon b. Lakish said, and it has been similarly taught in the name of R. Jose :
34.80: A man should not open his mouth to Satan.
34.82: What is the Scriptural authority for this ? As it is said,
34.83: "We should have been as Sodom" (Is. i. 9) ; and what did the prophet reply to them? "Hear the word of the Lord, ye rulers of Sodom" (ibid. v. 10).
34.84: Having buried the dead and returned, etc.
34.85: If they are able to begin and finish the whole, yes ; but if only one paragraph
34.86: or one verse, are they not [to commence it]?
34.88: Having buried the dead and returned, if they are able to begin and complete even one paragraph or one verse [they should commence it] !
34.90: if they are able to begin and finish one paragraph or even one verse, before reaching the row, they should begin ; but if not, they should not commence it.

35.0: As for those who stand in the row, etc.
35.2: The row which looks upon the inner  space is exempt [from reading the Shema']; but the row which does not look upon the inner space is under the obligation. R. Judah says :
35.3: Those who come out of regard for the mourner are exempt ; but those who come on their own account are under the obligation.
35.4: Rab Judah said in the name of Rab :
35.5: Who finds diverse kinds in his garment must divest himself thereof even in the street. What is the reason ? [As it is said,] "There is no wisdom nor understanding nor counsel against the Lord" (Prov. xxi. 30) — i.e. wherever the Divine Name is liable to be profaned, we pay no respect to a teacher.
35.7: Having buried the dead, and on returning there are two paths before them one clean, the other unclean, if [the mourner] enters the clean path, they follow him there, and if he enters the unclean path, they follow him there out of respect for him!
35.10: "There is no wisdom nor understanding nor counsel against the Lord"!
35.11: R. Abba explained that it speaks here of a Bet Peras which is declared unclean by the Rabbis.
35.12: For Rab Judah said in the name of Samuel :
35.13: One may blow upon a Bet Peras [to see whether there are any bones ; and if there are none] he may walk on it.
35.14: And Rab Judah b. Ashe said in the name of Rab :
35.15: A Bet Peras which has been much trodden under foot is to be regarded as clean.
35.16: Come and hear : R. Eleazar b. Sadok said :
35.17: We used to leap upon the coffins of the dead to meet the kings of Israel, and not only to meet kings of Israel do they so permit, but even to meet the kings of other nations ; for if he be worthy, he will discern between the kings of Israel and the kings of other nations.
35.20: "There is no wisdom nor understanding nor counsel against the Lord" !
35.21: It is in accord with the opinion of Raba, who said :
35.22: According to the teaching of the Torah, "a tent" — i.e. anything which contains a hollow space at least a handbreadth in extent — forms a partition against uncleanness, but if it does not contain a hollow space at least a handbreadth in extent it does not form such a partition ; and most coffins have a hollow space a handbreadth in extent. But the Rabbis decreed that even those which have this hollow space [should defile] because of those which have it not ; but for the purpose of paying honour to royalty, the Rabbis do not enforce this decree.
35.24: Great is the duty of honouring one's fellow-creatures, since it sets aside a prohibition enjoined by the Torah.
35.27: "There is no wisdom nor understanding nor counsel against the Lord" !
35.28: Rab b. Shaba explained it in the presence of Rab Kahana as referring to the prohibition, "Thou shalt not turn aside from the sentence which they shall declare unto thee" (Deut. xvii. 11).
35.30: for is not the prohibition, "Thou shalt not turn aside" enjoined by the Torah!
35.32: A great man having expressed an opinion, you should not laugh at him. We base the authority for all the dicta of the Rabbis upon the prohibition, "Thou shalt not turn aside" ; but for the duty of honouring a fellow-creature the Rabbis give permission.
35.34: [It is written :] "And hide thyself from them" (ibid. xxii. 1); i.e. there are times when thou mayest hide thyself from them, and times when thou must not hide thyself from them.
35.35: How can this be? If he was a Kohen and [the straying animal] was in a cemetery ; or he was an Elder and it was derogatory to his dignity [to be seen leading the animal back] ; or his work was more important than his neighbour's — therefore it is said,
35.39: "There is no wisdom nor understanding nor counsel against the Lord"!
35.40: It is different here ; for it is written,
35.42: May one, then, conclude from this?
35.43: We cannot draw an inference about a prohibition from a case involving only financial loss.
35.45: [It is written,] "Or for his sister" (Num. vi. 7). What has this teaching to tell us ?
35.46: Supposing he were on his way to sacrifice the Paschal lamb or circumcise his son, and he heard that one of his relatives had died, it is possible [to think] that he should turn back and render himself unclean ; say, then, he shall not make himself unclean.
35.47: It is possible [to think] that in the same way that [under these conditions] he may not make himself unclean for his relatives, he may not make himself unclean for a Met Miswah,
35.48: therefore there is a teaching to tell us
35.49: "or for his sister" ; i.e. "for his sister" he may not render himself unclean,

36.0: but for a Met Miswah he must defile himself. Why should this be so?
36.2: "There is no wisdom nor understanding nor counsel against the Lord"!
36.3: It is different here; because it is written "for his sister." May one, then, conclude from this ?
36.4: Sit and do nothing is different.
36.6: How were our predecessors different from us that miracles occurred for them but not for us?
36.7: Is it a question of learning ? In the time of Rab Judah, their whole study was limited to the Order "Damages," whereas we study the six Orders;
36.9: the paragraph in Mishnah 'Uksin : "If a woman presses vegetables in a pot" (some declare it was the paragraph : "Olives which are pressed with their leaves are clean"), he said,
36.10: "We see here the conflicts of Rab and Samuel," whereas we study 'Uksin in thirteen lessons !
36.11: Yet, with respect to Rab Judah, when he took off one of his shoes, the rain descended ; but we afflict our souls and cry aloud and there is none that takes notice of us !
36.13: Our predecessors jeopardised their lives for the sanctification of the Name, but we do not.
36.14: As it once happened with Rab Adda b. Ahabah who noticed a heathen woman wearing a karbalta in the street; thinking that she was an Israelite, he went up to her and tore it from off her.
36.15: It was then discovered that she was a heathen, and they fined him four hundred Zuzim.
36.21: "Matun, Matun, is worth four hundred Zuzim."
36.22: Rah Giddel had the habit of going and sitting at the gate of the baths, saying [to the women as they entered],
36.25: "Is not the master afraid of [the promptings of] the evil impulse ?"
36.27: "They are in my eyes like white geese."
36.29: of going and sitting at the gates of the baths, saying,
36.30: "When the daughters of Israel leave, let them gaze upon me, and they will have children as beautiful as I."
36.32: "Art thou not afraid of the Evil Eye?"
36.34: "I am come from the seed of Joseph against whom the Evil Eye had no power ; for it is written,
36.35: 'Joseph is a fruitful vine, a fruitful vine by a fountain' (Gen. xlix. 22) ; and R. Abbahu said:
36.36: Read not 'ale 'ayin 'by a fountain' but 'ole 'ayin 'overcoming the [Evil] Eye'."
36.37: R. Jose b. Hannina said : From the following passage [did R. Johanan derive his reason] :
36.38: "And let them grow [weyidgu] into a multitude in the midst of the earth" (ibid. xlviii. 16) ; i.e. as the fishes [dagim] in the sea are covered by the water and the Evil Eye has no power over them,
36.40: the Evil Eye has no power over the seed of Joseph. Or if thou wilt, say that the eye which desired not to partake of what did not belong to it cannot be influenced by the Evil Eye.
36.41: MISHNA: Women, slaves and minors are exempt from kriat shema.

37.0: [MISHNA CONT.] and from the [mitzva of] tefillin and they are obligated in prayer and in mezuzah and in [the mitzva of] grace after meals:
37.1: GEMARA Why are the reading of the Shema' and Tefillin different [from the others] ?
37.2: Because they are commands the observance of which depends upon a certain point of time, and women are exempt from all commands of this class. Tefillah, Mezuzah and Grace after meals, being commands the observance of which does not depend upon a certain point of time, are obligatory upon women. That the reading of the Shema' [is not obligatory upon women] is self-evident, because it is a command the observance of which depends upon a certain point of time, and women are exempt from all commands of this class!
37.3: [Why, then, does the Mishnah mention it ?]
37.4: Thou mightest say that since it contains a reference to the Kingdom of Heaven [it should be read by women] ; therefore it informs us [they are exempt].
37.8: that since Tefillin are to be compared with Mezuzah [they should be obligatory upon women] ; therefore it informs us [they are exempt].
37.9: But they are under the obligation of Tefillah ;
37.12: But thou mightest say that since it is written thereby, "Evening and morning and at noonday" (Ps. lv. 18), it is like a command the observance of which depends upon a certain point of time [and women are exempt]; therefore it informs us [the obligation is theirs].
37.15: since it is to be compared with the study of Torah, [being exempt from the latter they are likewise exempt from the former] ; therefore it informs us [that women have the duty of fixing the Mezuzah].
37.19: since it is written thereby, "When the Lord shall give you in the evening flesh to eat and in the morning bread to the full" (Exod. xvi. 8), it is like a command the observance of which depends upon a certain point of time [and women are exempt]; therefore it informs us [that it is obligatory].
37.21: Women are under the obligation to recite the Sanctitication  of the [Sabbath] day by the ordinance of the Torah.
37.23: since it is a command the observance of which is dependent upon a certain point of time, and women are exempt from all commands of this class !
37.25: [The Sanctification by women] is a Rabbinical ordinance.
37.27: But lo, [Rab Adda] mentioned it was "by the ordinance of the Torah" !
37.28: And further, let us make all commands [of this class] obligatory upon women by Rabbinic authority !
37.30: [the correct reason why they have to "sanctify" the Sabbath is because] the Scriptures declare, "Remember the Sabbath day to keep it holy" (Exod. xx. 8) and "Observe the Sabbath to keep it holy" (Deut. v. 12) — everyone who has to "observe" must likewise "remember"; and since women must "observe," so must they "remember."
37.32: Is the recital of the Grace after meals by women an ordinance from the Torah or the Rabbis ?
37.33: What is the point at issue ? It is whether they have the power of exempting others.
37.34: It is quite right if thou sayest it is from the Torah ; then one who is enjoined by the Torah [to keep the observance] comes and exempts one [whose observance is likewise commanded] by the Torah. But if thou sayest it is from the Rabbis, then it is not a compulsory observance, and one who is not under the obligation [to keep the observance] cannot exempt others.
37.36: Come and hear : It has indeed been stated :
37.37: A son [who is a minor] may say Grace for his father, a slave for his master, and a woman for her husband ;
37.39: May a curse alight upon the man for whom his wife or his son says Grace !
37.40: This is quite right if thou sayest that it is from the Torah; then one who is enjoined by the Torah [to keep the observance] comes and exempts one [whose observance is likewise commanded] by the Torah. But if thou sayest it is from the Rabbis, then one who is enjoined by the Rabbis [to keep the observance] comes and exempts one [whose observance is commanded] by the Torah !
37.41: Also, according to thy reason, is a minor under the obligation [to say Grace] ?
37.42: Nay, with what case are we here dealing ? With one who, for instance, has eaten the minimum quantity ordained by the Rabbis [as making the saying of Grace necessary] ; and thus one who is enjoined by the Rabbis [to say Grace] comes and exempts one [whose observance is likewise commanded] by the Rabbis.
37.43: Rab 'Awira expounded (sometimes he said it in the name of R. Ammi and sometimes in the name of R. Assi) :
37.44: The ministering angels spake before the Holy One, blessed be He,
37.45: "Lord of the universe ! It is written of Thee in Thy Torah, 'Who regardeth not persons nor taketh reward' (Deut. x. 17); but dost Thou not regard the person of Israel, for it is written,
37.46: 'The Lord lift up His countenance upon thee' (Num. vi. 26)?"
37.48: "And should I not regard the person of Israel,
37.49: for whom I wrote in the Torah, 'And thou shalt eat and be satisfied and bless the Lord thy God' (Deut. viii. 10), but they are strict with themselves [and bless] even with a quantity of food equal in size to an olive or an egg?"
37.50: MISHNAH A Ba'al Keri meditates upon [the wording of the Shema'] in his heart and says neither the benediction before nor after.
37.51: At his meal, he says the Grace after [in his heart] but not the Grace before.
37.53: He says Grace before and after.
37.55: [The statement of the Mishnah] means to say that meditation is the equivalent of speech ;
37.56: for if it enter thy mind that it is not the equivalent of speech,
37.57: why should he meditate! How is it then? Meditation is the equivalent of speech. Let him, then, utter the words with his lips !
37.58: No ; it is as we find at Mount Sinai.
37.60: Meditation is not the equivalent of speech ;
37.61: for if it enter thy mind that it is the equivalent of speech, let him utter the words with his lips !
37.62: How is it then ? Meditation is not the equivalent of speech. Why, then, should he meditate?
37.64: So that the whole world should not be engaged upon the reading of the Shema', whereas he sits idle.
37.65: Then let him read some other chapter !
37.67: With that wherewith the Community is engaged [should he like-wise be engaged].

38.0: But Tefillah is also a matter with which the  Community is engaged, and there is a Mishnaic teaching:
38.1: If he was standing in the Tefillah and recollected that he is a Ba'al Keri, he should not interrupt [his prayer] but shorten it. The reason is because he had already commenced it ; hence, if he had not commenced it, he should not do so !
38.2: It is different with Tefillah, because it contains no reference to the Kingdom of Heaven. But in the Grace after meals there is also no reference to the Kingdom of Heaven, and yet our Mishnah declares :
38.3: At his meal, he says the Grace after but not the Grace before !
38.5: but the reading of the Shema' and the Grace after meals are ordained by the Torah, whereas Tefillah is ordained by the Rabbis.
38.7: Whence is it that Grace after meals is ordained by the Torah? As it is said,
38.8: "And thou shalt eat and be satisfied and bless the Lord thy God" (Deut. viii. 10).
38.9: Whence is it that the benediction to be uttered before reading the Torah is ordained by the Torah? As it is said,
38.10: "For I will proclaim the name of the Lord : ascribe ye greatness unto our God" (ibid. xxxii. 3).
38.12: We derive the injunction to utter a benediction after reading the Torah from the Grace after meals by a fortiori argument, and the injunction to say Grace before meals from the benediction over the reading of the Torah by a similar method of reasoning.
38.13: We derive the injunction to utter a benediction after reading the Torah from the Grace after meals by a fortiori argument :
38.14: If a meal which requires no benediction before it requires one after it, is it not right that the reading of the Torah, which does require a benediction before it, should require one after it !
38.15: And we derive the injunction to say Grace after meals from the benediction over the reading of the Torah by a similar method of reasoning :
38.16: If the reading of the Torah, which requires no benediction after it, requires one before it, is it not right that a meal, which does require a benediction after it, should require one before it !
38.17: One can, however, object to this reasoning :
38.18: Why is Grace answered squired after a meal? Because it has been enjoyed. Why is a benediction required over the reading of the Torah ? Because it is life eternal.
38.19: Moreover there is a teaching in our Mishnah:
38.20: At his meal, he says the Grace after but not the Grace before !
38.23: If one is in doubt whether he has read the Shema' or not, he does not repeat it ; if he is in doubt whether he said "True and firm" or not, he does repeat it.
38.24: What is the reason ? Because the reading of the Shema' is ordained by the Rabbis, but saying "True and firm" by the Torah.
38.26: "When thou liest down and when thou risest up" (Deut. vi. 7)!
38.28: That is written with reference to words of Torah.
38.29: We have a teaching in our Mishnah :
38.30: A Ba'al Keri meditates upon [the wording of the Shema'] in his heart and says neither the benediction before nor after. At his meal, he says the Grace after [in his heart] but not the Grace before.
38.31: But if it enter thy mind that "True and firm" is ordained by the Torah, then he should say the benediction after the Shema' !
38.32: And for what reason should he say this benediction ? If because it contains a reference to the Exodus from Egypt, he has already mentioned that in the Shema' !
38.33: Then let him say this benediction and there will be no necessity for the other !
38.34: The reading of the Shema' is more important because it contains two things.
38.36: If one is in doubt whether he has read the Shema' or not, he should repeat it ; but if he is in doubt whether he has said the Tefillah or not, he need not repeat it.
38.38: Would that a man could pray all day.
38.39: Rab Judah also said in the name of Samuel :
38.40: If a man was standing in the Tefillah and recollected that he had already said it, he must stop even in the middle of a benediction.
38.42: For lo, Rab Nahman has said :
38.43: When we were at the school of Rabbah b. Abbuha we asked him, "How is it with those young disciples who made a mistake and said the week-day Tefillah on the Sabbath, should they finish it?"
38.45: "They should finish the whole of that benediction" !
38.47: In the latter instance, he was at any rate under the obligation [to say the Tefillah] and the Rabbis did not trouble him out of regard for the Sabbath ; but in the former case, he had already said the prayer.
38.48: Rab Judah also said in the name of Samuel :
38.49: Should one have already said the Tefillah and then enter a Synagogue and find the Congregation saying it, if he is able to add anything new to the prayer, he may repeat it ; but if not, he should not repeat it.
38.50: It was necessary [to have both this and the former teaching of Rab Judah in the name of Samuel] ;
38.51: for if he had given us only the first teaching, [we might have argued,] To whom does this apply ? To a person who said the Tefillah alone and is repeating it alone ;

39.0: or to a person who said the Tefillah with the Congregation and is repeating it with the Congregation ; but having said it alone, he is like one who has not prayed when he finds himself with a Congregation ! Therefore he informs us [that having once said the Tefillah in private, there is no need to say it a second time with a Congregation], And if he had only given us the latter teaching,
39.1: [we might have supposed that he does not say the Tefillah a second time with the Congregation] because he has not actually commenced it; but in the former circumstance, having commenced it, therefore he should not [interrupt it on discovering his error] ! Consequently it was necessary [to have the first teaching of Rab Judah].
39.3: Should one enter a Synagogue and find the Congregation saying the Tefillah, if he is able to commence and finish before the Precentor reaches the words "We give thanks unto Thee," he should say the Tefillah; but if not, he should not say it.
39.5: If he is able to commence and finish before the Precentor reaches the "Sanctification," he should say the Tefillah ; but if not, he should not say it.
39.7: The former is of the opinion
39.9: whereas the other is of the opinion
39.10: that the individual does not say it.
39.11: And similarly said Rab Adda b. Ahabah :
39.12: Whence is it that the individual does not say the "Sanctification"? As it is said,
39.13: "But I will be hallowed among the children of Israel" (Lev. xxii. 32) — i.e. anything which comes under the heading of "Sanctification" cannot be without a minimum of ten.
39.15: As Rabbanai, the brother of R. Hiyya b. Abba, taught :
39.16: We draw an analogy from the occurrence of the word "among."
39.18: "But I will be hallowed among the children of Israel" and it is written elsewhere
39.19: "Separate yourselves from among this congregation" (Num. xvi. 21). As in the latter circumstance there were ten, so here also there must be
39.21: But everybody agrees that a man must not interrupt [the Tefillah in order to make the responses to the "Sanctification" or "We give thanks"].
39.23: May one interrupt [the Tefillah] to respond, "Let His great name be blessed"?
39.24: When Rab Dimai came [from Palestine] he reported that R. Judah and R. Simeon, disciples of R. Johanan, said:
39.25: For no response may we interrupt [the Tefillah] except for "Let His great name be blessed"; for even one engaged with the study of the Ma'aseh Merkabah must interrupt [to make this response].
39.26: But the Halakah is not in accord with their view.
39.27: R. Judah declares : He says Grace before and after.
39.28: That is to say that R. Judah is of the opinion that a Ba'al Keri is permitted to study Torah.
39.29: But lo, R. Joshua b. Levi has said :
39.30: Whence is it that a Ba'al Keri is forbidden to study Torah? As it is said,
39.31: "Thou shalt make them known unto thy children and thy children's children" (Deut. iv. 9)
39.33: "The day that thou stoodest before the Lord thy God in Horeb" (ibid. v. 10) — as those who were Ba'al Keri were forbidden [in the assembly at Horeb], so are they forbidden [to occupy themselves with Torah].
39.35: R. Judah does not draw deductions from juxtaposition, but Rab Joseph has said :
39.36: Even one who does not draw deductions from juxtaposition in any other part of the Torah does so in the Book of Deuteronomy;
39.37: and R. Judah who does not draw deductions from juxtaposition in any other part of the Torah does so in the Book of Deuteronomy.
39.38: How do we know that he does not use this method in any other part of the Torah ? For there is a teaching : Ben 'Azzai said :
39.39: It is stated, "Thou shalt not suffer a sorceress to live" (Exod. xxii. 17) and it continues,
39.40: "Whosoever lieth with a beast shall surely be put to death" (ibid. v. 18);
39.41: [the Rabbis] connect the two laws to infer that as the one who lieth with a beast is put to death by stoning, so also is the sorceress put to death by stoning.
39.43: Because the two matters are in juxtaposition, shall we inflict stoning upon the person [condemned for sorcery] !
39.45: they that divine by a ghost or a familiar spirit come under the category of sorcerers; and why are they particularised? To draw an analogy and teach thee
39.46: that as these are punished by stoning, so also is the sorceress.
39.47: How do we know that R. Judah does draw deductions from juxta-position in the Book of Deuteronomy? For there is a teaching: R. Eliezer says :
39.48: A man may marry one outraged or seduced by his father, or one outraged or seduced by his son.
39.49: R. Judah prohibits a man to marry one outraged or seduced by his father.
39.50: Rab Giddel asked in the name of Rab :
39.51: What is R. Judah 's reason? Because it is written,
