43.55: Rab Joseph b. Rab Nehunyah asked Rab Judah:
43.56: May a man place his Tefillin beneath his pillow [at night] ?
43.57: About placing them at the foot of the bed is no question, since that would involve disrespectful treatment; but I ask about placing them beneath his pillow — how is it ?
43.59: It is allowed, even if his wife be with him.
43.61: A man may not place his Tefillin at the foot of the bed because it would be disrespectful, but he may place them beneath his pillow.
43.62: Should, however, his wife be with him, it is forbidden ;
43.63: but if there is a place three handbreadths above or below, he may place them beneath his pillow !
43.64: The refutation of Samuel remains unanswered.
43.66: Although it is stated that the refutation of Samuel remained unanswered, nevertheless the Halakah is in accord with his view.

44.0: The more one guards them [against  contemptuous treatment] the better.
44.1: Where, then, should one place them?
44.3: Between the mattress and the bolster, where he does not lay his head.
44.5: He should place them in a bag under his pillow !
44.6: Yes, if he leaves the top of the bag protruding outside [the pillow].
44.7: Bar Kappara used to tie them in the bed-curtain, leaving the cases of the Tefillin outside.
44.8: Rab Shesha b. Rab Iddi used to place them upon a stool and spread a cloth over them.
44.9: Rab Hamnuna b. Rab Joseph said :
44.10: On one occasion I was standing before Raba, and he said to me,
44.12: and I found them between the mattress and the bolster, where he did not lay his head ; and I knew that it was the day of bathing and he had done this for the purpose of teaching us the Halakah for practice.
44.13: Rab Joseph b. Rab Nehunyah asked Rab Judah :
44.14: How is it when two sleep in one bed — does one turn his face away and read the Shema' and the other act likewise?
44.16: [That is so] even if his wife is with him.
44.18: [Samuel mentions] his wife, but is it not the more necessary to mention [the case when he is with] somebody else?
44.20: his wife is like part of himself, whereas another is not like part of himself!
44.22: If two sleep in one bed, one turns his face away and reads [the Shema'] and the other acts likewise.
44.24: One who sleeps in a bed with his children or members of his household by his side should not read the Shema' unless a sheet separates between them ;
44.25: but if his children or the members of his household are minors, then he is permitted [to read the Shema' without such separation]!
44.26: This is quite right according to Rab Joseph and there is no contradiction [between the two teachings],
44.27: the first referring to his wife, the second to somebody else.
44.28: But with Samuel's view there is a contradiction.
44.30: Is it right according to Rab Joseph's opinion?
44.31: For lo, there is a teaching :
44.32: If a man sleeps in a bed with his children or the members of his household, he may not read the Shema' unless a sheet separates between them !
44.33: What, then, is there for thee to say ? There are Tannaim [who are at variance] on Rab Joseph's view of the question of the wife, and there are also Tannaim [who are at variance] on my view.
44.35: "He turns his face away and reads the Shema'" —
44.36: but their buttocks will be in contact !
44.37: This supports the opinion of Rab Huna who said that
44.38: with buttocks there is no concern on the score of nakedness.
44.39: It is possible to say that the following teaching is a support of Rab Huna's opinion, viz. :
44.40: A woman may sit and cut off the Hallah while she is naked,
44.41: because she is able to cover her nakedness with the ground; but it is not so with a man.
44.42: Rab Nahman b. Isaac explained this [as applying only to a case where] for instance, her nakedness is sunk in the ground.
44.44: "If his children or members of his household are minors, it is permitted." Up to what age?
44.46: With females, three years and one day;
44.47: with a male, nine years and one day.
44.49: With females, eleven years and one day ; with a male, twelve years and one day — i.e. with both of them until the age when "the breasts were fashioned and the hair grown" (Ezek. xvi. 7).
44.51: Raba said above, "Although the refutation of Samuel's view remained unanswered, the Halakah is in accord with him" ; how is it here?
44.53: Wilt thou weave all these things in one web?
44.55: where it is said, it is said ; and where it is not said, it is not said.
44.57: How is it if a hair protruded from his garment ?
44.58: The latter exclaimed : Hair is hair.
44.60: A handbreadth of a woman [if exposed] is nakedness.
44.62: Is it a question of gazing upon her? Behold Rab Sheshet said :
44.63: Why do the Scriptures enumerate the female ornaments worn outside together with those worn under the garments ? This is to tell thee that
44.64: whoever gazes upon the little finger of a woman is as though he had gazed at her nakedness !
44.66: [the statement of R. Isaac refers] to his wife and for the purpose of reading the Shema'.
44.68: The calf of a woman's leg is to be regarded as nakedness; as it is said, "Uncover the leg, pass through the rivers" (Is. xlvii. 2) and it continues, "Thy nakedness shall be uncovered, yea, thy shame shall be seen" (Is. xlvii. 3).
44.70: A woman's voice is to be regarded as nakedness ; as it is said, "For sweet is thy voice, and thy countenance is comely" (Cant. ii. 14).
44.72: A woman's hair is to be regarded as nakedness; as it is said, "Thy hair is as a flock of goats" (ibid. iv. 1).
44.74: I have seen Rabbi hang up his Tefillin.
44.76: He who hangs up his Tefillin will himself be hanged !
44.78: "And thy life shall hang in doubt before thee" (Deut. xxviii. 66) — this refers to one who hangs up his Tefillin !
44.79: There is no contradiction ; for this means one who hangs them up by the thongs, whereas Rabbi hung them up by the case.
44.80: or if thou wilt I can say that
44.81: whether to hang them by the thong or case is forbidden ; and when Rabbi hung them up it was in a bag.
44.82: If this be so, what need was there to mention it ?
44.84: Thou mightest have said that the Tefillin require laying down like a scroll of the Torah ; therefore he informs us.
44.86: I have seen Rabbi belch, yawn, sneeze, expectorate,

45.0: and put his garment in order [during his prayer], but he would not rewrap himself; and when he yawned, he would place his hand upon his chin.
45.2: He who makes his voice heard during prayer is of the small of faith;
45.3: he who raises his voice when praying is of the prophets of falsehood; he who belches and yawns [during prayer] is of the proud of spirit;
45.4: he who sneezes during prayer should regard it as a bad omen,
45.6: it is an indication that he is contemptible;
45.7: he who expectorates during prayer is as though he expectorated in the presence of the King !
45.8: It is quite right that there is no difficulty in the matter of belching or yawning,
45.9: for here it was an involuntary act and [the denunciation just quoted] refers to one who does it deliberately ; but there is a difficulty
45.10: in the matter of sneezing! No; there is no difficulty;
45.11: for here it was from above, but the latter refers to one who does so from below.
45.13: This thing was taught me in the school of Rab Hamnuna, and is equal in worth to me to all my studies.
45.14: He who sneezes during prayer may regard it as a good omen ; for just as it brings him gratification below [on earth], so will it bring him gratification above.
45.15: But there is a difficulty in the matter of expectoration!
45.17: for it may be [that Rabbi acted] according to the teaching of Rab Judah
45.19: If one is standing in prayer and his spittle collected in his mouth, he may empty it into his Tallit, and if his Tallit is costly, he may empty it into his underwear.
45.20: Rabina was once standing before Rab Ashe [during prayer], and the spittle collected in the latter's mouth, and he expectorated behind him.
45.22: "Does not the master hold the opinion of Rab Judah that one should empty his spittle into his underwear?"
45.25: [The teacher stated above:] "He who makes his voice heard during prayer is of the small of faith."
45.27: This teaching applies only to one who is able to direct his heart when whispering [the words of prayer] ; but if he is unable to do so, he is permitted [to pray aloud].
45.28: And this holds good only of one praying alone ; but with a congregation it would cause disturbance to others.
45.30: Rab Judah because he wished to go up to the land of Israel ; for Rab Judah declared :
45.31: Whoever goes up from Babylon to the land of Israel commits a transgression because of [the injunction] which is stated,
45.32: "They shall be carried to Babylon, and there shall they be, until the day that I remember them, saith the Lord" ( Jer. xxvii. 22).
45.34: I will go and hear some teaching from him at the seminary and then I will depart.
45.35: He went and found a Tanna teaching the following in the presence of Rab Judah :
45.36: If one was standing in the Tefillah and broke wind, he should wait until the odour passes off and then resume the prayer [from where he interrupted it] ;
45.38: If he was standing in the Tefillah and felt the need to break wind, he should step back four cubits and having relieved himself, wait until the odour passes off and then resume his prayer,
45.40: "Lord of the universe ! Thou hast created us with many orifices and vessels. Revealed and known to Thee is our shame and confusion in our lifetime, and in our end we are but worm and vermin";
45.41: he then resumes at the place where he interrupted.
45.43: Had I only come to hear this, it would suffice me.
45.45: If one is sleeping in his cloak and is unable to put forth his head because of the cold, he makes a sort of partition with his cloak around his neck and reads the Shema'.
45.47: [that he makes the partition] by his heart.
45.48: But according to the first Tanna, the heart sees the nakedness [during prayer] !
45.50: when the heart sees the nakedness, it is permitted [to read the Shema'].
45.51: Rab Huna said in the name of R. Johanan:
45.52: If one is walking in filthy courtways [and the time for reading the Shema' arrives], he should place his hand over his mouth and read the Shema'.
45.55: if R. Johanan had told me that himself, I would not have listened to him !"
45.56: Another version is : Rabbah b. Bar Hannah said in the name of R. Joshua b. Levi :
45.57: If one is walking in filthy courtways, he should place his hand over his mouth and read the Shema'.
45.59: "By God ! if R. Joshua b. Levi had told me that himself, I would not have listened to him !"
45.60: But did Rab Huna really say that?
45.62: A disciple of the wise is forbidden to stand in a filthy place, because it is impossible for him to stand anywhere without meditating upon Torah!
45.63: There is no contradiction ; the latter refers to standing still, the former to walking.
45.64: And did R. Johanan really say what is attributed to him?
45.65: For lo, Rabbah b. Bar Hannah has said in the name of R. Johanan :
45.66: One is permitted to meditate anywhere upon words of Torah except the bath-house and privy !
45.67: And shouldest thou urge that here also one refers to standing and the other to walking,
45.69: because R. Abbahu once followed R. Johanan and he was reading the Shema', but when he reached the filthy courtways he lapsed into silence.
45.73: "If thou hast waited sufficient time to finish the whole, return to the commencement" !
45.74: This is what R. Johanan meant to say to him,
45.75: "As for me, I do not hold [that the reading of the Shema' should be interrupted] ; but as for thee, since thou dost hold that view, if thou hast waited sufficient time to finish the whole, return to the commencement."
45.76: There is a teaching in agreement with Rab Huna and a teaching in agreement with Rab Hisda.
45.77: There is a teaching in agreement with Rab Huna :
45.78: If he was walking in filthy courtways, he should place his hand over his mouth and read the Shema'.
45.79: There is a teaching in agreement with Rab Hisda :
45.80: If he was walking in filthy courtways, he should not read the Shema' ;
45.81: and not only so, but if he was reading it and entered [such a place], he should stop.
45.82: If he did not stop, what then?
45.83: R. Meyasha, the grandson of R. Joshua b. Levi, said :
45.84: Of him the Scriptures state, "Wherefore I gave them also statutes that were not good, and ordinances whereby they should not live" (Ezek. xx. 25).
45.86: [Of him the Scriptures state], "Woe unto them that draw iniquity with cords of vanity" (Is. v. 18).
45.87: Rab Adda b. Ahabah said : From the following,
45.88: "Because he hath despised the word of the Lord" (Num. xv. 31).
45.89: But if he does stop, what is his reward?
45.90: R. Abbahu said : Of him the Scriptures state,
45.91: "Through this thing ye shall prolong your days" (Deut. xxxii. 47).
45.93: If his cloak was girded about his loins, he is permitted to read the Shema'.
45.94: There is a teaching to the same effect :
45.95: If his cloak of stuff, or skin, or sackcloth was girded about his loins, he is permitted to read the Shema' ;

46.0: but for the Tefillah [it is not permitted] until he covers his heart.
46.2: If a man forgot and entered a privy wearing his Tefillin, he should place his hand over them until he finishes. Until he finishes,
46.4: Nay, it is as Rab Nahman b. Isaac has said :
46.5: Until he finishes the first discharge.
46.6: Let him, then, stop at once and stand up!
46.7: [No,] because of [the saying of] Rabban Simeon b. Gamaliel ;
46.8: for there is a teaching : Rabban Simeon b. Gamaliel says :
46.9: If the fecal discharge is kept back
46.10: it causes dropsy, and if the fluid in the urinary duct is kept back it causes jaundice.
46.12: If there be filth upon his body, or his hand is placed within a privy,
46.14: It is permitted to read the Shema' ;
46.16: It is forbidden to read it.
46.18: What is Rab Huna's reason ? Because it is written, "Let everything that hath breath praise the Lord" (Ps. el. 6).
46.20: It is forbidden to read the Shema' [in such circumstances] —
46.21: what is the reason ? Because it is written, "All my bones shall say, Lord who is like unto Thee" (ibid. xxxv. 10).
46.23: If there is a foul odour for which there is a cause [present], Rab Huna said :
46.24: A man should remove himself a distance of four cubits and read the Shema'.
46.26: He should remove himself a distance of four cubits from the place where the odour ceases and read the Shema'.
46.27: There is a teaching in agreement with Rab Hisda :
46.28: A man should not read the Shema' opposite the excrement of a human being, or of dogs, or pigs, or poultry ; nor opposite the filth of a dunghill which gives forth a bad odour.
46.29: If there be a place ten cubits higher or lower, he sits down at the side and reads the Shema'; but if not, he removes himself as far as he can see it.
46.30: The same rule applies to the Tefillah.
46.31: "If there is a foul odour for which there is a cause [present], he removes himself a distance of four cubits from the place of the odour and reads the Shema'."
46.32: Raba said : The Halakah is not in agreement with this teaching in all these cases, but according to the following teaching :
46.33: A man should not read the Shema' opposite the excrement of human beings, nor opposite that of pigs or dogs when he has placed skins therein.
46.35: How is it with a foul odour which has no [material] cause?
46.37: Come and behold the mats in the school of Rab, on which some are sleeping while others are studying.
46.38: But this refers only to words of Torah, not to the reading of the Shema'.
46.39: And even of words of Torah this is not said except [when the bad odour is caused] by another ; but if he himself is the cause, he must not [even study until the odour has passed off].
46.40: It has been reported : If manure is being carried past a person,
46.42: It is permitted to read the Shema' ;
46.44: It is prohibited to read it.
46.45: Abbai said : Whence do I derive my opinion ? For there is a Mishnaic teaching :
46.46: If a ritually unclean person is standing under a tree and a person who is ritually clean passes by him, the latter also becomes defiled. If, however, a person ritually clean is standing under a tree and an unclean person passes by, the former remains in his state of purity; but should [the unclean person] remain standing there, then the former becomes unclean.
46.47: The same law holds good with a stone which has become infected.
46.48: And Raba? He can tell thee :
46.49: In this latter circumstance the criterion is a fixed place ; for it is written,
46.50: "He shall dwell alone ; without the camp shall his dwelling be" (Lev. xiii. 46). But here the All-merciful declared,
46.51: "Therefore shall the camp be holy" (Deut. xxiii. 15), and behold that is not so.
46.53: A pig's snout is to be regarded as passing manure [for the purpose of reading the Shema'].
46.55: No; it is necessary [to mention it], because even if it just came up out of the river [it is to be so considered].
46.57: If one is uncertain whether excrement is present, it is forbidden [to read the Shema'].
46.58: If one is uncertain whether urine is present, it is permitted.
46.59: Another version is : Rab Judah said :
46.60: If one is uncertain whether excrement is in the room, it is permitted [to read it], but by an ash-heap it is forbidden.
46.61: If one is uncertain whether urine is present, even by an ash-heap it is permitted.
46.62: His opinion agrees with that of Rab Hamnuna who said :
46.63: The Torah only forbids [the Shema' to be read] by fecal matter. He is also in agreement with
46.65: It is written "Thou shalt have a place also without the camp, whither thou shalt go forth abroad" (Deut. xxiii. 13) and it continues,
46.66: "And thou shalt have a paddle among thy weapons ; and it shall be when thou sittest down abroad, thou shalt dig therewith, and shalt turn back and cover that which cometh from thee" (ibid. 5:14) —
46.67: how is this? The latter verse refers to the major natural function, the former to the minor.
46.68: Infer, then, that the Torah forbids [the Shema' to be read] near to urine only when it is by fecal matter ;
46.69: but if it has fallen upon the ground, it is permitted [by the Torah], but the Rabbis have decreed against it. Have the Rabbis decreed against it ? When it is certain [that urine is there] ; but if there is a doubt, they do not decree against it.
46.70: Where it is certain [that urine is present], how long [must one wait before it is allowed to read the Shema' there] ?
46.71: Rab Judah said in the name of Samuel :
46.72: As long as the ground is sufficiently wet to moisten.
46.73: The same reply is given by Rabbah b. Bar Hannah in the name of R. Johanan
46.74: [As long as the ground is sufficiently wet to moisten]
46.76: [As long as the ground is sufficiently wet to moisten]
46.77: Geniba said in the name of Rab :
46.78: As long as the trace thereof can be recognised.
46.81: since in the case of excrement Rab Judah said in the name of Rab :
46.82: When the surface has hardened it is permitted [to read the Shema' thereby], how much more so with urine !
46.84: What seest thou that thou reliest upon this; rely upon that
46.85: which Rabbah b. Rab Huna said in the name of Rab :
46.86: It is forbidden [to read the Shema' near] excrement even when it is like earthenware.
46.88: Rabbah b. Bar Hannah said in the name of R. Johanan;
46.89: When one can throw it to the ground without its crumbling to pieces.
46.91: When one can roll it without its crumbling to pieces.
46.93: I was once standing before Rab Jeremiah of Difti ; he noticed some excrement, and he said to me,
46.94: "See whether its surface has hardened or not."
46.95: Another version is : He said to him,
46.97: How, then, is it with reference to this matter ?
46.99: When the excrement is like earthenware,
46.105: when the excrement is like earthenware it is forbidden ; and similarly with urine, so long as the ground is sufficiently wet to moisten.
46.107: With urine, so long as the ground is wet enough to moisten it is forbidden ; but if it has been absorbed [in the soil] or dried up, it is permitted.
46.108: But is not soaking into the soil like drying up by the sun? [No ;] for as when it dries up, no trace can be recognised, so when it has penetrated into the soil, there must be no trace visible; but if there be such a trace, it is forbidden [to read the Shema' thereby] even though the ground be not sufficiently wet to moisten !
46.109: But against thine own argument, I quote the first clause [of the Baraita brought in objection, viz. :]
46.110: "With urine, so long as the ground is wet enough to moisten it is prohibited" ; hence if the trace of it be recognisable, it is permitted!
46.111: No such deduction can be drawn.
46.112: It is possible to say that [the question under consideration]
46.113: is like [the following discussion of] the Tannaim :
46.114: It is forbidden to read the Shema' by a vessel from which urine has been poured;
46.115: but with urine which has been poured out, if it has been absorbed it is permitted, if it has not been absorbed it is forbidden.
46.117: So long as the earth is sufficiently wet to moisten [it is forbidden].
46.118: What does the first Tanna understand by "absorbed" and "not absorbed" ?
46.119: If it is supposed that "absorbed" means that the earth is not sufficiently wet to moisten, and "not absorbed" means that it can moisten, and R. Jose comes to declare,
46.120: "So long as the earth is sufficiently wet to moisten" it is forbidden, but if the trace thereof can be recognised it is permitted —
46.121: then he is in agreement with the first Tanna!
46.123: by "absorbed" he must mean that no trace can be recognised and by "not absorbed" that the trace is recognisable, and then R. Jose comes to declare,
46.124: "So long as the earth is sufficiently wet to moisten" it is forbidden, but if the trace can be recognised it is permitted.
46.125: No; everybody agrees that so long as the earth can moisten it is forbidden, and  if the trace can be recognised it is permitted ;

47.0: but here the point at issue is that the earth must be so wet as to moisten something which can moisten something else.
47.1: If he had gone down to bathe, should he have time to ascend, clothe himself and read [the Shema'] before sunrise, he must ascend, clothe himself and read.
47.2: It is possible to say that the Mishnah states the law anonymously in agreement with R. Eliezer who declares:
47.3: He may finish it any time until sunrise. Thou mayest even say that it is in agreement with R. Joshua and perhaps it is here like the Wetikin ;
47.5: The Wetikin finish it with the sunrise.
47.6: But if not, he should immerse his body in the water and read.
47.7: But his heart sees his nakedness !
47.8: R. Eleazar (another version : R.Aha b. Abba b. Aha in the name of our master) said :
47.9: The teaching here refers to turbid water which is to be considered like the solid earth, so that his heart does not see his nakedness.
47.11: With clear water, he must sit immersed up to his neck and read [the Shema'],
47.13: he should stir up the water with his foot. But according to the first Tanna his heart sees his nakedness!
47.15: when his heart sees his nakedness, it is permitted [to read].
47.16: But lo, his heel sees his nakedness !
47.18: when his heel sees his nakedness, it is permitted.
47.20: If his heel sees his nakedness, it is permitted [to read the Shema'].
47.21: If the heel touches, Abbai says :
47.22: It is forbidden [to read] ; Raba says :
47.24: So Rab Zebid taught this subject.
47.25: Rab Hinnana b. Rab Ika, however, taught it thus :
47.26: If the heel touches, all agree that it is forbidden [to read] ;
47.27: but if the heel sees [the nakedness], Abbai says :
47.29: It is permitted, because the Torah was not given to the ministering angels.
47.31: If the heel touches, it is forbidden ; if it sees, it is permitted.
47.33: If there be excrement in a transparent vessel, it is permitted to read the Shema' thereby ; if nakedness be in a transparent vessel, it is forbidden to read the Shema' thereby.
47.34: "If there be excrement in a transparent vessel, it is permitted to read the Shema' thereby" ; because with excrement the criterion is whether it is covered : and behold it is covered.
47.35: "If nakedness be in a transparent vessel, it is forbidden to read the Shema' thereby" ; because the All-merciful declared, "That He see no unseemly thing in thee" (Deut. xxiii. 15), and behold it is visible.
47.37: Should the excrement be but a minute quantity, one can nullify it [by covering it] with spittle.
47.39: It must be with thick spittle.
47.41: If excrement be in a hole, he may place his sandal over it and read the Shema'. Mar b. Rabina asked :
47.42: How is it if excrement adheres to his sandal ?
47.45: It is forbidden to read the Shema' in the presence of a naked gentile.
47.46: Why is a gentile specified ? Even by a naked Israelite it is likewise [forbidden] !
47.47: [That it is forbidden with an Israelite is obvious] ; but it was necessary to specify the case of a gentile.
47.49: Since it is written with reference to the gentiles, "Whose flesh is as the flesh of asses" (Ezek. xxiii. 20), argue that [in this matter the naked gentile is to be considered] only like an ass ; therefore he informs us that
47.50: to them also [when exposed] is "nakedness" attributed ; for it is written, "And they saw not their father's nakedness" (Gen. ix. 23).
47.51: He may not immerse himself in evil-smelling water, nor water of soaking, until he has poured [fresh] water therein.
47.52: How much water must he proceed to add?
47.53: Nay, the Mishnah must be read thus:
47.54: He may not immerse himself at all in evil-smelling water, nor in water of soaking ;
47.55: nor [may he read the Shema' by a vessel containing] urine, until he has poured [fresh] water therein, and then he may read it.
47.57: How much water must be poured therein ? Any small quantity.
47.61: The difference of opinion applies only to [where the vessel contained urine and into which water has been poured] afterwards ; but if originally [the vessel contained water, and urine was then poured into it, then all agree] that any small quantity of water will suffice.
47.63: The difference of opinion applies only to [where there was water] originally [and urine had afterwards been added] ; but where [water has to be added] afterwards, all agree that a fourth [of a Log] is necessary.
47.64: Rab Joseph said to his attendant,
47.65: "Bring me a fourth [of a Log] in accordance with the opinion of R. Zakkai."
47.67: It is forbidden to read the Shema' by a bed-pan for excrement or urine, although empty; also by urine until he has poured water therein.
47.68: How much water should he pour therein ?
47.72: whether it be before or behind the bed.
47.74: If it be behind the bed, he may read it ; if it be before the bed he may not, but he removes himself a distance of four cubits and reads.
47.76: Even if the room be the size of a hundred cubits, he may not read until he has removed it or placed it under the bed.
47.78: How did [Rabban Simeon b. Gamaliel] mean, "If [the urine] be behind the bed, he may read forthwith ; if it be before the bed, he removes himself a distance of four cubits and reads" ?
47.80: If it be behind the bed, he removes himself a distance of four cubits and reads ; if it be in front of the bed, he may not read at all !
