60.99: The Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moses,
60.100: "But have they not already seen the miracles and mighty acts which I wrought for Israel by the Red Sea?"
60.102: "Lord of the universe ! They will still be able to say,
60.103: 'Against one king He was able to stand, but not against thirty-one'!"
60.105: Whence is it that the Holy One, blessed be He, afterwards yielded to Moses? As it is said, "And the Lord said, I have forgiven according to thy word" (ibid. v. 20).
60.106: The school of R. Ishmael taught :
60.107: "According to thy word" — the nations of the world will say thus,
60.108: "Happy the disciple to whom his Master yielded."
60.109: "But in very deed, as I live" (ibid. v. 21) —
60.110: Raba said in the name of Rab Isaac :
60.111: This teaches that the Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moses,
60.112: "Moses, thou hast made Me to survive [in the estimation of the peoples] with thy word."
60.114: A man should always recount the praise of the Holy One, blessed be He, and thereafter pray [for his needs].
60.115: Whence have we this? From Moses; for it is written, "And I besought the Lord at that time, saying" (Deut. iii. 23).
60.116: Then it is written, "O Lord God, Thou hast begun to show Thy servant Thy greatness, and Thy strong hand ; for what god is there in heaven or on earth, that can do according to Thy works, and according to Thy mighty acts ?" (ibid. v. 24). And after that it is written, "Let me go over, I pray Thee, and see the good land" etc. (ibid. v. 25).
60.117: (Mnemonic: Deeds, Charity, Offering, Priest, Fast, Lock, Iron.)

61.1: Greater is prayer than good deeds ;
61.2: for thou hast no one greater in good deeds than Moses, our teacher, nevertheless he was only answered through prayer ; as it is said,
61.3: "Speak no more unto Me of this matter" (ibid. v. 26), which is followed by, "Get thee up into the top of Pisgah" (ibid. v. 27).
61.6: What is the reason ? The former [demands the sacrifice] of the person, the latter of money.
61.8: Greater is prayer than sacrifices ; as it is said, "To what purpose is the multitude of your sacrifices unto Me?" (Is. i. 11), and it is written, "And when ye spread forth your hands" (ibid. v. 15).
61.10: A Kohen who has committed murder must not lift up his hands; as it is said, "Your hands are full of blood" (ibid.).
61.12: From the day the Temple was destroyed, the gates of prayer were locked ; as it is said,
61.13: "Yea, when I cry and call for help, He shutteth out my prayer" (Lam. iii. 8). But although the gates of prayer are locked, the gates of tears remain unlocked ; as it is said, "Hear my prayer, O Lord, and give ear unto my cry ; keep not silence at my tears" (Ps. xxxix. 13).
61.15: on a cloudy day, because it is said, "Thou hast covered Thyself with a cloud, so that no prayer can pass through" (Lam. iii. 44).
61.17: From the day the Temple was destroyed, a wall of iron divides between Israel and their Father in Heaven ; as it is said, "And take thou unto thee an iron griddle, and set it for a wall of iron between thee and the city" (Ezek. iv. 3).
61.18: R. Hannin said in the name of R. Hannina :
61.19: Whoever prolongs his prayer, his prayer will not return empty.
61.20: Whence have we this ? From Moses our teacher ; as it is said,
61.21: "And I prayed unto the Lord" (Deut. ix. 26), and it is afterwards written, "[Now I stayed in the mount... forty days and forty nights ;] and the Lord hearkened unto me that time also" (ibid. x. 10).
61.23: For R. Hiyya b. Abba has said in the name of R. Johanan :
61.24: Whoever prolongs his prayer and calculates on it will eventually come to pain of heart ; as it is said,
61.25: "Hope deferred maketh the heart sick" (Prov. xiii. 12). What is his remedy? Let him occupy himself with Torah; as it is said, "But desire fulfilled is a tree of life" (ibid.), and "tree of life" is nothing else than Torah, as it is said, "It is a tree of life to them that lay hold upon it" (Prov. iii. 18)!
61.26: There is no contradiction; the latter teaching refers to one who prolongs his prayer and calculates on it, the former to one who prolongs his prayer without calculating on it.
61.28: If a man sees that he prays and is not answered he should repeat his prayer ; as it is said, "Wait for the Lord ; be strong and let thy heart take courage ; yea, wait thou for the Lord" (Ps. xxvii. 14).
61.29: Our Rabbis have taught: Four things require effort, viz. :
61.30: Torah, good deeds, prayer and worldly occupation.
61.31: Whence is it that Torah and good deeds [require effort] ? As it is said, "Only be strong and very courageous to observe to do according to all the law" (Josh. i. 7) —
61.32: "be strong" in Torah, and "very courageous" in good deeds.
61.33: Whence is it that prayer [requires effort] ? As it is said, "Wait for the Lord ; he strong, and let thy heart take courage; yea, wait thou for the Lord" (Ps. I.c.).
61.34: Whence is it that worldly occupation [requires effort]? As it is said, "Be of good courage, and let us prove strong for our people" etc. (II Sam. 10:12).
61.35: "But Zion said. The Lord hath forsaken me, and the Lord hath forgotten me" (Is. xlix. 14).
61.36: But a woman forsaken is the same as a woman forgotten !
61.37: R. Simeon b. Lakish said : The community of Israel spake before the Holy One, blessed be He,
61.38: "Lord of the universe ! Should a man marry a woman after his first wife, he remembers the deeds of the first ; but Thou hast forsaken me and forgotten me!"
61.39: The Holy One, blessed be He, replied,
61.40: "My daughter, twelve constellations have I created in the firmament, and for each constellation I have created thirty hosts, and for each host I have created thirty legions, and for each legion I have created thirty files, and for each file I have created thirty cohorts, and for each cohort I have created thirty camps, and in each camp I have suspended three hundred and sixty-five thousand myriads of stars, in accordance with the days of the solar year, and all of them have I only created for thy sake ; and yet thou sayest, 'Thou hast forsaken me, Thou hast forgotten me'!"
61.41: "Can a woman forget her sucking child ['ulah]?" (Is. xlix. 15). The Holy One, blessed be He, said,
61.42: "Can I forget the burnt-offerings ['olot] of rams and the firstborn of animals which Thou didst offer to Me in the wilderness?"
61.43: [The community of Israel] spake before Him,
61.44: "Lord of the universe ! Since there is no forgetfulness before the throne of Thy glory, perhaps Thou wilt not forget against me the incident of the Golden Calf!"
61.48: "Lord of the universe! Since there is forgetfulness before the throne of Thy glory, perhaps Thou wilt forget for me the incident at Sinai!"
61.50: "Yet 'the I' will I not forget thee" (ibid.).
61.51: That is the meaning of R. Eleazar's statement in the name of R. Osha'ya :
61.52: What is that which is written, "Yea, 'these' will be forgotten"? That refers to the incident of the Golden Calf; "Yet 'the I' will I not forget thee"? That refers to the incident at Sinai.
61.53: The pious men of old used to wait an hour.
61.56: The Scriptures state, "Happy are they that dwell in Thy house" (Ps. Ixxxiv, 5).
61.57: R. Joshua b. Levi also said :
61.58: He who prays should wait an hour after his prayer ; as it is said, "Surely the righteous shall give thanks unto Thy name, the upright shall dwell in Thy presence" (ibid. cxl. 14).
61.59: There is a teaching to the same effect :
61.60: He who prays should wait an hour before and an hour after his prayer.
61.61: Whence is it [that he should wait an hour] before his prayer? As it is said, "Happy are they that dwell in Thy house."
61.62: Whence is it [that he should wait an hour] after his prayer? As it is said, "Surely the righteous shall give thanks unto Thy name; the upright shall dwell in Thy presence."
61.64: The pious men of old used to wait an hour, pray for an hour, and again wait an hour.
61.65: Since they spent nine hours in the day in connection with prayer, how was their Torah kept up, and how was their work done ?
61.66: But since they were pious, their Torah was preserved and their work was blessed.
61.67: Even when a king greets him, he must not respond.
61.68: Rab Joseph said : This teaching applies only to the Israelite kings ; but for the kings of other peoples he must stop.
61.70: He who prays [the Tefillah] and sees a highway robber or waggon coming towards him should not interrupt but shorten it and step back !
61.72: for this means where it is possible to shorten, he should shorten, but if not, he should interrupt.
61.74: It happened that a pious man was saying the Tefillah by the roadside. A nobleman passed and greeted him ; but he did not respond. The nobleman waited until he had concluded his prayer ;
61.75: and after he had concluded it, he said to him,
61.76: "Good for nothing! Is it not written in your Torah, 'Only take heed to thyself, and keep thy soul diligently' (Deut iv. 9) and 'Take ye therefore good heed unto yourselves' (ibid. 5:15)? When I greeted thee, why didst thou not return my salutation?
61.77: If I had cut off thy head with a sword, who would have demanded thy blood at my hand?"
61.79: "Wait until I shall have conciliated thee with words."
61.81: "If thou hadst been standing before a human king,  and thy friend had greeted thee, wouldst thou have

62.3: "And if thou hadst responded to him, what would they have done to thee?"
62.5: "They would have cut off my head with the sword."
62.7: "May we not use the a fortiori argument :
62.8: If thou standing before a human king, who is here to-day and to-morrow in the grave, actest thus, how much more so I who was standing before the supreme King of kings, the Holy One, blessed be He, Who lives and endures for all eternity?"
62.9: The nobleman was at once conciliated, and the pious man departed for his house in peace.
62.10: And though a serpent is wound round his heel, he must not interrupt.
62.12: This teaching applies only to a serpent, but if it be a scorpion he may interrupt.
62.14: If a man fell into a den of lions, we cannot testify concerning him that he is dead ; but if he fell into a pit of serpents or scorpions, we can so testify !
62.15: It is different in this case, because through the pressure they will injure him.
62.17: If he saw oxen, he may interrupt ; for Rab Osha'ya taught :
62.18: One should remove himself fifty cubits from an ox which has never injured anybody and as far as he can see it from an ox whose owner has been warned of its tendency to gore.
62.19: It has been taught in the name of R. Meir :
62.20: Even when the ox has its head in the [fodder-] basket, go up to the roof, and remove the ladder from under thee.
62.22: This applies only to a black ox in the days of Nisan, because Satan then dances between its horns.
62.24: It happened once in a certain place that there was a lizard that was injuring people.People came and told R. Hanina ben Dosa.
62.28: he [R. Hanina] put his heel over the hole, and the lizard came out, bit him, and died.
62.29: He put it on his shoulder and brought it to the study hall
62.30: He said to them [the people in the study hall]:
62.31: See, my sons, it is not the lizard that kills, it is sin that kills
62.33: Woe is to the man whom a lizard meets, but woe is to the lizard that meets R. Hanina ben Dosa
62.34: MISHNAH We refer to rain in the benediction of "the Revival of the Dead" and the request [for rain] in the benediction of "the Years," and the "Division" in "Thou favourest man with knowledge."
62.36: One should say the last mentioned as a fourth benediction by itself.
62.38: [It is to be included] in the "Thanksgiving."
62.39: GEMARA We refer to rain in the benediction of "the Revival of the Dead."
62.42: Because it is equal to the revival of the dead, therefore they fixed it in the benediction of "the Revival of the Dead."
62.43: And the request [for rain] in the benediction of "the Years."
62.46: Because it is sustenance, therefore they fixed it in the benediction relating to sustenance.
62.47: And the "Division" in "Thou favourest man with knowledge."
62.50: Because it is wisdom, they fixed it in the benediction relating to wisdom.
62.52: Because it refers to the non-holy, therefore they fixed it in the [first] benediction [of the Tefillah] for the week-day.
62.54: Great is knowledge, which is placed at the beginning of the benediction said in the week-day [Tefillah].
62.56: Great is knowledge which is placed between two references to the Divine Name ; as it is said,
62.57: "For a God of knowledge is the Lord" (I Sam. ii. 3).
62.58: It is forbidden to have mercy upon one who does not possess knowledge ; as it is said,
62.59: "For it is a people of no understanding, therefore He that made them will not have compassion upon them" (Is. xxvii. 11).
62.61: Great is the Sanctuary which is placed between two references to the Divine Name; as it is said,
62.62: "...Thou hast made, O Lord, the sanctuary, O Lord..." (Exod. xv. 17).
62.64: Every one who possesses knowledge is as though the Sanctuary was built in his days ;
62.65: for "knowledge" is placed between two references to the Divine Name and "Sanctuary" is similarly placed.
62.67: In that case, great is vengeance which is placed between two references to the Divine Name; as it is said,
62.68: "A God of vengeance, the Lord" (Ps. xciv. 1)!
62.70: Quite so, in certain circumstances it is great ;
62.72: Why is "vengeance" mentioned twice in the verse?
62.73: One for good, the other for evil — for good, as it is written,
62.74: "He shone forth from Mount Paran" (Deut. xxxiii. 2) ; for evil, as it is written,
62.75: "O Lord, Thou God, to Whom vengeance belongeth, Thou God, to Whom vengeance belongeth, shine forth" (Ps. xciv. 1).
62.76: R. 'Akiba says : One should say the last-mentioned as a fourth benediction by itself.
62.77: Rab Shamman b. Abba said to R. Johanan,
62.78: "It is a fact that the men of the Great Assembly instituted for Israel benedictions and prayers, Sanctifications and Divisions ; let us see where it was arranged [for the Habdalah to be said]."
62.80: "At first they fixed it in the Tefillah ; when the people became prosperous, they arranged for it to be said over the cup of wine; when the people became poor, they again fixed it in the Tefillah ; and they said :
62.81: He who pronounces the 'Division' in the Tefillah must do it again over the cup of wine."
62.82: It has been similarly reported : R. Hiyya. b. Abba said in the name of R. Johanan :
62.83: The men of the Great Assembly instituted for Israel benedictions and prayers, Sanctifications and Divisions.
62.84: At first they fixed [the Habdalah] in the Tefillah; when the people became prosperous, they arranged for it to be said over the cup of wine ; when they again became poor, they fixed it in the Tefillah ; and they said :
62.85: He who pronounces the "Division" in the Tefillah must do it again over the cup of wine.
62.86: It has been likewise reported : Rabbah and Rab Joseph both declare :
62.87: He who pronounces the "Division" in the Tefillah must do it again over the cup of wine.
62.88: Raba said : We quote against this teaching :
62.89: If one erred and omitted the reference to rain in the benediction of "the Revival of the Dead" or the request [for rain] in the benediction of "the Years," we make him repeat it ; but [if he omitted] the "Division" in "Thou favourest man with knowledge" we do not make him repeat it, because he is able to say it over the cup of wine !
62.90: Do not say "because he is able to say it over the cup of wine" but "because he says it over the cup of wine."
62.91: It has been similarly reported : R. Benjamin b. Jephet said :
62.92: R. Assi asked R. Johanan in Zidon (another version : R. Simeon b. Jacob of Tyre asked R. Johanan), "But I have heard that
62.93: one who says the 'Division' in the Tefillah must say it again over the cup of wine ; or is it not so?"
62.95: "Yes, he must say the Habdalah over the cup of wine."
62.97: How is it with one who says the Habdalah over the cup of wine, does he say it in the Tefillah?
62.98: Rab Nahman b. Isaac replied : We draw an a fortiori conclusion from the Tefillah :
62.99: If of the Tefillah where [the Habdalah] was originally instituted they say :
62.100: He who pronounced the "Division" in the Tefillah must do so again over the cup of wine,
62.101: how much more so must one who says the Habdalah over the cup of wine, where it was not originally instituted, [say it in the Tefillah] !
62.102: R. Aha the Tall taught in the presence of Rab Huna :
62.103: He who pronounces the "Division" in the Tefillah is more praiseworthy than he who says it over the cup of wine ; but if he says it in both, may blessings alight upon his head.
62.105: Thou declarest, "He who pronounces the 'Division' in the Tefillah is more praiseworthy than he who says it over the cup of wine"; hence it is sufficient to say it
62.106: in the Tefillah alone ! And then he teaches,
62.107: "But if he says it in both, may blessings alight upon his head"; but since he has fulfilled his obligation with the former, he is exempt and [the latter] will be a superfluous benediction,
62.108: and Rab has declared (another version : R. Simeon b. Lakish ; or R. Johanan and R. Simeon b. Lakish both declare) :
62.109: Whoever utters a superfluous benediction commits a transgression because of [the injunction],
62.110: "Thou shalt not take the name of the Lord thy God in vain" (Exod. xx. 7) !
62.112: If he pronounced the "Division" in the Tefillah and not over the cup of wine, may blessings alight upon his head.
62.114: If a man erred [and omitted the Habdalah] in both, how is it ?
62.116: If he erred in both, he must start again.

63.1: What is the Halakah [if one pronounced the "Division" in the Tefillah, must he say it over the cup of wine] ?
63.3: It is like the Sanctification ; although one sanctifies [the Sabbath] in the Tefillah, he must do so over the cup of wine; so also with the Habdalah, although he said it in the Tefillah, he must do so over the cup of wine.
63.5: [It is to he included] in the "Thanksgiving"
63.6: R. Zera was riding on an ass, and R. Hiyya b. Abin was following him.
63.7: He said to him, "Is it really so as thou didst state in the name of R. Johanan :
63.8: The Halakah is in agreement with R. Eliezer on a Festival which occurs on the conclusion of the Sabbath ?"
63.11: "The Halakah being so, is it to be inferred that there are some who differ from him?
63.12: Are there not, indeed, some who differ?"
63.14: "On which point do the Rabbis differ?" "On the other days of the year." "Do they differ on the question of a Festival which occurs at the conclusion of the Sabbath?
63.16: "Do we, then, act in accordance with R. 'Akiba the whole year, that we should now agree and act in accord with his view?
63.17: Why do we not act in agreement with R. 'Akiba the whole year?
63.18: Because eighteen benedictions were instituted, not nineteen; and so here also, seven benedictions were instituted, not eight."
63.20: It has not been reported that the Halakah [is in accord with R. Eliezer], but it has been reported that we incline [towards his view].
63.21: For it has been reported : Rab Isaac b. Abdemi said in the name of our teacher :
63.22: The Halakah [is in accord with R. Eliezer] ; but some say :
63.25: [The Rabbis] acknowledge [that the Halakah is in agreement with him].
63.29: Take the statement of R. Hiyya. b. Abba in thine hand, because he is most careful to report a teaching exactly as it issued from the mouth of his teacher ; like Rahba of Pombedita.
63.30: For Rahba said in the name of R. Judah :
63.31: The Temple mount was a double colonnade, and it was a colonnade within a colonnade.
63.33: I know neither the one nor the other ; but from Rab and Samuel I know that they instituted a "pearl" for us in Babylon :
63.34: "Thou, O Lord our God, hast made known unto us the judgments of Thy righteousness ; Thou hast taught us to perform the statutes of Thy will. Thou hast caused us to inherit seasons of joy and feasts of free will gifts, and hast given us as an heritage the holiness of the Sabbath, the glory of the appointed time, and the celebration of the festival. Thou hast made a distinction between the holiness of the Sabbath and that of the festival, and hast hallowed the seventh day above the six working days ; Thou hast distinguished and sanctified Thy people Israel by Thy holiness. And Thou hast given us," etc.
63.35: MISHNAH Whoever says [in his Tefillah] "To a bird's nest do Thy mercies extend" or "For the good be Thy name remembered" or "We give thanks, we give thanks," him do we silence.
63.37: we silence him who says, "We give thanks, we give thanks," because he makes it appear as though there were two Powers; and likewise him who says, "For the good be Thy name remembered," the inference being that for the good [may it be remembered] but not for the bad ; and we have a Mishnaic teaching :
63.38: A man is in duty bound to utter a benediction for the bad even as he utters one for the good.
63.39: But why [do we silence him who says], "To a bird's nest do Thy mercies extend"?
63.40: Two Amoraim in the West differ, viz. : R Jose b. Abin and R. Jose b. Zebida :
63.42: Because he causes jealousy between God's creatures ; the other said :
63.43: Because he makes the ordinances of the Holy One, blessed be He, to be simply acts of mercy, whereas they are injunctions.
63.44: A certain man went down [to the Ark] in the presence of Rabbah and said,
63.45: "Thou hast compassion on a bird's nest ; do Thou have compassion and mercy upon us."
63.47: "How this Rabbinical scholar knows how to find favour with his Lord!"
63.49: "Lo, we have learnt in the Mishnah: We silence him!"
63.50: But Rabbah merely wished to test Abbai.
63.51: A certain man went down [to the Ark] in the presence of R. Hannina. He said,
63.52: "O God, the great, the mighty, the revered, the glorious, the powerful, the feared, the strong, the courageous, the certain, the honoured."
63.53: R. Hannina waited until he had finished.
63.54: When he had finished, he said to him,
63.55: "Hast thou exhausted all the praises of thy Lord?
63.56: What is the use of all those [adjectives]? The three which we do say, if Moses our teacher had not used them in the Torah and the men of the Great Assembly come and instituted them in the Tefillah, we should not have been able to say ; and thou dost go on saying all those!"
63.57: A parable : [It may be likened] to a human king who possessed a million golden denarii, and people kept praising him as the possessor of [a million denarii of] silver; is it not an insult to him ?
63.59: Everything is in the hand of Heaven except the fear of Heaven; as it is said,
63.60: "And now, O Israel, what doth the Lord thy God require of thee but to fear" (Deut. x. 12).
63.61: Is, then, the fear of Heaven a small thing?
63.62: Lo, R. Hannina has said in the name of R. Simeon b. Johai :
63.63: The Holy One, blessed be He, has in His treasury nothing but the store of heavenly fear; as it is said,
63.64: "And the fear of the Lord which is His treasure" (Is. xxxiii. 6) !
63.65: Yes, in the estimation of Moses it was a small thing ;
63.67: A parable : [It may be likened] to a man from whom a large vessel is required ; possessing it, it seems to him small ; but if he does not possess it, though it be small, it seems to him large.
63.68: [ Who says], "We give thanks," him do we silence.
63.69: R. Zera said : Whoever says Shema', Shema' is like him who says "We give thanks, we give thanks" [and is to be silenced].
63.71: He who reads the Shema' and repeats the words is to be reprimanded.
63.72: He is to be reprimanded, but not silenced !
63.74: This refers to one who repeats it word by word ; but the former refers to him who repeats it verse by verse.
63.76: But perhaps he at first did not direct his mind and finally did so!

64.1: If he did not at first direct his mind [to his prayer], we smite him with a smith's hammer until he does direct his mind.
64.2: MISHNAH He who says in his Tefillah
64.3: "The good bless Thee" behold this is the way of error.
64.4: If a man step before the Ark and make a mistake [in the Tefillah], another replaces him ; and at such a time, one may not decline.
64.5: From where does the latter begin?
64.6: From the commencement of the benediction where the other erred.
64.7: He who steps before the Ark should not respond "Amen" after [the benedictions of] the Kohanim because it might cause him confusion. If there be no other Kohen there but himself he does not raise his hands [for the priestly benediction] ;
64.8: but if he is confident that he can raise his hands and return to the Tefillah, he is permitted.
64.10: [If one is invited] to step before the Ark, he should first decline; should he not do so, he is like cooking without salt. But if he decline unduly, he is like cooking spoilt by over-salting.
64.11: How should he act ? The first time [of asking] he declines ; the second time he wavers ; the third time he stretches his legs and descends [before the Ark].
64.13: There are three things where excess is bad and a small quantity pleasant :
64.14: leaven, salt and declining an office.
64.16: If he erred in the first three benedictions [of Tefillah], he commences again at the beginning; if in the middle benedictions, he returns to "Thou favourest man with knowledge" ; if in the last [three], he returns to the "Service."
64.18: The middle benedictions have no order.
64.20: From where does the latter begin ? From the commencement of the benediction where the other erred ! This is a refutation of Rab Huna ;
64.22: The middle benedictions are all one benediction.
64.24: A man should never pray for his personal needs in the first three or last three benedictions, but in the middle ones.
64.26: [When saying] the first three benedictions, he is like a slave recounting praise before his master ; [when saying] the middle benedictions, he is like a slave begging a reward from his master ; [when saying] the last three benedictions, he is like a slave who, receiving a reward from his master, takes his departure and goes away.
64.28: It happened that a disciple who descended before the Ark in the presence of R. Eliezer unduly prolonged [the prayers].
64.30: "Our master, what a prolonger he is!"
64.32: "Did he prolong more than Moses, our teacher,
64.34: 'The forty days and forty nights that I fell down'" (Deut. ix. 25)?
64.35: It again happened that a disciple who descended before the Ark in the presence of R. Eliezer unduly shortened [the prayers].
64.39: "Did he shorten more than Moses, our teacher ;
64.41: 'Heal her now, O God, I beseech Thee'" (Num. xii. 13)?
64.42: R. Jacob said in the name of Rab Hisda :
64.43: Whoever prays on behalf of another need not mention his name ; as it is said,
64.44: "Heal her now, O God, I beseech Thee," without mentioning Miriam's name.
64.46: These are the benedictions at which a man bends low ;
64.47: at the beginning and end of the "Patriarchs" and at the beginning and end of the "Thanksgiving."
64.48: Should anyone come to bend low at the end and beginning of every benediction, we tell him not to do so.
64.49: R. Simeon b. Pazzi said in the name of R. Joshua b. Levi in the name of Bar Kappara :
64.50: The ordinary man [acts] as we have stated ;

65.0: a high priest [bends] at  the end of each benediction ; a king at the beginning and end of each benediction.
65.1: R. Isaac b. Nahmani said : It was explained to me by R. Joshua b. Levi :
65.2: The ordinary man [acts] as we have stated ; a high priest [bends] at the beginning of each benediction ; a king, when once he bends, should not straighten himself [until the end of the Tefillah] ; as it is said,
65.3: "And it was so, that when Solomon had made an end of praying all this prayer and supplication unto the Lord, he arose from before the altar of the Lord from kneeling on his knees" (I Kings viii. 54).
65.5: "Bowing" means upon the face ; as it is said,
65.6: "Then Bath Sheba bowed with her face to the earth" (ibid. i. 31)."Bending" means upon the knees; as it is said,
65.7: "From kneeling on his knees" (ibid. viii. 54). "Prostrating" means spreading out the hands and legs ; as it is said,
65.8: "Shall I and thy mother and thy brethren indeed come to prostrate ourselves to thee to the earth?" (Gen. xxxvii. 10).
65.9: Rab Hiyya b. Rab Huna said :
65.10: I saw Abbai and Raba just recline on their side.
65.12: He who bends the knee in the "Thanksgiving" is praiseworthy ;
65.14: Such an one is to be reprimanded !
65.16: one referring to the beginning, the other to the end [of the benediction].
65.17: Raba bent the knee at the beginning and end of the "Thanksgiving,"
65.21: "I saw Rab Nahman bend the knee, and I saw Rab Sheshet do it.
65.23: He who bends the knee in the 'Thanksgiving' is to be reprimanded —
65.24: refers to the 'Thanksgiving' in the Hallel."
65.26: He who bends the knee in the "Thanksgiving" of the Tefillah and in the "Thanksgiving" of the Hallel is to be reprimanded —
65.27: to what does this refer? To the "Thanksgiving" in the Grace after meals.
65.28: MISHNAH If one errs while saving the Tefillah, it is a bad omen for him ; and should he be the messenger of the congregation, it is a bad omen for those who deputed him, since a man's deputy is similar to himself.
65.29: They declared concerning R. Hannina b. Dosa that when praying on behalf of the sick, he would say, "This one will live, that one will die."
65.33: "If my prayer is fluent in my mouth, I know that he is accepted; but if not, I know that he is rejected."
65.35: R. Hiyya stated that Rab Safra said in the name of one attached to the school of Rabbi:
65.37: Others refer this [statement of Rab Safra] to the following Baraita:
65.38: One who says the Tefillah must direct his heart to each benediction ; but if unable to do so to each one, he must at least direct his heart to one. To which?
65.39: R. Hiyya stated that Rab Safra said in the name of one attached to the school of Rabbi :
65.41: They declared concerning R. Hannina b. Dosa, etc.
65.43: R. Joshua b. Levi said :For the Scriptures state,
65.44: "Peace, peace to him that is far off and to him that is near, saith the Lord that createth the fruit of the lips; and I will heal him" (Is.lvii. 19).
65.45: R. Hiyya b. Abba said in the name of R. Johanan :
65.46: Every prophet prophesied only to marry his daughter to a disciple of the wise, and for him who transacts the affairs of a disciple of the wise and allows him to enjoy his possessions ; but as for the disciples of the wise themselves, "No eye hath seen what God, and nobody but Thee, will work for him that waiteth for Him" (Is. Ixiv. 3).
65.47: R. Hiyya b. Abba also said in the name of R. Johanan :
65.48: Every prophet only prophesied for the days of the Messiah ; but as for the world to come, "No eye hath seen what God, and nobody but Thee, will work for him that waiteth for Him."
65.49: This is at variance with the opinion of Samuel who said :
65.50: There is no difference between this world and the days of the Messiah, except the servitude of the heathen kingdoms alone ; as it is said,
65.51: "For the poor shall never cease out of the land" (Deut. xv. 11).
65.52: R. Hiyya b. Abba also said in the name of R. Johanan :
65.53: Every prophet only prophesied for the penitent ; but as for the perfectly righteous, "No eye hath seen what God, and nobody but Thee, will work for him that waiteth for Him."
65.54: This is at variance with the opinion of R. Abbahu who said :
65.55: The place which the penitent occupy, the perfectly righteous are unable to occupy ; as it is said,
65.56: "Peace, peace to him that is far off and to him that is near" —
65.57: "to him that is far off [from God]" first, and then "to him that is near." But R. Johanan can reply :
65.58: What means "To him that is far off"? To him who was far off from transgression from the first ; and what means "To him that is near"? To him that was near transgression and has now removed himself therefrom.
65.59: What is the significance of "No eye hath seen" etc.?
65.61: It refers to the wine preserved in the grape from the six days of creation.
65.63: It refers to Eden, upon which the eye of no creature has gazed.
65.64: Perhaps thou wilt ask : Where, then, was Adam ?
65.66: But perhaps thou wilt say that
65.67: the Garden is the same as Eden ! Therefore there is a teaching to tell thee,
65.68: "And a river went out of Eden to water the Garden" (Gen. ii. 10). Hence the Garden and Eden are distinct.
65.70: It once happened that the son of Rabban Gamaliel was ill. He sent two disciples of the wise to R. Hannina b. Dosa to pray on his behalf.
65.71: When he saw them, he ascended to an upper chamber and prayed on his behalf.
65.72: On descending he said to them,
65.77: "'I am no prophet nor a prophet's son' (Amos vii. 14) ; but so is my tradition :
65.78: If my prayer is fluent in my mouth, I know that he is accepted ; but if not, I know that he is rejected."
65.79: They sat down and wrote and noted the time.
65.80: When they came to Rabban Gamaliel, he said to them,
65.82: You have neither understated nor overstated [the time]. But thus it happened ; at that very hour the fever left him, and he asked us for water to drink."
65.83: It also happened with R. Hannina b. Dosa that he went to Torah with Rabban Johanan b. Zakkai. The son of Rabban Johanan b. Zakkai fell ill,
65.85: "Hannina, my son ! Pray on his behalf that he may live"
65.86: R. Hannina laid his head between his knees, and prayed on his behalf, and he recovered.
65.88: "Were Ben Zakkai to press his head between his knees all the day long, no notice would be taken of him."
65.92: "No; he is like a slave before the King, and I like a nobleman before the King."
65.93: R. Hiyya b. Abba also said in the name of R Johanan :
65.94: A man should not pray except in a room which has windows ; as it is said,
65.95: "Now his windows were open in his upper chamber towards Jerusalem" (Dan. vi. 11). Rab Kahana said :
65.96: I consider him impertinent who prays in a valley.
65.98: I consider him impertinent who recounts his sins ; as it is said,
65.99: "Happy is he whose transgression is forgiven, whose sin is pardoned" (Ps. xxxii. 1).
65.100: May we return unto thee : One must not stand.

66.0: Mishna How do we make berakhot on fruit?
66.1: (What grows on a) tree, he says
66.2: "who creates the fruit of the tree",except for wine, for on wine he says
66.3: "who creates the fruit of the vine".
66.4: And on fruits of the land, he says
66.5: "who creates the fruit of ground - except for bread, for on bread he says
66.6: "who brings bread forth from the ground".
66.8: "who creates the fruit of the ground." Rabbi Yehuda says
66.10: Guemara : Where we know about Brakhot ?
66.12: (Vayikra 18, 24) "Holy praise to Hashem" we learn we need brakha before and after. Like this, say Rabbi Akiva
66.13: forbidden for man to eat anything before brakha. But "Holy praise"
66.14: Surely it is required [to teach as follows :] First,
66.15: that the All-merciful declares [the owner] must redeem it and then eat it ;
66.17: only those things which require "a song of praise" require redemption, but if they do not require "a song of praise," redemption is unnecessary ! This is according to the statement of R. Samuel b. Nahmani in the name of R. Jonathan who said :
66.19: Whence is it that we say "a song of praise" only over wine ? As it is said, "And the vine said unto them, Should I leave my wine which cheereth God and man?" (Judges ix. 13). If it cheereth man, how does it cheer God ?
66.20: Hence it is to be inferred that we have "a song of praise" only over wine.
66.21: It is quite right according to him who teaches "the planting of the fourth year"; but according to him who teaches "the vineyard of the fourth year" what is there to say?
66.23: R. Hiyya and R. Simeon b. Rabbi [differ] ; one teaches
66.24: "The vineyard of the fourth year," the other teaches
66.26: According to him who teaches "the vineyard of the fourth year" it is quite right if he argues by analogy of expression ; for there is a teaching :
66.27: Rabbi says : It is stated here,
66.28: "That it may yield unto you more richly the increase thereof" (Lev. xix. 25), and it is stated elsewhere,
66.29: "the increase of the vineyard" (Deut. xxii. 9) — as in the latter passage "increase" refers to the vineyard, so also in the former passage it refers to the vineyard ; and there thus remains over one hillul to be interpreted as meaning that a benediction is required [when partaking of fruits].
66.30: But if he does not resort to this argument from analogy, whence does he derive the necessity for a benediction ?
66.31: And even if he resort to this method of reasoning, we find that a benediction is required after eating ; but whence is it that a benediction is necessary before eating ?
66.32: This is no difficulty ; for we can use a fortiori reasoning —
66.33: if he is to bless God when he is satisfied, how much more so when he is hungry ! We find this in connection with
66.34: [the produce of] the vineyard; whence is it [that a benediction is required with] other species ?
66.35: It can be derived from the instance of the vineyard — as the vineyard, a thing that is enjoyed, requires a benediction, so also everything which is enjoyed requires a benediction.
66.36: But it is possible to object :
66.37: Why [is a benediction required with the fruit of] the vineyard ? Because there is the obligation of the gleanings.
66.38: Let, then, the instance of corn show [whether this point is material] !
66.39: But why [is a benediction required when partaking of food made from] corn ? Because there is the obligation of Hallah.
66.40: Then let the instance of the vineyard show [whether this point is material]!
66.41: The argument has therefore to be reinstated,
66.42: because the feature of the first case is not like that of the second and vice versa ; but the factor common to both is that each is something which is enjoyed and consequently requires a benediction. Hence everything which is enjoyed requires a benediction.
66.43: How is this the factor common to them both? [That they are both brought upon] the altar is likewise a common factor !
66.44: Then the olive must also be included because it likewise has this factor of [being brought to] the altar !
66.45: Does, then, the olive need inclusion because of the factor of the altar ?
66.46: Behold, the expression kerem "vineyard" is explicitly written in connection therewith ; for it is stated,
66.47: "And he burnt up the shocks and the standing corn, and also the olive-yards" (Judges xv. 5) !
66.49: It is called "a kerem of olives" but not kerem without qualification.
66.51: "How is this the factor common to them both ? [That they are both brought upon] the altar is likewise a common factor."
66.52: One can, however, derive [the necessity for a benediction] from "the seven species" — as "the seven species" are things enjoyed and require a benediction, so everything that is enjoyed requires a benediction.
66.53: But why do "the seven species" [require a benediction]? Because they are under the obligation of first-fruits.
66.55: it is right [that a benediction is necessary] after partaking of them, but whence is it [that a benediction is necessary] before partaking of them ?
66.56: That is no difficulty ; because it can be derived by a fortiori reasoning —
66.57: if he says a benediction when satisfied, how much more so when hungry ! According to him
66.58: who teaches "the planting of the fourth year" it is quite right [that a benediction is required] for everything that is planted;
66.59: but whence [does he derive the necessity for a benediction] for things not planted, like meat, eggs, fish?
66.60: It is, however, a generally held opinion that
66.61: a man is forbidden to enjoy anything of this world without a benediction.
66.63: It is forbidden for a person to enjoy [something] from this world without a [saying] a blessing and anyone who enjoys [something] from this world without [saying] a blessing steals.
66.64: What is the remedy ? Let him go to a Sage.
66.65: Let him go to a Sage ! What can he do for him,
66.66: seeing that he has done what is forbidden ?
66.68: [The meaning is,] let him from the first go to a Sage who will teach him the benedictions, so that he should not come to commit sacrilege.
66.69: Rab Judah said in the name of Samuel :
66.70: Whoever enjoys anything of this world without a benediction is as though he had partaken of the holy things of Heaven ; as it is said,
66.71: "The earth is the Lord's, and the fulness thereof" (Ps. xxiv. 1).
66.73: t is written, "The earth is the Lord's and the fulness thereof," and it is written, "The heavens are the heavens of the Lord, but the earth hath He given to the children of men" (ibid. cxv. 16) !
66.74: There is no contradiction ; the former passage referring [[fol. 35 b.]] to before the benediction [has been uttered],

67.0: the latter to after the benediction.
67.2: Whoever enjoys anything of this world without a benediction is as though he robbed the Holy One, blessed be He, and the Community of Israel ; as it is said,
67.3: "Whoso robbeth his father or his mother and saith, It is no transgression, the same is the companion of a destroyer" (Prov. xxviii, 24) —
67.4: "father" is none other than the Holy One, blessed be He ; as it is said, "Is not He thy father that hath gotten thee?" (Deut. xxxii. 6) ;
67.5: and "mother" is none other than the Community of Israel ; as it is said,
67.6: "Hear, my son, the instruction of thy father, and forsake not the teaching of thy mother" (Prov. i. 8).
67.7: What means "the companion of a destroyer" ?
67.9: He is the companion of Jeroboam, the son of Nebat, who corrupted Israel against their Father in Heaven.
67.11: It is written, "Therefore will I take back My corn in the time thereof" etc. (Hosea ii. 11), and it is written,
67.12: "And thou shalt gather in thy corn" etc. (Deut. xi. 14) !
67.14: the latter referring to the time when Israel perform the will of the All-present, the former to when Israel neglect His will.
67.16: "And thou shalt gather in thy corn" — what has this teaching to tell us ? Since it is written,
67.17: "This book of the law shall not depart out of thy mouth [but thou shalt meditate therein day and night]" (Josh. i. 8), it is possible to think that these words [are to be understood] as they are written;
67.18: therefore there is a teaching to say,
67.19: "And thou shalt gather in thy corn," ie. conduct at the same time a worldly occupation. These are the words of R. Ishmael.
67.21: Is it possible for a man to plough at the time of ploughing, sow at seed-time, reap at harvest-time, thresh at the time of threshing, and winnow at the time of wind — what is to become of Torah?
67.23: when Israel perform the will of the All-present, their work is done by others; as it is said,
67.24: "And strangers shall stand and feed your flocks," etc. (Is. Ixi. 5) ;
67.25: and at the time when Israel perform not the will of the All-present, their work has to be done by themselves ; as it is said,
67.26: "And thou shalt gather in thy corn."
67.27: Not that alone, but the work of others will be done by them ; as it is said,
67.28: "And thou shalt serve thine enemy" etc. (Deut. xxviii. 48).
67.30: Many acted in accord with the teaching of R. Ishmael and it proved efficacious ; but he who acted in accord with R. Simeon b. Johai did not find it so.
67.32: I beg of you not to appear before me during the days of Nisan and Tishri, so that you may not be concerned about your maintenance the whole year.
67.33: Rabbah b. Bar Hannah stated that R. Johanan said in the name of R. Judah b. R. El'ai :
67.34: Come and see that the later generations are not like the former generations. The former generations made their Torah their principal concern and their work only occasional, and both flourished in their hand ; whereas the later generations made their work their principal concern and their Torah only occasional and neither flourished in their hand.
67.35: Rabbah b. Bar Hannah also stated that R. Johanan said in the name of R. Judah b. R. El'ai :
67.36: Come and see that the later generations are not like the former generations.
67.37: The former generations used to bring their fruits home by way of the kitchen-garden in order to make them liable to the tithe ; whereas the later generations bring their fruits home by way of the roof, or courts, or enclosures in order to exempt them from the tithe.
67.39: Produce is not subject to the tithe until it sees the face of the house ; as it is said,
67.40: "I have put away the hallowed things out of my house" (Deut. xxvi. 13).
67.41: R. Johanan said : Even [if it see] a fixed court [it is subject to the tithe] ; as it is said,
67.42: "That they may eat within thy gates and be satisfied" (ibid. v. 12).
67.43: Except over wine, etc. Why is wine different ?
67.44: Should one say because it is changed [from the grape] into something higher [in value], therefore there is a change in the benediction,
67.45: but lo, oil which is changed [from the olive] into something higher [in value] has no alteration in the benediction ;
67.46: for Rab Judah said in the name of Samuel, and similarly said R. Isaac in the name of R. Johanan :
67.47: Over olive-oil we pronounce the benediction "...Who createst the fruit of the tree" !
67.49: In this case [of oil, the benediction is unaltered] because none other is possible. What other benediction could he say?
67.50: Should he use the formula "...Who createst the fruit of the olive," the olive itself is called "fruit"!
67.51: Then let him say "...Who createst the fruit of the olive-tree."
67.55: Lo, there is a Mishnaic teaching :
67.56: He who vows [to abstain] from food may partake of water and salt ! And we argue that
67.57: water and salt are not called "food," but everything else is so called ; and we further say that this is a refutation of Rab and Samuel who maintain that
67.58: we pronounce the benediction "...Who createst various kinds of food" only over the five species.
67.60: [The quoted Mishnah means,] Whoever declares "Everything that nourishes [I forbid] myself" —
67.61: hence conclude that oil does nourish !
67.63: wine satisfies and oil does not.
67.65: Lo, Raba used to drink wine the whole of the day preceding Passover to whet his appetite in order to eat the unleavened bread with greater zest !
67.66: A large quantity whets the appetite, but a little satisfies [hunger].
67.67: But does it satisfy at all?
67.69: "And wine that maketh glad the heart of man, making the face brighter than oil, and bread that stayeth man's heart" (Ps. civ. 15) — it is bread, not wine, that is a stay!
67.71: wine does both, it satisfies and makes glad, whereas bread is only a stay, but does not cheer.
67.72: If so, let him utter three benedictions !
67.73: But men do not fix their meals for its sake.
67.74: Rab Nahman b. Isaac asked Raba :
67.75: How is it if a man did fix his meal on its account?
67.77: When Elijah comes, let him say whether such can be fixed for a meal ; at present, at least, such a thought does not exist amongst men.
67.79: "Rab Judah said in the name of Samuel, and similarly said R. Isaac in the name of R. Johanan :
67.80: Over olive-oil we pronounce the benediction '...Who createst the fruit of the tree'."
67.82: Should I say that he drinks it as a beverage, it does him harm;
67.84: He who drinks the oil of an offering repays its value but not a fifth in addition ; but he who anoints himself with the oil of an offering repays its value plus a fifth!
67.85: But [perhaps it is here meant that] he eats it together with bread.
67.86: If so, the bread is the principal food and the oil is only accessory ;
67.87: and we have the Mishnaic teaching : This is the general rule :
67.88: In the case of a food which is the principal thing and together with it something accessory, the benediction is to be uttered over the former, and there is no necessity for a benediction over the latter !
67.90: [perhaps what is meant is] he drinks it with elaiogaron.
67.92: Elaiogaron is the juice of beets ; oxygaron is the juice

68.0: of all other kinds of boiled vegetables.)
68.1: If so, the elaiogaron is the principal thing and the oil an accessory ;
68.2: and we have the Mishnaic teaching : This is the general rule :
68.3: In the case of a food which is the principal thing and together with it is something accessory, the benediction is to be uttered over the former, and there is no necessity for a benediction over the latter !
68.4: With what are we here dealing ? With the case of one who has a sore throat;
68.6: One suffering from a sore throat may not directly mollify it with oil on the Sabbath, but he should put a large quantity of oil into an elaiogaron and swallow it.
68.9: because he intends it as a cure no benediction at all is necessary, therefore it informs us that
68.10: since he derives enjoyment from it, he is required to pronounce a benediction.
68.12: [The benediction is] "...Who createst the fruit of the ground."
68.14: It is "...By Whose word all things exists."
68.16: Thou shouldest not differ from Rab Judah, because R. Johanan and Samuel agree with him ;
68.17: for Rab Judah said in the name of Samuel, and similarly said R. Isaac in the name of R. Johanan :
68.18: We pronounce over olive-oil the benediction "... Who createst the fruit of the tree" —
68.20: although it has undergone change, it still remains essentially the same;
68.21: and like-wise here [with wheaten-flour] although it has undergone change, it still remains essentially the same.
68.22: Are, however, the two cases analogous ?
68.23: There [with oil], it has not another and higher value ; but here it has by being made into bread !
68.24: But if [the wheaten-flour] have another and higher value, should we no longer use the benediction "...Who createst the fruit of the ground," but say instead "...By Whose word all things exist"?
68.25: And lo, R. Zera said in the name of Rab Mattena in the name of Samuel :
68.26: Over raw cabbage and barley-flour we use the benediction "...By Whose word all things exist"; is it not then to be supposed that wheaten-flour requires the benediction "...Who createst the fruit of the ground"?
68.27: No; wheaten-flour also requires "...By Whose word all things exist."
68.28: Then he should have specified wheaten-flour, and [we could have argued for ourselves] how much more so barley-flour!
68.29: If he had specified wheaten-flour, I might have thought that
68.30: it applies only to wheat, but barley requires no benediction at all ; therefore he mentioned it for us.
68.31: Is, then, [barley-flour] of less value than salt and brine?
68.33: Over salt and brine one says "...By Whose word all things exist."
68.34: It was necessary ; for otherwise it might have entered thy mind to item, the rest being accessory; consequently it is established that there is a circumstance where oil requires a benediction. say that
68.35: salt or brine a man is accustomed to convey to his mouth [with his food, and therefore a benediction is required], but since barley-flour is injurious by creating tape-worms no benediction should be uttered at all ;
68.37: since there is some enjoyment therefrom, it is necessary to pronounce a benediction.
68.38: Over the palm-heart, Rab Judah said:
68.39: [The benediction is] "...Who createst the fruit of the ground" ;
68.41: It is "...By Whose word all things exist."
68.42: Rab Judah said : It is "...Who Greatest the fruit of the ground" because it is fruit. Samuel said : It is "...By Whose word all things exist" because in the end it hardens.
68.45: Thy opinion is correct: because over the radish, though it in the end grows hard, we say "...Who createst the fruit of the ground."
68.46: But it is not so ! For people plant radishes for the sake of the tuber, but people do not plant palms for the sake of the heart ! Is it, then, [to be assumed] that
68.47: in every case where men do not plant specifically to obtain that article of food, we do not pronounce the benediction over it?
68.48: Lo, the caper-bush men plant for the purpose of the caper-blossom ; and we have a Mishnaic teaching :
68.49: In the case of the various kinds of capers, over the leaves and young shoots one says
68.50: "...Who createst the fruit of the ground," but over the berries and buds
68.51: "...Who createst the fruit of the tree" !
68.53: Men do plant caper-bushes for the sake of the shoots, but not the palm for the sake of the heart ;
68.54: and although Samuel praised Rab Judah, the Halakah is in agreement with Samuel.
68.55: Rab Judah said in the name of Rab :
68.56: As for the caper-bush which is still in a state of 'Orlah outside the [Holy] Land, one throws away the berries but eats the buds ;
68.57: that is to say, the berries are fruit but not the buds.
68.59: ln the case of the various kinds of capers, over the leaves and their young shoots one says "...Who createst the fruit of the ground," but over the berries and buds "...Who createst the fruit of the tree!"
68.60: He speaks according to the view of R. 'Akiba ;
68.61: for there is a Mishnaic teaching : R. Eliezer says :
68.62: In the case of the caper-bush, we give tithe of the young shoots and the berries and buds ; R. 'Akiba says :
68.63: We only give tithe of the berries because they are fruit.
68.64: Then let him say that the Halakah is in agreement with R. 'Akiba!
68.65: If he had said that the Halakah is in agreement with R. 'Akiba, I might have thought that [that is so] even in the Land of Israel ; therefore he informs us :
68.66: Whoever takes a lenient view within the Land, the Halakah is in accord with him outside the Land, but not within.
68.68: The Halakah is in agreement with R. 'Akiba outside the Land; for everyone who takes the lenient view within the Land, the Halakah is in accord with him outside the Land !
68.69: If he had stated that, I might have said :
68.70: This applies to the tithe of trees which within the Land is a Rabbinical ordinance ; but with regard to 'Orlah, which within the Land is ordained by the Torah, I must suppose that likewise outside the Land we must apply it ! Therefore he informs us.
68.71: Rabina found Mar b. Rab Ashe throwing away the berries and eating the caper-buds.
68.73: What is thy opinion — like R. 'Akiba's who takes the lenient view? Then let the master act in accord with Bet Shammai who take a still more lenient view.
68.74: For there is a Mishnaic teaching :
68.75: In the case of the caper-bush. Bet Shammai say :
68.76: It constitutes Kila'im in a vineyard ; but Bet Hillel say :
68.77: It does not. Both, however, admit that it is subject to
68.80: Thou declarest, "In the case of the caper-bush, Bet Shammai say :
68.81: It constitutes Kila'im in a vineyard" — hence it is a kind of vegetable ! It then goes on to state,
68.82: "Both, however, admit that it is subject to 'Orlah" — hence it is a kind of tree!
68.84: for Bet Shammai, being in doubt, take the stricter view in both cases.
