80.22: "Does not the master hold that if one has finished [his meal], he must not eat anything further?"
80.24: "This has only been said when the table has been cleared."
80.25: Raba and R. Zera went on a visit to the house of the Exilarch.
80.26: After the tray had been taken away from before them, there was sent to them from the Exilarch's house a gift [of fruit]. Raba ate it, but R. Zera did not.
80.28: "Does not the master hold that if the table has been cleared, it is forbidden to eat?"
80.32: He who is accustomed [to anoint his hands] with oil [after finishing a meal], the oil impedes him
80.33: Rab Ashe said : When we were at the school of Rab Kahana, he said to us,
80.34: "For instance we are accustomed to the use of oil, and the oil impedes us."
80.35: But the Halakah is in agreement with none of these teachings, but with that which Rab Hiyya b. Ashe said in the name of Rab, viz.: There are three actions which have to be performed with dispatch :
80.36: the putting on of hands must be followed immediately by the act of slaughtering ; the Tefillah must follow immediately on the Ge'ullah ; and the Grace after meals must follow immediately on the washing of the hands.
80.38: A benediction [immediately alights upon him who entertains] disciples of the wise ; as it is said,
80.39: "The Lord hath blessed me for thy sake" (Gen. xxx. 27);
80.40: or, if thou wilt, from this passage, as it is said,
80.41: "The Lord blessed the Egyptian's house for Joseph's sake " (ibid. xxxix. 5).
80.42: MISHNAH  If a man said the benediction over wine before the meal, he is exempt from saying it over the wine after the meal. If he said it over the dainty served before the meal, he is exempt from saying it over the dainty served after the meal. If he said it over the bread, he is exempt from saying it over the dainty; over the dainty, he is not exempt from saying it over the bread.
80.44: Nor from saying it over a cooked dish.
80.45: If men were sitting [at the meal], each one says Grace for himself. If they were reclining, one may say it for all.

81.0: If wine  is set for them in the course of the meal, each one says the benediction for himself;
81.1: after the meal, one may say it for all. The same one says the benediction over the perfume, although they do not bring the perfume until after the meal.
81.2: GEMARA Rabbah b. Bar Hannah said in the name of R. Johanan :
81.3: The teaching applies only to Sabbaths and Festivals, for then a man arranges his meal with wine; but on other days of the year, a benediction is to be said over each cup of wine.
81.4: It has been similarly reported : Rabbah b. Mari said in the name of R. Joshua b. Levi :
81.5: The teaching applies only to Sabbaths and Festivals and the time when one comes from the bath-house and the meal after blood-letting, for then a man arranges his meal with wine; but on the other days of the year, a benediction is to be said over each cup of wine.
81.6: Rabbah b. Mari visited the house of Raba on a week-day, and noticed him pronounce the benediction [over the wine] before the meal and again after it ; and he said to him,
81.7: "That is correct, and so also said R. Joshua b. Levi."
81.8: Rab Isaac b. Joseph visited the house of Abbai on a Festival and noticed that he pronounced the benediction over each cup.
81.10: "Does not the master agree with the opinion of R. Joshua b. Levi ?"
81.14: How is it if wine is brought in the course of the meal — does it make the benediction over the wine after the meal unnecessary?
81.15: Shouldest thou wish to quote our Mishnah : If a man said the benediction over wine before the meal, he is exempt from saying it over the wine after the meal — this is because both of them are for drinking ; but here, since one is for steeping and the other for drinking, it is not so ;
81.16: or perhaps that makes no difference ?
81.18: He is exempt [from repeating the benediction] ; but Rab Kahana said :
81.21: He is exempt; but Rab Sheshet said :
81.23: Rab Huna, Rab Judah and all the pupils of Rab say :
81.26: If wine is set for them in the course of the meal, each one says the benediction for himself ; after the meal, one may say it for all!
81.27: He replied : This is what he means to say,
81.28: If no wine was set for them in the course of the meal, only after it, then one may say the benediction for all.
81.29: If he said it over the bread, he is exempt from saying it over the dainty ; over the dainty, he is not exempt from saying it over the bread.
81.31: Nor from saying it over a cooked dish.
81.33: Are Bet Shammai in disagreement with the first clause of this teaching, or is it perhaps with the second clause?
81.34: They are in disagreement with the first clause; for the first Tanna declares :
81.35: If he said it over the bread, he is exempt from saying it over the dainty, so how much more [is it unnecessary for him to say a benediction] over a cooked dish ; then Bet Shammai come to declare that
81.36: not only does [the benediction over] the bread not exempt that over the dainty, but it does not even exempt that over a cooked dish !
81.37: Or is it perhaps with the second clause that Bet Shammai disagree? For it teaches :
81.38: [Having said the benediction] over the dainty, he is not exempt from saying it over the bread ; it is [the benediction over] the bread from which he is not exempt, but he is exempt from that over the cooked dish ;
81.39: and then Bet Shammai come to say :
81.40: He is not even exempt from that over the cooked dish ! The question [remains unanswered].
81.41: If men were sitting [at the meal], each one says Grace for himself.
81.42: If they were reclining, then yes; but if they were not reclining. no !
81.43: Against this I quote the following :
81.44: If ten were journeying by the way, although they all partake of one loaf, each of them says Grace for himself ;
81.45: should they sit down to eat, although each eats of his own loaf, one may say Grace for all.
81.46: Note that he here states "they sit," i.e. although they are not reclining !
81.47: Rab Nahman b. Isaac said : [This Baraita refers to the case where] for instance men say,
81.48: "Let us go and eat our meal in a certain place."
81.49: When Rab died, his disciples followed his cortege.
81.51: "Let us go and have our meal by the River Danak."
81.52: After they had eaten, they sat on and the question was asked :
81.53: Does our Mishnah intend that only when they recline [does one say the benediction for all] and not if they sit ; or is it perhaps that where people say, "Let us go and eat our meal in a certain place" this is to be regarded the same as reclining?
81.54: They were unable [to answer the question].
81.55: Rab Adda b. Ahabah stood up,

82.0: turned the torn part of his garment to the rear and made a fresh tear,
82.2: "Rab has died and we have not learnt [the regulations of] the Grace after meals!"
82.3: In the meanwhile an Elder came and pointed out the disagreement between our Mishnah and the Baraita, and taught them :
82.4: When men say, "Let us go and eat our meal in a certain place," it is the same as if they had reclined.
82.5: If they were reclining, one may say Grace for all.
82.7: This teaching applies only to bread for which reclining is necessary, but for wine reclining is not necessary.
82.9: Even for wine likewise reclining is needed.
82.11: This teaching applies only to bread where it is beneficial to recline, but with wine it is not beneficial to recline.
82.13: Even with wine it is likewise beneficial to recline.)
82.15: What is the procedure of reclining?
82.16: The guests enter and seat themselves upon stools and chairs until all are assembled. Then water is brought to them, and each washes one hand. Wine is set for them, and each says the benediction for himself.
82.17: They thereupon ascend [the couch] and recline, and water is brought before them ; and although each one has washed one hand, he again washes both hands.
82.18: Wine is brought to them, and although each has said the benediction for himself, one may now say it for all !
82.19: According to one version of Rab's statement, viz. :
82.20: "This teaching applies only to bread for which reclining is necessary, but for wine reclining is not necessary," the first part [of this Baraita] is in disagreement!
82.21: It is different with guests, because it is their intention to move their position.
82.22: And according to the other version of Rab's statement, viz. :
82.23: "This teaching applies only to bread where it is beneficial to recline, but with wine it is not beneficial to recline," the latter part [of the Baraita] is in disagreement !
82.24: It is different there, because while it is beneficial to recline for the bread, it is at the same time beneficial to recline for the wine.
82.25: If wine is set for them in the course of the meal.
82.27: Why is it stated : If wine is set for them in the course of the meal, each one says the benediction for himself; after the meal, one may say it for all ?
82.29: Because the gullet is not empty.
82.30: The same one says the benediction over the perfume, etc.
82.31: Since he teaches, The same one says the benediction over the perfume, it is to be inferred that there may be somebody more worthy than he ; why, then, [is it his privilege] ?
82.32: Because he is the first to wash his hands at the conclusion of the meal.
82.33: This supports the statement of Rab ; for Rab Hiyya b. Ashe said in the name of Rab :
82.34: He who is the first to wash his hands at the conclusion of the meal has the privilege of saying Grace.
82.35: Rab and R. Hiyya were sitting at table in the presence of Rabbi.
82.38: R. Hiyya noticed that Rab was trembling, and said to him,
82.40: See it is for the privilege of saying Grace after meals that Rabbi tells thee [to wash]."
82.41: R. Zera said in the name of Raba b. Jeremiah :
82.42: From what time may we say the benediction over the smell [of the perfume]? From the time its column of smoke ascends.
82.43: R. Zera said to Raba b. Jeremiah
82.44: , "But one has not yet smelt it!"
82.46: "According to thy reasoning, one says the Grace before meals but has not yet eaten !
82.47: His intention is to eat, and so here likewise it is his intention to smell."
82.48: R. Hiyya b. Abba b. Nahmani stated that Rab Hisda said in the name of Rab (another version : Rab Hisda said in the name of Ze'iri) :
82.49: Overall kinds of perfumes the benediction is "...Who Greatest fragrant woods," excepting musk which comes from a species of animal and its benediction is "...Who createst various kinds of spices."
82.51: We only say "...Who createst fragrant woods" over the balsam-trees of the house of Rabbi
82.52: and the balsam-trees of the Emperor's palace and over the myrtle-tree wherever it comes from !
82.57: It is '...Who createst the oil of our land '."
82.59: "Leave out Rab Judah, because the land of Israel is very dear to him ; what is the benediction generally?"
82.64: Over costum the benediction is "...Who createst fragrant woods," but not over the oil in which it is steeped.
82.66: [That is the benediction] even for the oil in which it is steeped, but not the oil with which it is ground.
82.68: [That is the benediction] even for the oil in which it is ground.

83.0: Rab Giddel said in the name of Rab :
83.1: Over jasmine the benediction is "...Who createst fragrant woods."
83.2: Rab Hananel said in the name of Rab:
83.3: Over sea-rush the benediction is "...Who createst fragrant woods."
83.5: What is the Scriptural authority? "She had brought them up to the roof, and hid them with the stalks of flax" (Josh. ii. 6).
83.7: Over the garden-narcissus the benediction is "...Who createst fragrant woods," but over the wild narcissus "...Who createst fragrant herbs."
83.9: Over violets the benediction is "...Who createst fragrant herbs."
83.11: He who smells the citron or quince should say "Blessed be He Who setteth a beautiful fragrance in fruits."
83.13: He who goes out during the days of Nisan and sees the trees budding should say
83.14: "Blessed be He Who has caused nothing to be lacking in His Universe and created therein beautiful creations and beautiful trees where-from men may derive pleasure."
83.15: Rab Zotra b. Tobiah said in the name of Rab :
83.16: Whence is it learnt that one should pronounce a benediction over a fragrant smell? As it is written,
83.17: "Let every soul praise the Lord" (Ps. cl. 6). From what is it that the soul, but not the body, derives enjoyment? Say it is a fragrant smell.
83.18: Rab Zotra b. Tobiah also said in the name of Rab :
83.19: The young men of Israel will in the future give forth a sweet fragrance like Lebanon ; as it is said,
83.20: "His branches shall spread, and his beauty shall be as the olive-tree, and his fragrance as Lebanon" (Hosea xiv. 7).
83.21: Rab Zotra b. Tobiah also said in the name of Rab : What means that which is written,
83.22: "He hath made everything beautiful in its time" (Eccles. iii. 11)? It teaches that the Holy One, blessed be He, makes every occupation agreeable in the eyes of those who follow it.
83.23: Rab Pappa said : Hence the proverb,
83.24: "Hang the heart of a palm-tree around a sow, and it will act as usual."
83.25: Rab Zotra b. Tobiah also said in the name of Rab :
83.26: [Walking by the light of] a torch is equal to two; by moonlight is equal to three.
83.28: Is the light of the torch equal to two, including himself ; or perhaps it is equal to two excluding himself?
83.30: [It is stated,] "By moonlight is equal to three."
83.31: That is quite right if thou sayest it means including himself, well and good ; but if thou sayest it means excluding himself, why are four necessary?
83.32: For lo, the teacher has said :
83.33: To a single person an evil spirit appears and injures him ; to two it appears but does not injure them ; to three it does not appear at all !
83.34: Certainly it is to be concluded that the expression "torchlight is equal to two" means including himself. Draw that conclusion.
83.35: Rab Zotra b. Tobiah also said in the name of Rab (another version : Rab Hanna b. Bizna in the name of R. Simeon Hasida ; still another version : R. Johanan said in the name of R. Simeon b. Johai) :
83.36: It were better for a man to cast himself into the midst of a fiery furnace rather than cause the face of his fellow-creature to blanche in public.
83.38: From Tamar ; as it is said, "When she was brought forth" etc. (Gen. xxxviii. 25).
83.40: If they set before him oil and myrtle, Bet Shammai declare :
83.41: He first says the benediction over the oil and then over the myrtle ;
83.43: He first says the benediction over the myrtle and then over the oil.
83.46: Oil we use for its fragrance and for anointing, whereas we use the myrtle only for its fragrance and not for anointing.
83.48: The Halakah is in accord with him who decided.
83.49: Rab Pappa visited the house of Rab Huna b. Rab Ika; they set before him oil and myrtle. He took and made the benediction first over the myrtle and then over the oil.
83.51: Does not the master hold that the Halakah is in accord with the words of him who decided ?
83.53: The Halakah is in accord with Bet Hillel.
83.54: But it was not so, and he only did this to extricate himself.
83.56: If oil and wine are set before him, Bet Shammai declare :
83.57: He should take hold of the oil in his right hand and the wine in his left, say the benediction over the oil and then over the wine ;
83.59: He should take hold of the wine in his right hand and the oil in his left, say the benediction over the wine and then over the oil.
83.60: And he should rub the oil upon the head of the attendant ; but if the attendant be a disciple of the wise, he should rub it upon the wall, because it is a disgrace for a disciple of the wise to go into the street perfumed.
83.62: Six things are a disgrace to a disciple of the wise :
83.63: He should not go out into the street perfumed ; nor go out alone at night ; nor go out with patched sandals ; nor converse with a woman in the street ; nor recline in the company of 'Amme ha'ares ; nor be the last to enter the House of Study.
83.65: he should also not walk with a big stride, nor walk with an erect carriage.
83.66: He should not go out into the street perfumed. R. Abha b. R. Hiyya b. Abba said in the name of R. Johanan :
83.67: This refers to a place where people are suspected of pederasty.
83.69: They mean only with his garment [perfumed], but on his body [it is permitted] because it removes [the odour of] perspiration.
83.71: [To perfume] his hair is like [perfuming] his garment;
83.72: but some declare that it is like [perfuming] his body.
83.73: He should not go out alone at night, because of the suspicion [it may arouse] ; and they mean only where he has no fixed hour [for going out at night], but if he have a fixed hour, it will be well known that he goes out as is his usual custom.
83.74: He should not go out with patched sandals. This supports the statement of R. Hiyya b. Abba who said :
83.75: It is a disgrace for a disciple of the wise to go out with patched sandals.
83.77: for R. Hiyya b. Abba went out thus!
83.78: Mar Zotra b.  Rab Nahman said :
83.79: It means with a patch on top of a patch,
83.80: and it refers only to the legging ; but as for the sole, we have no objection.
83.81: And even in the case of the legging, it means only when walking by the way ; but as for wearing such in the house, we have no objection.
83.82: It further refers to the days of Summer, but in the days of Winter we have no objection.
83.83: He should not converse with a woman in the street. Rab Hisda said :
83.84: Even if it be his wife.
83.85: There is a teaching to the same effect :
83.86: Even if it be his wife, or his daughter, or his sister, because everybody is not well acquainted with his female relations.
83.87: He should not recline in the company of 'Amine ha'ares. What is the reason ?
83.88: He may perhaps be induced to be drawn after them.
83.89: He should not be the last to enter the House of Study; because such an one is called "a transgressor."
83.91: he should not walk with a big stride. For the teacher has said :
83.92: A big stride takes away one five hundredth part of the light of a man's eyes.
83.93: What is the remedy for if ?
83.94: He may restore it [by drinking the wine of] Sanctification on the [Sabbath] night.
83.95: He should not walk with an erect carriage. For the teacher has said:
83.96: He who walks with an erect carriage, even a distance of four cubits, is as though he pushed against the feet of the Shekinah; for it is written,
83.97: The whole earth is full of His glory" (Is. vi. 3).

84.0: MISHNAH If they set before him salted food first and with it bread, he says the benediction over the salted food and this makes it unnecessary over the bread, because the bread is something accessory to it.
84.2: In the case of a food which is the principal thing and together with it is something accessory, the benediction is to be uttered over the former and there is no necessity for a benediction over the latter.
84.3: GEMARA Is there any salted food which is the principal thing and the bread, accessory ?
84.4: Rab Aha b. Rab 'Awira said in the name of Rab Ashe :
84.5: They refer to one who eats the fruits of Gennesareth.
84.7: At the time we were following R. Johanan to eat the fruits of Gennesareth, when we were a hundred in number we used each to take ten for him, and when we were ten we used each to take a hundred for him ; and a basket of the capacity of three Saot could not hold a hundred of them. But he ate them all and swore that he had tasted no food.
84.10: [He meant that he had eaten no] satisfying meal.
84.11: R. Abbahu ate so many of them that a fly would glide down his face.
84.12: R. Ammi and R. Assi ate so many of them that their hair fell out.
84.13: R. Simeon b. Lakish ate so many of them that he began to rave. R. Johanan reported this to the household of the Prince, and R. Judah the Prince sent officials after him and brought him to his house.
84.14: When Rab Dimai came [from Palestine] he said :
84.15: Jannaeus the king had a city on the king's mountain from which they obtained sixty myriad basins of salted fish for the hewers of the fig-trees from one Sabbath-eve to the next.
84.17: Jannaeus the king had a tree on the king's mountain from which they took down forty Saot of young pigeons monthly from three broods.
84.18: When R. Isaac came he said :
84.19: There was a city in the land of Israel named Gofnit in which were eighty pairs of brothers of a priestly family married to eighty pairs of sisters of a priestly family ;
84.20: and the Rabbis searched from Sura to Nehardea and could not find [a similar case] with the exception of the daughters of Rab Hisda who were married to Rammi b. Hamma and Mar 'Ukba b. Hamma ; but although the women belonged to a priestly family, the men did not.
84.22: A meal without salt is no meal.
84.23: R. Hiyya b. Abba said in the name of R. Johanan :
84.24: A meal without some acrid substance is no meal.
84.25: MISHNAH If one ate grapes, figs or pomegranates, he says after them the three benedictions. These are the words of Rabban Gamaliel ;
84.27: One benediction which is an abstract of three.
84.29: Even if one eats [nothing but] boiled vegetables and makes a meal of it, he pronounces thereover the three benedictions.
84.30: If one drinks water to slake his thirst, he says the benediction "...By Whose word all things exist ";
84.32: "...Who createst many living beings and their wants."
84.33: GEMARA What is Rabban Gamaliel's reason?
84.35: "A land of wheat and barley and vines and fig-trees and pomegranates" (Deut. viii. 8), and it is written,
84.36: "A land wherein thou shalt eat bread without scarceness" (ibid. v. 9), and it is written
84.37: "And thou shalt eat and be satisfied, and bless the Lord thy God" (ibid. v. lO).
84.39: [The reference to] the "land" interrupts the subject-matter.
84.40: But for Rabban Gamaliel likewise [the reference to] the "land" interrupts the subject-matter !
84.41: He requires that to exclude the case of one who chews wheat.
84.42: R. Jacob b. Iddi said in the name of R. Hannina :
84.43: Over any food which belongs to the five species, before partaking thereof one says the benediction "...Who createst various kinds of foods," and afterwards one benediction which is an abstract of three.
84.44: Rabbah b. Mari said in the name of R. Joshua b. Levi :
84.45: Over any food belonging to the seven species, before partaking thereof one says the benediction "...Who createst the fruit of the tree," and afterwards one benediction which is an abstract of three.
84.47: What is the one benediction which is an abstract of three?
84.49: For the fruit of the tree it is: "[Blessed art Thou, O Lord our God, King of the universe,] for the tree and the fruit of the tree and for the produce of the field; for the desirable, good and ample land which Thou didst give as an heritage unto our fathers, that they might eat of its fruits and be satisfied with its goodness. Have mercy, O Lord our God, upon Israel Thy people, upon Jerusalem Thy city, upon Thy Sanctuary and altar. Rebuild Jerusalem, Thy holy city, speedily in our days ; lead us up thither and make us rejoice in its rebuilding ; for Thou art good and beneficent unto all."
84.50: For the five species it is : "[Blessed... universe] for the sustenance and the nourishment, and for the produce of the field," etc. And the benediction is concluded : "[Blessed art Thou, O Lord,] for the land and for the sustenance."
84.51: In the case of fruit how should the benediction conclude ?
84.52: When Rab Dimai came he said :
84.53: Rab concluded on the New Moon thus, "Blessed [art Thou, O Lord] Who sanctifiest Israel and the beginnings of the months."
84.54: So how should it be concluded in this case of fruit ?
84.56: "[Blessed art Thou, O Lord,] for the land and its fruits."
84.58: "For the land and for the fruits."
84.60: There is no contradiction, Rab Hisda's wording being customary with us [in Babylon] and R. Johanan's with them [in Palestine].
84.62: They eat and we make the benediction !
84.63: Nay, the wording should be reversed ;
84.65: "For the land and for the fruits"

85.0: Rab Isaac b. Abdemi said in the name of our teacher :
85.1: Over  an egg and various kinds of meat, before partaking thereof one says the benediction "...By Whose word all things exist" and afterwards "...Who createst many living beings" etc. ;
85.4: Even over vegetables, but not over water.
85.7: Mar Zotra acted in accord with Rab Isaac b. Abdemi, and Rab Shimi b. Ashe in accord with R. Isaac. (A mnemonic for thee is :
85.8: One in accord with two and two in accord with one.)
85.10: When I think of it, I act in accord with them all.
85.12: Everything that requires a benediction after it requires one before it ; but there are things which require a benediction before but not after.
85.13: This is quite right for Rab Isaac b. Abdemi, since it is to exclude vegetables, and for R.Isaac to exclude water ; but for Rab Pappa what is it to exclude ?
85.15: But for the sons of the West who on removing the Tefillin say the benediction, "[Blessed art Thou, O Lord our God, King of the universe] Who didst sanctify us with Thy commandments and commanded us to observe Thy statutes," what is it to exclude ?
85.17: R. Jannai said in the name of Rab :
85.18: Any food [whose minimum standard is the size of] an egg, the egg is superior to it [as nourishment].
85.20: Better is a light-roasted egg than six measures of fine flour.
85.21: When Rab Dimai came he said:
85.22: Better is a light-roasted egg than six [measures of fine flour] and a hard-baked egg than four. Of a boiled egg [it is said], any food [whose minimum is the size of] an egg, the egg is superior to it [as nourishment] with the exception of meat.
85.23: R. 'Akiba says : Even if one eats boiled vegetables, etc.
85.24: Is there any boiled vegetable which is to be regarded as nourishment?
85.25: Rab Ashe said: It refers to cabbage-stalks.
85.27: Milt is good for the teeth but bad for the bowels ; horse-beans are bad for the teeth but good for the bowels.
85.28: All raw vegetables make the complexion pale ; anything not fully grown makes the body shrink ; every living being restores the soul and everything near to the soul restores the soul.
85.29: Cabbage [is good] as nourishment and beet as a remedy ; but woe to the body through which vegetables keep constantly passing.
85.31: "Milt is good for the teeth but bad for the bowels."
85.33: Let him chew it and then throw it away.
85.34: "Horse-beans are bad for the teeth but good for the bowels."
85.36: Let him boil them well and swallow them.
85.37: "All raw herbs make the complexion pale."
85.39: This refers only to the first meal after blood-letting.
85.41: It is forbidden to converse with him who has eaten [raw] herbs before the fourth hour of the day.
85.45: It is forbidden for a man to eat raw herbs before the fourth hour of the day.
85.46: Amemar, Mar Zotra and Rab Ashe were sitting [at table], and they set before them raw herbs before the fourth hour. Amemar and Rab Ashe ate, but not so Mar Zotra.
85.48: "What is thy opinion ? Is it because R. Isaac declared :
85.49: It is forbidden to converse with him who has eaten [raw] herbs before the fourth hour of the day on account of the evil odour ? Behold we have eaten, and still thou talkest with us!"
85.51: "I agree with the other statement of R. Isaac, viz. :
85.52: It is forbidden for a man to eat raw herbs before the fourth hour of the day."
85.53: "Anything not fully grown makes the body shrink."
85.55: Even a young kid worth a Zuz ;
85.56: and it only refers to that which is not a fourth [of its full natural size], but if it be a fourth, we have no objection.
85.59: Even the small fishes from the swamps.
85.60: "Everything near to the soul restores the soul."
85.64: "When thou bringest me a piece of meat, take the trouble and obtain it from a place near to where the benediction is pronounced."
85.65: "Cabbage is good as nourishment and beet as a remedy."

91.28: Whoever has no Sisit on his garment. R. Nathan says :
91.29: Whoever has no Mezuzah on his door. R. Nathan b. Joseph says :

91.35: Rab Menashya b.Tahlifa who taught Sifra, Sifre and the Halakah.

91.38: But there is a teaching : Others declare ;
91.39: Even if one has studied Torah and Mishnah but has not ministered to the disciplas of the wise, he is an 'Am ha'ares !

91.67: An infant lying in the cradle may be included for Zimmun.
91.68: But lo, there is our Mishnaic teaching :
91.69: Women, slaves and minors may not be included!
91.70: R. Jose is in agreement with the statement of R. Joshua b. Levi who said :
91.71: Although they declare that an infant lying in the cradle may not be included for Zimmun, yet we may consider him an addition. to make up a quorum of ten.

91.73: Nine [free] men and a slave may be reckoned together for a quorum.

91.81: "Of them shall ye take your bondmen forever" (Lev. xxv. 46) !

103.34: Rab Zebid (another version : Rab Dimai b. Abba) said :

104.0: When you see a place where miracles were done to Israel, you say:
104.1: Blessed is He who preformed miracles for our forefathers in this place.
104.2: In a place where idol worship was uprooted, you say:
104.3: Blessed is He who uprooted idol worship from our land.
104.4: For shooting stars, earthquakes, thunders, storms and lightnings he says,
104.5: "Blessed...Whose strength and might fill the world."
104.6: For mountains, hills, seas, rivers and deserts he says,
104.9: He who beholds the ocean says,
104.10: "Blessed... Who hast made the ocean," but only when he beholds it at intervals.
104.11: For rain and good tidings he says,
104.12: "Blessed... Who art good and dispensest good."
104.15: He who has built a new house or bought new vessels says,
104.16: "Blessed... Who hast kept us in life, hast preserved us and enabled us to reach this season,"
104.17: One says the benediction for a calamity apart from any attendant good, and for good fortune apart from any attendant evil ;
104.18: but he who supplicates concerning that which is past utters a vain prayer.
104.19: If his wife is pregnant and he says,
104.20: "May it be Thy will that my wife bear a son," behold that is a vain prayer.
104.21: If he were on the way, and hearing a cry of lamentation in the city, exclaims,
104.22: "May it be Thy will that it be not within my house," behold that is a vain prayer.
104.23: He who enters a town should offer prayer twice, once on entering and once on leaving.
104.25: Four times, twice on entering and twice on leaving. He gives thanks for what is past and supplicates for what is yet to be.
104.26: A man is in duty bound to utter a benediction for the bad even as he utters one for the good ; as it is said,
104.27: "And thou shalt love the Lord thy God with all thy heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy might" (Deut. vi. 5) —
104.28: "with all thy heart," i.e. with thy two impulses, with the good and the evil impulse ;
104.29: "with all thy soul," i.e. even if He take thy soul; "with all thy might," i.e. with all thy wealth.
104.31: "with all thy might [meodeka]" — with whatever measure [middah] He metes out to thee, do Thou return Him thanks [modeh].

104.33: Nor may one enter the Temple Mount with his staff, his sandal, his wallet, and with the dust upon his feet ; nor may he use it as a short cut,
104.34: and to expectorate [on the Temple Mount is forbidden] a fortiori. At the conclusion of every benediction in the Sanctuary they used to say

104.39: "And behold, Boaz came from Bethlehem, and said unto the reapers,

104.43: "The Lord is with thee, thou mighty man of valour" (Judges vi. 12);
104.45: Don't be embarrassed because your mother has grown old
104.47: It is time to act for G-d because they have violated your Torah
104.49: They should violate your Torah because it is time to act for G-d

104.51: R. Yochanan said according to the Tanach:
104.52: "And Jethro said, Blessed be the Lord Who hath delivered you" etc. (Exod. xviii. 10).
104.53: Do we say a benediction for the miracle wrought on behalf of the many but not for the miracle wrought on behalf of an individual?
104.54: Lo, there was the man who was journeying by 'Eber Jamina when a lion attacked him, and a miracle was wrought for him and he was rescued.
104.55: He came before Raba who told him :
104.56: Whenever thou reachest that spot, say "Blessed... Who hast wrought a miracle for me in this place."
104.57: And Mar b. Rabina was passing through the valley of 'Arabot and thirsted for water ; a miracle was wrought for him and a well was created and he drank.
104.58: On another occasion, he was passing through the market-place of Mahoza when a wild camel attacked him, and the wall was cleft for him and he went through it.
104.59: Whenever he came to 'Arabot he said the benediction
104.60: "Blessed... Who hast wrought for me a miracle in 'Arabot and with the camel" ; and whenever he came to the market-place of Mahoza he said,
104.61: "Blessed... Who hast wrought for me a miracle with the camel and in 'Arabot."
104.63: In the case of a miracle wrought on behalf of the many, everybody is obliged to utter the benediction; but in the case of a miracle wrought on behalf of an individual, only he is obliged to say it. Our Rabbis have taught :
104.64: He who beholds the fords of the [Red] Sea, or the fords of the Jordan, or the fords of the valleys of Arnon, or the hail-stones in the descent of Bet Horon, or the stone which Og, king of Bashan, sought to cast upon Israel, or the stone upon which Moses sat when Joshua fought against Amalek, or [the pillar of salt of] Lot's wife, or the wall of Jericho which was swallowed up in its place — over all these one must give thanks and praise before the All-present.
104.65: It is quite right with the fords of the [Red] Sea ; for it is written,
104.66: "And the children of Israel went into the midst of the Sea upon the dry ground" (Exod. xiv. 22).
104.67: [It is quite right with] the fords of the Jordan; for it is written,
104.68: "And the priests that bare the ark of [the covenant of] the Lord stood firm on dry ground in the midst of the Jordan, while all Israel passed over on dry ground, until all the nation were passed clean over the Jordan" (Josh. iii. 17).
104.69: But the fords of the valleys of Arnon — whence is it [that a benediction is necessary]?
104.71: "Wherefore it is said in the book of the Wars of the Lord, Et and Heb in the rear and the valleys of Arnon" etc. (Num. xxi. 14).
104.73: "Et and Heb in the rear" were two lepers who journeyed in the rear of the camp. When the Israelites were to pass through [the valleys of Arnon], the Amorites came

105.0: and made caves for themselves in which they hid, saying,
105.1: "When the Israelites pass here we will kill them." But they knew not that the Ark was journeying before Israel and was lowering the rocks in front of them ;
105.2: so when the Ark reached [the spot where the Amorites were in hiding], the rocks clave together, killing them, and their blood descended into the valleys of Arnon.
105.3: When Et and Heb came and saw blood issuing from between the rocks, they went and told the Israelites and uttered a song. That is what is written,
105.4: "And he poured out the valleys that incline toward the seat of Ar and lean upon the border of Moab" (ibid. v. 15).
105.5: "Hail-stones" abne elgabish. What are abne elgabish ?
105.7: They are stones which remained suspended [in the air] for the sake of a man and descended for the sake of a man.
105.8: They remained suspended for the sake of a man, viz.: Moses; for it is written,
105.9: "Now the man Moses was very meek" (Num. xii. 3), and it is written,
105.10: "And the thunders and hail ceased, and the rain poured not upon the earth" (Exod. ix, 33).
105.11: They descended for the sake of a man, viz. Joshua ; for it is written,
105.12: "Take thee Joshua the son of Nun, a man in whom is spirit" (Num. xxvii. 18), and it is written,
105.13: "And it came to pass, as they fled from before Israel, while they were at the descent of Beth-horon, that the Lord cast down great stones" (Josh. x. 11).
105.14: "The stone which Og, king of Bashan, sought to cast upon Israel." A tradition has been handed down in this connection :
105.16: "What is the extent of Israel's camp ? Three Parsah. I will go and uproot a mountain of the size of three Parsah, and cast it upon them so that I will kill them."
105.17: He went and uprooted a mountain of the size of three Parsah and carried it upon his head ; but the Holy One, blessed be He, sent ants which bored a hole through it so that it sank about his neck.
105.18: As he sought to draw it off, his teeth were extended on both sides, so that it was impossible to extricate himself. That is what is written,
105.19: "Thou hast broken the teeth of the wicked" (Ps. iii. 8) ;
105.20: and it is in accord with the statement of R. Simeon b. Lakish who said:

105.22: What was the height of Moses? Ten cubits. He took an axe ten cubits long, jumped to a height of ten cubits and struck Og on his ankle and killed him.
105.23: "The stone upon which Moses sat"; for it is written,
105.24: "But Moses' hands were heavy ; and they took a stone, and put it under him, and he sat thereon" (Exod. xvii. 12). [Had not Moses a cushion or bolster upon which to sit ? But thus spake Moses : Since Israel are now enduring hardship, I too will endure hardship with them.]
105.26: "But his wife looked back from behind him and she became a pillar of salt" (Gen. xix. 26).

105.38: "And it came to pass, when God destroyed the cities of the Plain, that God remembered Abraham, and sent Lot out of the midst of the overthrow..." (Genesis 19:29)
105.39: "And the wall of Jericho which was swallowed up."
105.40: And the wall of Jericho which was swallowed up !

106.10: "He who prolongs his stay in the privy" — is that a virtue?
106.11: Lo, there is a teaching : Ten things cause a man piles :
106.12: Eating the leaves of reeds, the leaves of the vine, the sprouts of the vine, the palate of an animal, the backbone of a fish, salted fish which has not been sufficiently cooked, to drink the lees of wine, to wipe oneself [after evacuation] with lime, potters' clay, or pebbles with which another has wiped himself ; and some add :
106.13: Also unduly to strain oneself in the privy !
106.14: There is no contradiction ; the latter refers to one who stays and strains, the other to one who stays long but does not strain.
106.15: It is like the incident where a certain matron said to R. Judah b. R. El'ai,
106.16: "Thy face is like that of pig-rearers and usurers."
106.20: but there are twenty-four privies from my lodging-place to the House of Study, and whenever I go there I test myself in all of them."
106.21: Rab Judah also said : Three things shorten a man's days and years :
106.22: To be given a Scroll of the Torah from which to read [a portion in the Synagogue] and decline to read ; to be handed the cup of benediction to say Grace and decline ; and to give oneself an air of superiority.
106.23: "To be given a Scroll of the Torah from which to read and decline to read" — for it is written, "For that is thy life and the length of thy days" (Deut. 30:20).
106.24: "To be handed the cup of benediction to say Grace and decline" — for it is written, "I will bless them that bless thee" (Gen. 12:3).
106.25: "To give oneself an air of superiority" — for R. Hamma b. R. Hannina said :
106.26: Why did Joseph die before his brothers? Because he gave himself superior airs.
106.27: Rab Judah also said in the name of Rab : For three things it is necessary to offer supplication :
106.28: A good king, a good year, and a good dream.
106.29: "A good king" — for it is written, "The king's heart is in the hand of the Lord as the water-courses" (Prov. xxi. 1).
106.30: "A good year" — for it is written, "The eyes of the Lord thy God are always upon it, from the beginning of the year even unto the end of the year" (Deut. 11:12).
106.31: "A good dream" — for it is written, "Wherefore cause Thou me to dream and make me to live" (Is. 38:16).
106.33: There are three things which the Holy One, blessed be He, Himself proclaims, viz. :
106.34: famine, plenty and a good leader.
106.35: "Famine" — for it is written, "The Lord hath called for a famine" (II Kings 8:1). "Plenty" — for it is written, "I will call for the corn and will increase it" (Ezek. 36:29). "A good leader" — for it is written, "And the Lord spoke unto Moses, saying, See I have called by name Besalel, the son of Uri" etc. (Exod. 31:1 f.).
106.36: Rabbi Shmuel bar Nachmani said in the name of Rabbi Yonetan:
106.37: Betzalel was called upon because of his wisdom. In the moment that the Holy One Blessed be God said to Moses:
106.38: Say to Betzalel: make for me a Mishkan, an ark, and vessels. Moses went and switched the order, and he said to him (Betzalel): make an ark, vessels, and a Mishkan.
106.39: [Betzalel] said to him, our teacher, it is the custom of everyone that one builds a house, and afterwards places inside vessels, and you are saying, make for me
106.40: an ark, vessels, and a Mishkan. Where do I place the vessels that I am making? Perhaps the Holy One blessed be God said to you: Make a Mishkan, an ark, and vessels.
106.41: Moses responded] said to him: Perhaps you were in the shadow of God and you knew!
106.42: Rav Yehuda said: Rav Said: Betzalel knew how to combine the letters that were used to create the Heavens and the Earth. It was written here, “And he filled him with the spirit of God with Wisdom, Understanding, and Intellect.” (Exodus 35:31) and it was written there, “The LORD founded the land with Wisdom and established the Heavens with Understanding.” (Proverbs 3:19) and it is written, “with his intellect, the depths were broken.” (Proverbs 3:20)
106.47: "If he is acceptable to the Holy One, blessed be He, and to thee, how much more so to us ! "
106.48: R. Samuel b. Nahmani said in the name of R. Jonathan :
106.49: He was called Basalel because of his wisdom :
106.50: for at the time that the Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moses,
106.51: "Go, tell Besalel, 'Make for Me a tabernacle, an ark and vessels'," Moses went and inverted the order, saying to him,
106.52: "Make an ark and vessels and a tabernacle."
106.54: "Moses, our teacher, it is the way of the world for a man to build a house and afterwards furnish it ; but thou sayest,
106.55: 'Make for Me an ark, vessels and a tabernacle'!
106.56: Where shall I place the vessels which I make?
106.57: Perhaps thus spake the Holy One, blessed be He, unto thee,
106.58: 'Make a tabernacle, an ark and vessels'."
106.60: "Perhaps thou wert in the shadow of God and thou knowest this."
106.61: Rab Judah said in the name of Rab :
106.62: Besalel knew how to combine the letters with which the heavens and earth had been created ;
106.63: for it is written here, "And He hath filled him with the spirit of God, in wisdom and in understanding and in knowledge" (Exod. 35:31), and it is written elsewhere, "The Lord by wisdom founded the earth; by understanding He established the heavens" (Proverbs 3:19) and "By His knowledge the depths were broken up" (Proverbs 5:20).
106.65: The Holy One, blessed be He, only gives wisdom to him who has wisdom ; as it is said, "He giveth wisdom unto the wise, and knowledge to them that know understanding" (Dan. 2:21 ).
106.66: Rab Tahlifa the Palestinian heard this and repeated it in the presence of R. Abbahu. He said to him :
106.67: You learn it from there ; but I learn it from the following, for it is written, "In the hearts of all that are wise-hearted I have put wisdom" (Exod. 31:6).
106.69: [There is no reality in] any dream without a fast.
106.71: An uninterpreted dream is like an unread letter.
106.73: Neither a good nor a bad dream is fulfilled in every detail.
106.75: A bad dream is preferable to a good dream.
106.77: When a dream is bad, the pain it causes is sufficient [to prevent its fulfilment], and when the dream is good, the joy it brings is sufficient.
106.79: As for a good dream, even in my own case, its cheerfulness frustrates it [so that it is not realised].
106.81: A bad dream is worse than scourging ; as it is said, "God hath so made it that men should fear before Him" (Eccles. 3:14), and Rabbah b. Bar Hannah said in the name of R. Johanan :
106.82: This refers to a bad dream.
106.83: "The prophet that hath a dream, let him tell a dream ; and he that hath My word, let him speak My word faithfully. What hath the straw to do with the wheat ? saith the Lord" (Jer. 23:28). What connection has "straw and wheat" with a dream ?
106.84: But said R. Johanan in the name of R. Simeon b. Johai :
106.85: Just as one cannot have wheat without straw, similarly it is impossible for a dream to be without something that is vain.
106.87: A dream, though it be fulfilled in part, is never completely realised. Whence is this learnt? From Joseph; for it is written, "And behold the sun and the moon and eleven stars bowed down to me" (Gen. 37:9);

107.0: but at that time his mother was no longer living.
107.2: A man should always wait up to twenty-two years for [the fulfilment of] a good dream.
107.3: Whence is this learnt ? From Joseph ; for it is written, "These are the generations of Jacob. Joseph, being seventeen years old" etc. (ibid. v. 2), and it is written, "And Joseph was thirty years old when he stood before Pharaoh" (ibid. xli. 46).
107.4: From seventeen to thirty — how many years is it? Thirteen ; add the seven years of plenty and two of famine, hence we get twenty-two.
107.6: A good man is not shown a good dream and a bad man is not shown a bad dream.
107.7: There is a teaching to the same effect:
107.8: Throughout David's lifetime he never saw a good dream, and throughout Ahitophel's lifetime he did not see a bad dream.
107.9: But lo, it is written, "There shall no evil befall thee" (Ps. xci. 10), and Rab Hisda said in the name of Rab Jeremiah b. Abba :
107.10: [These words mean,] neither bad dreams nor evil thoughts will trouble thee! [not fully translated]
107.12: the good man sees no evil dream, but others dream about him.

107.16: Nay, this is what he means to say :

107.18: Rab Huna b. Ammi stated that R. Pedat said in the name of R. Johanan :
107.19: He who sees a dream and his soul is depressed should go and have it interpreted in the presence of three.
107.22: An uninterpreted dream is like an unread letter !
107.24: He should have it turned into good in the presence of three.
107.25: He should assemble three men and say to them,
107.27: and they should say to him,
107.28: "Good it is and may it be good. May the All-merciful turn it to good ;
107.29: seven times may it be decreed concerning thee from Heaven that it should be good, and may it be good."
107.30: Then they should recite three verses in which the word hapak "turn" occurs, three in which padah "redeem" occurs, and three in which shalom "peace" occurs.
107.31: Three verses in which "turn" occurs — "Thou didst turn for me my mourning into dancing ; Thou didst loose my sackcloth and gird me with gladness" (Ps. xxx. 12); "Then shall the virgin rejoice in the dance, and the young men and the old together; for I will turn their mourning into joy, and will comfort them, and make them rejoice from their sorrow" (Jer. xxxi. 12); "Nevertheless the Lord thy God would not hearken unto Balaam; but the Lord thy God turned the curse into a blessing unto thee" (Deut. xxiii. 6).
107.32: Three verses in which the word "redeem" occurs — "He hath redeemed my soul in peace so that none came nigh me" (Ps. Iv. 19) ; "And the redeemed of the Lord shall return and come with singing unto Zion...and sorrow and sighing shall flee away" (Is. 35:10) ; "And the people said unto Saul, Shall Jonathan die, who hath wrought this great salvation in Israel?... So the people rescued [padah] Jonathan, that he died not" (I Sam. xiv, 45).
107.33: Three verses in which the word "peace" occurs — "Peace, peace, to him that is far off and to him that is near, saith the Lord that createth the fruit of the lips ; and I will heal him" (Is. lvii. 19) ; "Then the spirit clothed Amasai, who was chief of the captains : Thine are we, David, and on thy side, thou son of Jesse ; peace, peace be unto thee, and peace be to thy helpers; for thy God helpeth thee" (I Chron. xii. 18); "Thus ye shall say, All hail! and peace be both unto thee, and peace be to thy house, and peace be unto all that thou hast" (I Sam. xxv. 6).
107.34: Amemar, Mar Zotra and Rab Ashe were sitting together; they said:
107.35: Let each one of us relate something which the others have not heard.
107.36: One of them commenced and said :
107.37: He who has seen a dream and knows not what he has seen, let him stand before the Kohanim at the time that they spread their hands [to pronounce the priestly benediction] and utter the following :
107.38: "Lord of the universe ! I am Thine and my dreams are Thine ; a dream have I dreamed and I know not what it is. Whether I dreamed concerning myself, or my fellows dreamed concerning me, or I dreamed concerning others, if they be good dreams, strengthen and fortify them [and may they be fulfilled] like the dreams of Joseph ; but if they require to be remedied, heal them as the waters of Marah [were healed] by the hands of Moses our teacher, as Miriam [was healed] from her leprosy, as Hezekiah from his illness, and like the waters of Jericho [sweetened] by the hands of Elisha. And as Thou didst turn the curse of the wicked Balaam into a blessing, so do Thou turn all my dreams for me into good." He should conclude [his prayer] simultaneously with the Kohanim, so that the Congregation responds "Amen."
107.39: But if not, let him say the following:
107.40: "Thou majestic One in the heights, Who abidest in might, Thou art peace and Thy name is peace. May it be Thy will to grant us peace."
107.42: He who enters a town and is afraid of the Evil Eye, let him take his right thumb in his left hand and his left thumb in his right hand and say the following:
107.43: "I, A the son of B, come from the seed of Joseph against whom the Evil Eye had no power ; as it is said, 'Joseph is a fruitful vine, a fruitful vine by a fountain' (Gen. xlix. 22). Read not 'ale 'ayin 'by a fountain' but 'ole 'ayin 'overcoming the [Evil] Eye'."
107.44: R. Jose b. R. Hannina said : It may be derived from the verse :
107.45: "And let them grow [weyidgu] into a multitude in the midst of the earth" (ibid, xlviii. 16) ; i.e. as the fishes [dagim] in the sea are covered by the water and the Evil Eye cannot have power over them, in similar manner the Evil Eye has no power over the seed of Joseph.
107.46: Should he, however, be afraid of his own Evil Eye, let him gaze upon the wing of his left nostril.
107.47: The third of them commenced and said :
107.48: He who is ill should not disclose the fact on the first day so as not to cause himself bad luck, but after that he may disclose it.
107.49: As when Raba fell ill, on the first day he did not disclose it, but after that be said to his attendant, "Go, announce that
107.51: Let him who loves me pray on my behalf, and let him that hates me rejoice over my plight ; for it is written, 'Rejoice not when thine enemy falleth, and let not thy heart be glad when he stumbleth ; lest the Lord see it and it displease Him, and He turn away His wrath from him' (Prov. xxiv. 17 f.)."
107.52: When Samuel had a bad dream, he used to say,
107.54: but when he had a good dream, he used to say,
107.56: For lo, it is written, 'I [God] do speak with him in a dream' (Num. xii. 6)."
107.58: It is written, "I do speak with him in a dream," and it is written, "The dreams speak falsely" !
107.59: There is no contradiction ; the former being through an angel, the latter through an evil spirit.
107.60: R. Bizna b. Zabda stated that R. 'Akiba said in the name of R. Panda, in the name of R. Nahum, in the name of R. Biryam, in the name of an Elder — and who is he? R. Banaah:
107.61: There were twenty-four interpreters of dreams in Jerusalem. I once had a dream and went to consult them all ; but the interpretation each gave me differed from that of the others. Nevertheless all their interpretations were realised in me ; to fulfil that which was said
107.62: "All dreams follow the mouth [of the interpreter]."
107.63: Is there such a Scriptural passage as "All dreams follow the mouth"?
107.64: Yes; and it is like the statement of R. Eleazar who said :
107.65: Whence is it that all dreams follow the mouth ?
107.66: As it is said, "And it came to pass, as he interpreted to us, so it was" (Gen. xli. 13).
107.68: That is only so if he interprets it from the content of the dream; as it is said, "To each man according to his dream he did interpret" (ibid. v. 12).
107.69: "When the chief baker saw that the interpretation was good" (ibid. xl. 16) — how did he know this?
107.71: This teaches that each of them was shown the dream and interpretation of the other.
107.73: If one wakes up and a verse comes to his mouth, it is to be regarded as a minor prophecy.
107.74: R. Johanan also said : Three types of dream are fulfilled —
107.75: a morning dream, a dream which his friend has about him, and a dream interpreted in the midst of a dream.
107.77: Also a dream which is repeated ; as it is said, "And for that the dream was doubled unto Pharaoh twice" (Gen. xli. 32).
107.78: R. Samuel b. Nahmani said in the name of R. Jonathan :
107.79: A man is only shown [in a dream what emanates] from the thoughts of his heart ; as it is said, "As for thee, O king, thy thoughts  came into thy mind upon thy bed" (Dan. ii. 29). Or if thou wilt I can say from this passage, "That thou mayest know the thoughts of thy heart" (ibid. v. 30).
107.81: Thou mayest know this from the fact that a man is never shown [in a dream] a golden date-palm or an elephant entering the eye of a needle.

108.0: The Roman Emperor said to R. Joshua b. R. Hannina,
108.1: "You declare that you are wise. Tell me what I shall see in my dream."
108.3: "Thou wilt see the Persians enslaving thee, despoiling thee, and making thee pasture unclean animals with a golden crook."
108.4: The Emperor reflected upon it the whole day and in the night saw it [in a dream].
108.6: "You declare that you are very wise.
108.7: Tell me what I shall see in my dream."
108.9: "Thou wilt see the Romans come and take thee captive and make thee grind date-stones in a golden mill."
108.10: The king reflected upon it the whole day and in the night saw it [in a dream].
108.11: Bar Hedja was an interpreter of dreams. When one paid him a fee, he interpreted [the dream] favourably ; but if no fee was given him, he interpreted it unfavourably.
108.12: Abbai and Raba had a dream ; Abbai gave him a Zuz but Raba gave him nothing.
108.14: We were made to read in our dream the words "Thine ox shall be slain before thine eyes" (Deut. xxviii. 31).
108.16: Thy business will fail, and thou wilt have no desire to eat because of the grief of thy heart. To Abbai he said :
108.17: Thy business will prosper, and thou wilt have no desire to eat because of the joy of thy heart.
108.19: We were made to read in our dream the words "Thou shalt beget sons and daughters, but they shall not be thine, for they shall go into captivity" (ibid. 5:41). To Raba he replied in an unfavourable sense. To Abbai he said :
108.20: Thy sons and daughters will be many, and thy daughters will marry [husbands in distant parts of] the world, so that they will seem to thee as though they had gone into captivity,
108.21: [They said to him : In our dream] we were made to read the words "Thy sons and thy daughters shall he given unto another people " (ibid. v. 32), To Abbai he said :
108.22: Thy sons and daughters will be many ; thou wilt say [they should marry] thy relatives, but [thy wife] will say they [should marry] her relatives, and she will compel thee to give them to her relatives, and it will seem [as though they had been given] to another people.
108.24: Thy wife will die, and thy sons and daughters will come under the control of another wife. For Raba said in the name of R. Jeremiah b. Abba in the name of Rab :
108.25: What means that which is written, "Thy sons and thy daughters shall be given unto another people"? This refers to a stepmother.
108.26: [They said to Bar Hedja] : We were made to read in our dream the words "Go thy way, eat thy bread with joy" (Eccles, ix. 7). To Abbai he said :
108.27: Thy business will prosper and thou wilt eat and drink and read Scriptural verses from the joy of thy heart.
108.29: Thy business will fail, thou wilt slaughter [cattle] but not eat, and thou wilt drink and read Scriptural verses to banish thy dread.
108.30: We were made to read the words "Thou shalt carry much seed out into the field, and shalt gather little in for the locust will consume it" (Deut. xxviii. 38). To Abbai he gave an interpretation from the first half of the verse ; to Raba from the latter half.
108.31: We were made to read the words "Thou shalt have olive-trees throughout all thy borders, but thou shalt not anoint thyself with the oil, for thine olives shall drop off" (Deut. xxviii, 40). To Abbai he gave an interpretation from the first half of the verse ; to Raba from the latter half.
108.32: We were made to read the words "And all the peoples of the earth shall see that the name of the Lord is called upon thee, and they shall be afraid of thee" (ibid. v. 10). To Abbai he said :
108.33: Thy fame will go forth as the Principal of the College and the fear of thee will be widespread in the world.
108.35: The king's treasury will be broken into and thou wilt be arrested as one of the thieves, and everybody will draw an inference from thee.
108.36: The next day the king's treasury was broken into, and they came and arrested Raba.
108.38: We saw [in a dream] lettuce upon the mouth of a jar.
108.40: Thy business will be doubled like the lettuce. To Raba he said :
108.41: Thy business will be bitter like the lettuce.
108.43: We saw [in a dream] meat upon the mouth of a jar.
108.45: Thy wine will be sweet and everybody will come to buy meat and wine of thee.
108.47: Thy wine will be sour and everybody will come to buy meat to eat therewith.
108.49: We saw [in a dream] a jug hanging upon a date-palm. To Abbai he said :
108.50: Thy wares will be exalted like the palm.
108.52: Thy wares will be sweet as dates.
108.54: We saw [in a dream] a pomegranate sprouting on the mouth of a jar. To Abbai he said :
108.55: Thy wares will be high-priced like the pomegranate.
108.57: Thy wares will be stale [and taste] like the pomegranate.
108.59: We saw [in a dream] a jug fall into a well. To Abbai he said :
108.60: Thy wares will be sought as one says, "A piece of bread fell into a well and cannot be found."
108.62: Thy wares will go bad and thou wilt cast them into a well.
108.64: We saw [in a dream] a young ass standing by the side of our pillow and braying. To Abbai he said :
108.65: Thou wilt become the President of the College and an Amora will stand by thee.

108.69: I have myself seen that the words are there.
