109.65: Kappa means 'a beam' and Deka 'ten.' Go, examine the beam which heads number ten, for it is full of coins." He went and found it full of coins.
109.67: Who dreams of a well will see peace ; as it is said, "And Isaac's servants digged in the valley, and found there a well of living water" (Gen. xxvi. 19).
109.69: He will find Torah; as it is said, "Whoso findeth me findeth life" (Prov. viii. 35), and it is written here "a well of living water."
109.72: R. Hanan said : There are three [types of dreams which indicate] peace —
109.74: "A river" — for it is written, "Behold I will extend peace to her like a river" (Is. Ixvi. 12). "A bird" — for it is written, "As birds hovering, so will the Lord of hosts protect Jerusalem" (ibid. xxxi. 5). "A pot" — for it is written, "Lord, Thou wilt establish peace for us" (ibid. xxvi. 12).
109.76: But it must be a pot in which there is no meat; for it is said,
109.77: "They chop them in pieces, as that which is in the pot, and as flesh within the caldron" (Micah iii. 3).
109.79: Who dreams of a river should on rising say, "Behold I will extend peace to her like a river" (Is. Ixvi. 12), before another verse occurs to him, viz. : "For distress will come  in like a river" (ibid. lix. 19).
109.80: Who dreams of a bird should on rising say, "As birds hovering so will the Lord of hosts protect" (ibid. xxxi. 5), before another verse occurs to him, viz. : "As a bird that wandereth from her nest, so is a man that wandereth from his place" (Prov. xxvii. 8).
109.81: Who dreams of a pot should on rising say, "Lord, Thou wilt establish [shapat] peace for us" (Is. xxvi. 12), before another verse occurs to him, viz. : "Set on [shapat] the pot, set it on" (Ezek. xxiv. 3).
109.82: Who dreams of grapes should on rising say, "I found Israel like grapes in the wilderness" (Hos. ix. 10) before another verse occurs to him, viz.: "Their grapes are grapes of gall" (Deut. xxxii. 32).
109.83: Who dreams of a mountain should on rising say, "How beautiful upon the mountains are the feet of the messenger of good things" (Is. lii. 7), before another verse occurs to him, viz.: "For the mountains will I take up a weeping and wailing" (Jer. ix. 9).
109.84: Who dreams of a horn should on rising say, "And it shall come to pass in that day, that a great horn shall be blown" (Is. xxvii. 13), before another verse occurs to him, viz. : "Blow ye the horn of Gibeah" (Hos. 5:8).
109.85: Who dreams of a dog should on rising say, "But against any of the children of Israel shall not a dog whet his tongue" (Exod. xi. 7), before another verse occurs to him, viz. : "Yea, the dogs are greedy" (Is. Ivi. 11).
109.86: Who dreams of a lion should on rising say, "The lion hath roared, who will not fear?" (Amos iii. 8), before another verse occurs to him, viz. : "A lion is gone up from his thicket" (Jer. iv. 7). [is gone up]
109.87: [a lion from his thicket] Who dreams of shaving should on rising say, "And [Joseph] shaved himself and changed his raiment" (Gen. xli. 14), before another verse occurs to him, viz. : "If I be shaven, then my strength will go from me" (Judges xvi. 17).
109.88: Who dreams of a well should on rising say, "A well of living waters" (Cant. iv. 15), before another verse occurs to him, viz. : "As a cistern welleth with her waters, so she welleth with her wickedness" (Jer. vi. 7).
109.89: Who dreams of a reed should on rising say, "A bruised reed shall he not break" (Is. xlii. 3), before another verse occurs to him, viz. : "Behold, thou trustest upon the staff of this bruised reed" (ibid, xxxvi. 6).
109.91: Who dreams of a reed [kaneh] may hope for wisdom ; as it is said, "Get [keneh] wisdom" (Prov. iv. 5). Who dreams of reeds may hope for understanding ; as it is said, "With all thy getting get understanding" (ibid. v. 7).
109.93: A pumpkin [kara], a palm-heart [kora], wax [kira] and a reed [kanya] are all auspicious in a dream.
109.95: Nobody is shown a gourd [in a dream] except him who is a fearer of Heaven with all his strength.
109.96: Who dreams of an ox should on rising say, "His firstling bullock, majesty is his" (Deut. xxxiii. 17), before another occurs to him, viz. : "If an ox gore a man" (Exod. xxi. 28).
109.97: Our Rabbis have taught : Five things are said in connection with the ox :
109.98: Who [dreams that he] eats of its flesh will grow rich; that an ox had gored him, he will have sons who will contend with each other in Torah; that it bit him, sufferings will come upon him ; that it kicked him, a long journey is destined for him ; that he rode upon it, he will ascend to greatness. But there is a teaching :
109.99: [One who dreams of] riding upon an ox will die !
109.101: the former referring [to a dream wherein] he rides upon the ox, the latter to when the ox rides on him.
109.102: Who dreams of an ass may hope for salvation ; as it is said, "Behold thy king cometh unto thee: he is triumphant and victorious, lowly, and riding upon an ass" (Zech. ix. 9).
109.103: Who dreams of a cat in a place where the word for it is Shunnara, a beautiful song [shirah naah] will be composed in his honour ; [but where the word for it is] Shinnara, a change for the worse [shinnui ra'] is in store for him.
109.104: Who dreams of grapes, if they are white, both in their season and out of season, they are a good omen ; if they are black, in their season they are a good omen, but out of season a bad omen.
109.105: Who dreams of a white horse, whether standing still or galloping, it is a good omen for him ; if it is roan, should it be standing still, it is a good omen; should it be galloping, it is a bad omen.
109.106: Who dreams of Ishmael, his prayer will be heard; but only of Ishmael the son of Abraham, and not of an ordinary Arab.
109.107: Who dreams of a camel, death had been decreed upon him by Heaven, but he has been delivered therefrom.
109.108: R. Hamma b. R. Hannina said :
109.109: What is the Scriptural authority for this ? "I will go down with thee into Egypt ; and I will also surely bring thee up again" (Gen. xlvi. 4).
109.110: Rab Nahman b. Isaac said : It may be derived from the following, "The Lord also hath put away thy sin; thou shalt not die" (II Sam. xii. 13).
109.111: Who dreams of Phineas, a miracle will be wrought for him. Who dreams of an elephant [pil], miracles [pela'ot] will be wrought for him; of elephants, miracles upon miracles will be performed for him.
109.113: To dream of all kinds of animals is a good omen with the exception of the elephant and ape !

110.0: the former referring to animals which are bridled, the latter to those which are not bridled.
110.1: Who dreams of the name "Huna," a miracle will be wrought for him ;
110.2: of "Hannina, Hananya, Johanan," miracles will be wrought for him.
110.3: Who dreams of a Hasped, from Heaven will pity and redemption be vouchsafed him.
110.4: This only applies [to him who sees in his dream the word Hesped] in writing.
110.5: [Who dreams] that he makes the response "May His great name be blessed" is assured that he is a son of the world to come. [Who dreams] that he recites the Shema' is meet that the Shekinah should rest upon him, but his generation is not worthy of it.
110.6: Who dreams that he lays the Tefillin may hope for greatness ; as it is said, "And all the peoples of the earth shall see that the name of the Lord is called upon thee, and they shall fear thee" (Deut. xxviii. 10); and there is a teaching :
110.8: This refers to the Tefillin worn on the head.
110.9: Who dreams that he is saying the Tefillah, it is a good omen for him ; but this applies only when he does not conclude it.
110.10: Who dreams of having intercourse with his mother may hope for understanding; as it is said, "Yea, thou wilt call understanding 'mother'" (Prov. ii. 3).
110.11: [Who dreams] of having intercourse with a betrothed maiden may hope for Torah, as it is said, "Moses commanded us a law [Torah], an inheritance of the congregation of Jacob" (Deut. xxxiii. 4) — read not morashah "an inheritance" but me'orasah "betrothed maiden."
110.12: Who dreams of having had intercourse with his sister may hope for wisdom ; as it is said, "Say unto wisdom, thou art my sister" (Prov. vii. 4).
110.13: Who dreams of having had intercourse with a married woman is assured that he is a son of the world to come ; but this applies only if he was not acquainted with her and did not think of her during the evening.
110.15: Who dreams of wheat will see peace ; as it is said,
110.16: "He maketh thy borders peace ; He giveth thee in plenty the fat of wheat" (Ps. cxlvii. 14).
110.17: Who dreams of barley, his iniquities will depart; as it is said, "Thine iniquity is taken away, and thy sin expiated" (Is. vi. 7).
110.19: I never went up from Babylon to the Land of Israel without dreaming of barley.
110.20: Who dreams of a well-laden vine, his wife will not miscarry ; as it is said, "Thy wife shall be as a fruitful vine" (Ps. cxxviii. 3).
110.21: [Who dreams] of a choice vine may hope for the Messiah ; as it is said, "Binding his foal unto the vine and his ass' colt unto the choice vine" (Gen. xlix. 11).
110.22: Who dreams of the fig, his Torah will be preserved within him ; as it is said, "Whoso keepeth the fig-tree shall eat the fruit thereof" (Prov. xxvii. 18).
110.23: Who dreams of pomegranates, if small, his business will bear fruit like the pomegranate ; if large, his business will grow like the pomegranate ; if split open, should he be a disciple of the wise, he may hope for Torah ; as it is said, "I would cause thee to drink of spiced wine, of the juice of my pomegranate" (Cant. viii. 2); but should he be an 'Am ha'ares, he may hope for commandments [to perform], as it is said, "Thy temples [rakkah] are like a pomegranate split open" (ibid. iv. 3).
110.24: What means rakkah? Even the illiterate [rekanim] amongst thee will be full of commandments as a pomegranate [is full of seeds].
110.25: Who dreams of olives, if small, his business will be fruitful and multiply and endure like olives. But this applies only to [dreaming of] the fruit ; if [he dreamt] of olive-trees, then he will have numerous offspring; as it is said, "Thy children like olive-plants, round about thy table" (Ps. cxxviii. 3).
110.27: he who dreams of the olive, a good name will proceed from him; as it is said, "The Lord called thy name a leafy olive-tree, fair and goodly fruit" (Jer. xi. 16).
110.28: Who dreams of olive-oil may hope for the light of Torah ; as it is said, "That they bring unto thee pure olive-oil beaten for the light" (Exod. xxvii. 20).
110.29: Who dreams of palms, his iniquities will be ended; as it is said, "The punishment of thine iniquity is accomplished, O daughter of Zion" (Lam. iv. 22).
110.31: Who dreams of a goat, the year will be blessed for him; of goats, years will be blessed for him ; as it is said, "And there will be goat's milk enough for thy food" (Prov. xxvii. 27).
110.32: Who dreams of the myrtle, his business undertakings will prosper ; and if he has no business undertakings, an inheritance will fall to his lot from some other place.
110.33: 'Ulla said (another version : It was taught in a Baraita) :
110.34: This only applies when he sees [the myrtle] on its stem.
110.35: Who dreams of a citron, will be honoured before his Maker; as it is said, "The fruit of goodly trees, branches of palm-trees" (Lev. xxiii. 40). Who dreams of a palm-branch has but one heart for his Father in Heaven.
110.36: Who dreams of a goose may hope for wisdom; as it is said, "Wisdom crieth aloud in the street" (Prov. i. 20);
110.37: and he who [dreams of having] intercourse with it will become the Principal of a Seminary.
110.38: Rab Ashe said : I dreamt of seeing one and having intercourse with it, and I ascended to greatness.
110.39: Who dreams of a cock may hope for a son, of cocks may hope for sons, of hens may hope for a beautiful rearing [of his children] and rejoicing.
110.40: Who dreams of eggs, his petition remains in suspense ; if broken, his petition has been granted. Similarly is it with nuts and cucumbers and all glass vessels and all such breakable articles.
110.41: [Who dreams] that he entered a town, his desires will be fulfilled for him ; as it is said, "And He led them unto their desired haven" (Ps. cvii. 30).
110.42: Who dreams of shaving his head, it is a good omen for him; [of shaving] his head and beard, [it is a good omen] for him and all his family.
110.43: [Who dreams] that he is sitting in a small boat, a good name will proceed from him ; if in a big boat, then from him and all his family ; but that only applies when it is sailing high on the seas.
110.44: Who dreams that he is performing the functions of nature, it is a good omen for him ; as it is said, "He that is bent down shall speedily be loosed" (ls li. 14). But that only applies if he does not [dream of] wiping himself.
110.45: Who dreams of ascending to the roof will ascend to greatness ; of descending, he will descend from greatness.
110.47: Since he has ascended, he has ascended.
110.48: Who dreams of rending his garments, the Divine decree will be rent for him.
110.49: Who dreams of standing naked, if in Babylon he will stand without sin ; but if in the Land of Israel, [he will stand] naked without commandments.
110.50: Who dreams that he has been arrested by the police, the Divine protection will be vouchsafed him. [If he dreamt] that they placed him in neck-chains, the Divine protection will be doubly vouchsafed him ; but this applies only to a neck-chain, not to a common cord.
110.51: Who dreams of walking into a pool will be appointed Principal of a Seminary ; into a forest, he will be made the head of the Collegiates.
110.52: Rab Pappa and Rab Huna b. Rab Joshua had a dream. Rab Pappa [dreamt that he] walked into a pool and was appointed the Principal of a Seminary, and Rab Huna b. Rab Joshua that he walked into a forest and was made the head of the Collegiates.
110.54: They both [dreamt that they] walked into a pool; but Rab Pappa, who was wearing a drum around his neck, was made Principal of the Seminary, whereas Rab Huna b. Rab Joshua, who had no drum around his neck, was made the head of the Collegiates.
110.56: I [once dreamt that I] walked into a pool, with a drum around my neck, and I made a noise therewith.
110.57: A Tanna taught in the presence of Rab Nahman b. Isaac :
110.58: Who dreams of blood-letting, his sins will be pardoned him.
110.60: His sins are set in order for him !
110.61: What means "set in order"? Set in order so as to be pardoned.
110.62: A Tanna taught in the presence of Rab Sheshet ;
110.63: Who dreams of a serpent, his sustenance will be provided him ; if it bit him, his sustenance will be doubled for him ; if he killed it, his sustenance is lost.
110.65: [When he dreams of killing the serpent], how much more likely is it that his sustenance will be doubled !
110.66: But it is not so ; and it was Rab Sheshet who dreamt that he saw a serpent and killed it.
110.67: A Tanna taught in the presence of R. Johanan :
110.68: To dream of any kind of liquids is a good omen, with the exception of wine. Some [dream they] drink it and it is a good omen for them, and some do so and it is a bad omen for them.
110.69: There are some who [dream they] drink it and it is a good omen for them, as it is said, "Wine that maketh glad the heart of man" (Ps. civ. 15); and there are some who [dream they] drink it and it is a bad omen for them, as it is said, "Give strong drink unto him that is ready to perish, and wine unto the bitter in soul" (Prov. xxxi. 6). R. Johanan said to the Tanna : Teach that in the case of a
110.70: disciple of the wise, it is always a good omen ; as it is said, "Come, eat of my bread, and drink of the wine which I have mingled" (ibid, ix. 5).

111.1: If one wakes up and a verse comes to his mouth, it is to be regarded as a minor prophecy.
111.2: Our Rabbis have taught : There are three kings [to dream of whom has significance]. Who dreams of David may hope for piety ; of Solomon, may hope for wisdom ; of Ahab, he should be concerned about punishment.
111.3: There are three prophets [to dream of whom has significance].
111.4: (Who dreams of the Book of Kings may hope for greatness;) of Ezekiel, may hope for wisdom ; of Isaiah, may hope for consolation ; of Jeremiah, he should be concerned about punishment.
111.5: There are three major books of the Hagiographa [to dream of which has significance].
111.6: Who dreams of the Book of Psalms may hope for piety ; of Proverbs, may hope for wisdom ; of Job, he should be concerned about punishment.
111.7: There are three minor books of the Hagiographa [to dream of which has significance].
111.8: Who dreams of the Song of Songs may hope for piety ; of Ecclesiastes, may hope for wisdom ; of Lamentations, he should be concerned about punishment ;
111.9: and he who dreams of the Scroll of Esther, a miracle will be wrought for him.
111.10: There are three Sages [to dream of whom has significance].
111.11: Who dreams of Rabbi may hope for wisdom ; of R. Eleazar b. 'Azariah, may hope for wealth ; of Ishmael b. Elisha, he should be concerned about punishment.
111.12: There are three disciples of the wise [to dream of whom has significance].
111.13: Who dreams of Ben 'Azzai may hope for piety ; of Ben Zoma, may hope for wisdom ; of Aher, he should be concerned about punishment.
111.14: To dream of any species of animal is a good omen with the exception of the elephant, monkey and long-tailed ape.
111.16: Who dreams of an elephant, a miracle will be wrought for him !
111.17: There is no contradiction ; the latter refers to where it is bridled and the other to where it is not bridled.
111.18: To dream of any kind of metal-tool is a good omen, with the exception of the hoe, the mattock and the axe ; but this applies only when he sees them with their handles.
111.19: To dream of any kind of fruit is a good omen with the exception of unripe dates.
111.20: To dream of any kind of vegetables is a good omen with the exception of turnipheads.
111.22: I did not become rich until I dreamt of turnip-heads !
111.23: When he saw them, he saw them on their stem.
111.24: To dream of any kind of colour is a good omen with the exception of blue.
111.25: To dream of any kind of birds is a good omen with the exception of the owl, the horned owl and the bat.
111.26: (The body; The body ; Essence; Restore; Enlarge — mnemonic.)
111.27: Three things enter the body without its deriving any benefit therefrom ;
111.29: Three things do not enter the body, but it derives benefit therefrom :
111.32: Three things are of the essence of the world to come :
111.34: the Sabbath, the sun and tashmish.
111.36: Are we to suppose tashmish of the bed? That weakens !
111.38: Three things restore a man's [tranquillity of] mind :
111.40: Three things enlarge a man's mind:
111.41: a beautiful home, a beautiful woman and beautiful utensils.
111.43: Five things are a sixtieth part of something else :
111.44: fire, honey, the Sabbath, sleep and a dream.
111.45: Fire is a sixtieth part of Gehinnom; honey a sixtieth of manna ; the Sabbath a sixtieth of the world to come ; sleep a sixtieth of death ; a dream the sixtieth of prophecy.
111.46: Six things are a favourable symptom in an invalid :
111.47: sneezing, perspiration, abdominal motion, seminal emission, sleep and a dream.
111.49: "His sneezings flash forth light" (Job xli. 10). "Perspiration" — for it is written, "In the sweat of thy face shalt thou eat bread" (Gen, iii. 19). "Abdominal motion" — for it is written, "He that is bent down shall speedily be loosed ; and he shall not go down dying into the pit" (Is. li. 14). "Seminal emission" — for it is written, "Seeing seed, he will prolong his days" (ibid. liii. 10). "Sleep" — for it is written, "I should have slept, then had I been at rest" (Job iii. 13). "A dream" — for it is written, "Thou didst cause me to dream and make me to live" (Is. xxxviii. 16).
111.50: Six things cure an invalid from his sickness and their remedy is an [efficacious] remedy, viz. :
111.51: cabbage, beet, a decoction of dried poley, the maw, the womb and the large lobe of the liver. Some add :
111.53: more than that, small fish make a man's whole body fruitful and strong.
111.54: Ten things cause an invalid to relapse and his sickness becomes worse, viz. :
111.55: to eat the flesh of the ox, fat meat, roast meat, poultry, roasted egg ; also shaving, and partaking of cress, milk, cheese ; and bathing. Some add:
111.58: The school of R. Ishmael taught :
111.59: Why are they called "cucumbers" [kishshuim] ? Because they are injurious [kashim] to the body like swords.
111.61: For lo, it is written, "And the Lord said unto her, Two nations are in thy womb" (Gen. xxv. 23) — read not goyim "nations," but geim "lords"; and Rab Judah said in the name of Rab:
111.62: These are Antoninus and Rabbi from whose table radish, lettuce and cucumbers were never absent either in Summer or Winter !
111.63: There is no contradiction ; the large ones [are injurious], the small ones [beneficial].
111.65: [If one dreams] there is a corpse in the house, there will be peace in the house ; that he was eating and drinking in the house, it is an auspicious omen for the house ; that he took a vessel from the house, it is an inauspicious omen for the house.
111.66: Rab Pappa explained [the "vessel" to refer to] a shoe or sandal.
111.67: Everything that the corpse takes away [if seen in a dream] is auspicious with the exception of a shoe or sandal; and everything that the corpse gives is auspicious with the exception of dust and mustard.
111.68: [He who beholds] a place from which idolatry has been uprooted.
111.69: Our Rabbis have taught : (Who sees a statue of Hermes says,
111.70: "Blessed... Who hast shown long-suffering to those who transgress Thy will"),
111.71: [If he sees] a place from which idolatry has been uprooted, he should say,
111.72: "Blessed... Who hast uprooted idolatry from our land ; and as it has been uprooted from this place, so may it be uprooted from all places of Israel. And do Thou turn the heart of those who serve idols to serve Thee."
111.73: But if this is outside the Land [of Israel], it is unnecessary to say "And do Thou turn the heart of those who serve idols to serve Thee," because most of them are gentiles.
111.75: The benediction should also be uttered outside the Land, because they will in the future become converted ; as it is said, "For then will I turn to the peoples a pure language" (Zeph. iii. 9).
111.77: Who sees the wicked Babylon should utter five benedictions.
111.78: If he sees Babylon, he says "Blessed... Who hast destroyed wicked Babylon."
111.79: If he sees the palace of Nebuchadnezzar, he says
111.80: "Blessed...Who hast destroyed the palace of Nebuchadnezzar."
111.81: If he sees the den of lions or the fiery furnace, he says
111.82: "Blessed ...Who hast performed miracles for our fathers in this place."
111.83: If he sees a statue of Hermes, he says
111.84: "Blessed... Who hast shown long-suffering to those who transgress Thy will."
111.85: If he sees a place [in Babylon] from which dust is being taken away, he says
111.86: "Blessed...Who sayest and doest, Who doth decree and fulfil."
111.87: When Raba saw asses carrying this dust, he struck them upon the back with his hand and exclaimed,
111.88: "Run, ye righteous, to perform the will of your Master."
111.89: When Mar b. Rabina came to Babylon, he took up some earth in his mantle and cast it out, to fulfil that which was said, "I will sweep it with the besom of destruction" (Is. xiv. 23).
111.91: I had not heard that of Rab Hamnuna, but from my own mind I said all those benedictions.

112.1: When Babylon was cursed, her neighbours were cursed ; but when Samaria was cursed, her neighbours were blessed. When Babylon was cursed, her neighbours were cursed ;
112.2: for it is written, "I will also make it a possession for the bittern, and pools of water" (ibid.).
112.3: When Samaria was cursed, her neighbours were blessed ; for it is written, "Therefore I will make Samaria a heap in the field, a place for the planting of vineyards" (Micah i. 6).
112.5: Who beholds crowds of Israelites should say
112.7: but [on beholding] crowds of idolaters he says,
112.10: Who sees crowds of Israelites should say
112.12: because their minds differ and their faces differ.
112.13: Ben Zoma saw a crowd on top of the ascent of the Temple Mount and said,
112.14: "Blessed... Who art wise in secrets, and blessed...Who hast created all these to serve me."
112.16: How much labour Adam must have expended before he obtained bread to eat !
112.17: He ploughed, sowed, reaped, piled up the sheaves, threshed, winnowed, selected [the ears], ground, sifted [the flour], kneaded and baked, and after that he ate ; whereas I get up in the morning and find all this prepared for me.
112.18: And how much labour must Adam have expended before he obtained a garment to wear !
112.19: He sheared, washed [the wool], combed, spun, wove, and after that he obtained a garment to wear ; whereas I get up in the morning and find all this prepared for me.
112.20: All artisans attend and come to the door of my house, and I get up and find all these things before me.
112.22: What does a good guest say ? "How much trouble has my host taken on my behalf ! How much meat he set before me ! How much wine he set before me ! How many cakes he set before me ! And all the trouble he took was only for my sake."
112.23: But what does the bad guest say ? "What trouble has my host taken ?
112.24: I ate one piece of bread ; I ate one slice of meat ; I drank one cup of wine; and whatever trouble my host experienced was only for the sake of his wife and children."
112.25: What does one say concerning a good guest ? "Remember that thou magnify his work, whereof men have sung" (Job xxxvi. 24) ;
112.26: and of a bad guest it is written, "Men do therefore fear him ; he regardeth not any that are wise of heart" (ibid. xxxvii 24).
112.27: "And the man was an old man in the days of Saul, stricken in years among men" (I Sam. xvii. 12). Raba (other versions : Rab Zebid, Rab Osha'ya) said :
112.28: This refers to Jesse, the father of David, who went out with a crowd, came in with a crowd and expounded [Torah] with a crowd.
112.30: We have received a tradition that there is no crowd in Babylon.
112.32: A crowd must not consist of less than sixty myriads.
112.34: Who beholds the Sages of Israel should say, "Blessed... Who hast imparted of Thy wisdom to them that fear Thee" ; but [on beholding] the wise men of other peoples, he says "Blessed... Who hast given of Thy wisdom to Thy creatures."
112.35: Who beholds the kings of Israel should say, "Blessed... Who hast imparted of Thy glory to them that fear Thee"; but [on beholding] the kings of other peoples he says, "Blessed... Who hast imparted of Thy glory to Thy creatures."
112.37: A man should always bestir himself to run to meet the kings of Israel ; and not only the kings of Israel, but even to meet the kings of other peoples, for if he is worthy, he will distinguish between the kings of Israel and of other peoples.
112.38: Rab Sheshet was blind. Everybody went to greet a king, and Rab Sheshet arose and went with them.
112.39: A certain Min met him and said,
112.40: "Pitchers [go] to the river, where [go] the potsherds?"
112.42: "Come, see how I know things better than thou."
112.43: The first troop of soldiers passed by, and when a shout arose, the Min said to him,
112.47: A second troop passed, and when a shout arose, the Min said to him,
112.51: A third troop passed, and while there was silence, Rab Sheshet said to him,
112.55: He replied, "Earthly kingship is like the Kingship of Heaven,
112.56: of which it is written, 'Go forth, and stand upon the mount before the Lord. 116.54: and the other said to him:
116.55: This man wants to bring suffering on himself,
116.56: since it is written:(Job 3:25)" For the thing which I did fear is come upon me, and that which I was afraid of hath overtaken me."
116.58: "Happy is the man who feareth alway"?
116.59: — He replied: That is written in connection with words of Torah.
116.60: ONE WHO GOES THROUGH A CAPITAL CITY.
116.61: Our Rabbis taught: What does he say on entering?
116.62: 'May it be Thy will O Lord, my God, to bring me into this city in peace'.
116.63: When he is inside he says:
116.64: 'I give thanks to Thee, O Lord, my God, that Thou hast brought me into this city in peace'.
116.65: When he is about to leave he says:
116.66: 'May it be Thy will, O Lord, my God, and God of my fathers, to bring me out of this city in peace'.
116.67: When he is outside he says:
116.68: 'I give thanks to Thee, O Lord, my God, that Thou hast brought me out of this city in peace, and as Thou hast brought me out in peace, so mayest Thou guide me in peace and support me in peace and make me proceed in peace and deliver me from the hands of all enemies and liers-in-wait by the way'.
116.69: R. Mattena said: This applies only to a city where criminals are not tried and sentenced: but in a city where criminals are tried and sentenced, this is unnecessary.
116.70: Some report: R. Mattena said: Even in a city where criminals are tried and sentenced, for sometimes he may happen not to find a man who can plead in his defence.
116.71: Our Rabbis taught: On entering a bath-house one should say:
116.72: 'May it be Thy will O Lord, my God, to deliver me from this and from the like of this, and let no humiliation or iniquity befall me; and if I do fall into any perversity or iniquity, may my death be an atonement for all my iniquities'.
116.74: A man should not speak thus, so as not to open his mouth for the Satan.
116.75: For Resh Lakish said-and so it was taught in the name of R. Jose:
116.76: A man should never open his mouth for the Satan.
116.78: What text proves this? Because it is written (Isaiah 1:9), "We should have been as Sodom, we should have been like unto Gomorrah."  What did the prophet answer them? Hear the word of the Lord, ye rulers of Sodom, etc.
116.79: On leaving the bath-house what does he say?
116.81: 'I give thanks unto Thee, O Lord, my God, that Thou hast delivered me from the fire'.
116.82: R. Abbahu once went into the bathhouse and the floor of the bath-house gave way beneath him, and a miracle was wrought for him, and he stood on a pillar and rescued a hundred and one men with one arm. He said:
116.83: This is what R. Aha meant.
116.84: On going in to be cupped one should say:
116.85: 'May it be Thy will, O Lord, my God, that this operation may be a cure for me, and mayest Thou heal me, for Thou art a faithful healing God, and Thy healing is sure, since men have no power to heal, but this is a habit with them'
116.87: A man should not speak thus, since it was taught in the school of R. Ishmael: [It is written](Exodus 21:19)
116.88: "He shall cause him to be thoroughly healed" From this we learn that permission has been given to the physician to heal.
116.89: When he gets up [after cupping] what does he say?
116.91: Blessed be He who heals without payment.
116.92: [It is written,] "Only he shall pay for the loss of his time, and shall cause him to be thoroughly healed" (Exod. xxi. 19) ; from this [it follows] that a physician is given permission [by God] to cure.
116.93: When he rises [from the cupping], what does he say?
116.95: "Blessed be He Who heals without pay."

117.24: "O my God, the soul which Thou hast given me is pure. So long as the soul is within me, I will give thanks unto Thee, O Lord my God and God of my fathers, Sovereign of all worlds, Lord of all souls. 117.55: A man is in duty bound, etc.

117.59: For good tidings he says "Who art good and dispensest good" and For bad tidings he says "Blessed be the true Judge"!

117.62: R. Aha said in the name of R. Levi:
117.63: What is the Scriptural authority? "I will sing of mercy and justice ; unto Thee, O Lord, will I sing praises" (Ps. ci. 1) — if it be mercy, I will sing ; and if it be justice, I will sing.
117.65: It may be derived from the following: "In the Lord, I will praise His word ; in God, I will praise His word" (ibid. Ivi. 11) — "In the Lord, I will praise His word" refers to His attribute of goodness; "In God, I will praise His word" refers to His attribute of retribution.
117.67: It may be derived from the following : "I will lift up the cup of salvation and call upon the name of the Lord" (ibid. cxvi. 13) [and] "I found trouble and sorrow, but I called upon the name of the Lord" (ibid. vv. 3f).
117.68: The Rabbis say : It may be derived from the following : "The Lord gave, and the Lord hath taken away ; blessed be the name of the Lord" (Job i. 21).

117.70: A man should always accustom himself to say, "Whatever the All-merciful does, He does for the best."
117.71: As when R.'Akiba was journeying by the way, he came to a certain town and asked for hospitality, but it was refused him ;
117.72: so he exclaimed, "Whatever the All - merciful does is for the best."

117.74: A gust of wind came and extinguished the lamp, a cat came and ate the cock, and a lion came and devoured the ass ;
117.76: "Whatever the All-merciful does is for the best."

118.1: Rab Huna stated that Rab said in the name of R. Meir :
118.2: A man's words should always be few before the Holy One, blessed be He ; as it is said, "Be not rash with thy mouth, and let not thy heart be hasty to utter a word before God ; for God is in heaven, and thou upon earth, therefore let thy words be few" (Eccles. v. 1).
118.3: Rab Nahman b. Rab Hisda expounded :
118.4: What means that which is written, "Then the Lord God formed man" (Gen. ii. 7), the word wayyiser "and He formed" being spelt with two letters yod? The Holy One, blessed be He, created two impulses, one good and the other evil.
118.6: Therefore since the word wayyiser is not mentioned in connection with the animal it has no evil impulse,
118.7: and yet we see it injuring and biting and kicking !
118.8: Nay [the double yod is to be explained] according to the statement of R. Simeon b. Pazzi who said :
118.9: Woe to me because of my Creator [yoseri], and woe to me because of my impulse [yisri].
118.11: according to the statement of R. Jeremiah b. Eleazar who said :
118.12: The Holy One, blessed be He, made Adam with two faces ; as it is said, "Behind and before hast Thou formed me" (Ps. cxxxix. 5).
118.13: "And the rib, which the Lord God had taken from the man, made He a woman" (Gen. ii. 22). Rab and Samuel [comment upon this] :
118.15: it was a face [from which Eve was made] ; the other declared that
118.16: it was a tail. It is right according to him who says that it was a face; that is what is written, "Behind and before hast Thou formed me." But according to him who said it was a tail, what means "Behind and before hast Thou formed me"? It is [to be explained]
118.17: according to the statement of R. Ammi who said :
118.18: "Behind" refers to the work of creation, "before" to retribution.
118.19: It is right that "behind" may refer to the work of creation, for Adam was not created until the eve of the Sabbath ; but that "before" refers to retribution — retribution for what?
118.20: Are we to suppose the punishment of the serpent-incident? Lo, there is a teaching : Rabbi says :
118.21: With [the award of] greatness we begin with the most important ; but with a curse, we begin with the least important.
118.22: With greatness we begin with the most important — for it is written, "And Moses spoke unto Aaron, and unto Eleazar and unto Ithamar, his sons that were left, Take the meal-offering that remaineth" etc. (Lev, x. 12).
118.23: With a curse we begin with the least important — first the serpent was cursed, then Eve and then Adam!
118.24: Nay, the retribution in connection with the flood [is referred to] ; for it is written, "And He blotted out every living substance which was upon the face of the ground, both man and cattle" (Gen. vii. 23).
118.25: It is quite right according to him who says that [Eve was created from] a face ; that is what is written wayyiser "And He formed," spelt with a double yod. But according to him who said that it was from a tail, what means wayyiser?
118.26: It is [to be explained] according to the statement of R. Simeon b. Pazzi who said :
118.27: Woe to me because of my Creator and woe to me because of my impulse.
118.28: It is quite right according to him who says that it was a face ; that is what is written, "Male and female created He them" (Gen. 5:2). But according to him who said it was a tail, what means "Male and female created He them"? It is [to be explained]
118.29: according to R. Abbahu who asked :
118.30: It is written "Male and female created He them," and it is written, "For in the image of God made He man" (ibid. ix. 6).
118.31: How is this? At first He planned to create two, but in the end only one was created.
118.32: It is quite right according to him who says it was a face ; that is what is written, "He closed up the place with flesh instead thereof " (ibid. ii. 21). But according to him who said it was a tail, what means "He closed up the place with flesh instead thereof"?
118.33: R. Jeremiah (other versions : Rab Zebid ; Rab Nahman b. Isaac) said :
118.34: That was only necessary in the place of the wound.
118.35: It is quite right according to him who said it was a tail ; that is what is written, "And He made [lit. built]" (ibid. v. 22). But according to him who said it was a face, what means "He made"?
118.36: It is [to be explained] according to R. Simeon b. Menasya who expounded :
118.37: What means, "And the rib which the Lord God had taken from the man, made He [banah] a woman"? It teaches that the Holy One, blessed be He, plaited her hair and brought her [adorned] to Adam ; for so in the sea-towns they call plaits binyata.
118.39: of "And He made [lit. built]" — Rab Hisda said (another version : It was taught in a Baraita) :
118.40: This means that the Holy One, blessed be He, fashioned Eve like a store-building ; as the store is narrow above and broad below so as to receive the fruits, similarly is a woman narrow above and broad below so as to receive the child.
118.41: "And He brought her unto the man" (ibid.). R. Jeremiah b. Eleazar said :
118.42: This means that the Holy One, blessed be He, constituted Himself Adam's "best man";
118.43: hence the Torah teaches a rule of conduct, viz. : that an eminent man should accompany one of less importance as "best man," and it will not injure [his dignity].
118.44: According to him who said [Eve was made from] a face, which of them went in front?
118.46: It is more probable that the masculine countenance went in front ; for there is a teaching :
118.47: A man should never walk behind a woman along the road, even his own wife. Should a woman meet him on a bridge he should let her pass by on the side ; and whoever crosses a stream behind a woman will have no portion in the world to come.
118.49: He who pays money to a woman counting it from his hand into hers for the sake of gazing at her, even if he possess Torah and good deeds like Moses our teacher, he will not escape the punishment of Gehinnom ; as it is said, "Hand to hand the evil man shall not be unpunished" (Prov. xi. 21) — he shall not escape the punishment of Gehinnom.
118.51: Manoah was an 'Am ha'ares; for it is written, "And Manoah went after his wife" (Judges xiii. 11).
118.53: But that is likewise true of Elisha ; for it is written, "And he arose and followed her" (II Kings iv. 30) — here also he actually walked behind her !
118.54: Nay ; [it means that Elisha] followed her words and advice, and so also [in the instance of Manoah] he followed her words and advice.
118.56: With reference to what Rab Nahman said, viz. that Manoah was an 'Am ha'ares, he had not even learnt [the Scriptures which are taught] in an elementary school; as it is said, "And Rebekah arose, and her damsels, and they rode upon the camels, and followed the man" (Gen. xxiv. 61) — they went behind the man, not in front of him.
118.58: A man should walk behind a lion rather than behind a woman, behind a woman rather than behind an idolater, behind an idolater rather than behind a Synagogue when the Congregation is at prayer.
118.59: But this last is only meant when he is not carrying a load ; should he, however, be carrying a load, there is no objection. It is only meant when there is no other entrance ; but should there be another entrance, there is no objection. It is further only meant when he is not riding upon an ass ; but should he be riding upon an ass, there is no objection. It is likewise only meant when he is not wearing Tefillin ; but if he is wearing Tefillin, there is no objection.
118.61: The evil impulse is like a fly and dwells between the  two entrances of the heart ; as it is said, "Dead flies make the ointment of the perfumers fetid and putrid" (Eccles. x. 1).
118.63: It is like a kind of wheat [hittah] ; as it is said, "Sin [hatt'at] croucheth at the door" (Gen. iv. 7).
118.65: There are two reins in man, one prompting him to good, the other to evil.
118.66: It is probable that the good is on the right side and the bad on the left ; for it is written, "A wise man's understanding is at his right hand; but a fool's understanding at his left" (Eccles. x. 2).
118.68: The reins prompt [the thought], the heart exercises intelligence, the tongue pronounces, the mouth completes [the words]. The gullet lets in and brings out all kinds of food, the windpipe produces voice,

119.0: the lungs absorb all kinds of liquids, the liver arouses anger, the gall lets a drop fall upon it and stills it, the milt produces laughter, the large intestine grinds [food], the maw induces sleep and the nose awakens. Should the organ which induces sleep arouse from sleep,
119.1: or should the organ which arouses from sleep induce sleep, the person pines away.
119.3: Should both of them induce sleep or arouse from sleep simultaneously, one immediately dies.
119.4: There is a teaching : R. Jose of Galilee says :
119.5: The good impulse controls the righteous ; as it is said, "My heart is wounded within me" (Ps. cix. 22).
119.6: The evil impulse controls the wicked ; as it is said, "Transgression speaketh to the wicked, in the midst of the heart, There is no fear of God before his eyes" (ibid, xxxvi. 2). Both impulses control average people ; as it is said, "Because He standeth at the right hand of the needy, to save him from them that judge his soul" (Ps. cix. 31).
119.8: "The average people are, for instance, ourselves."
119.10: "The master does not leave life for any creature!"
119.12: The universe was only created for the completely wicked or the completely righteous. Raba said :
119.13: Let a man know himself whether he is completely righteous or not.
119.15: The universe was only created for Ahab the son of Omri and for R. Hannina b. Dosa —
119.16: for Ahab the son of Omri, this world; and for R. Hannina b. Dosa, the world to come.
119.18: We learned in a Braita: Rabbi Eliezer says
119.19: If we say with all your life, why do we say with all your wealth?
119.20: And if you say with all your wealth, why do you say with all your life?
119.22: If there is a person who values their body more than their money, therefore it says "with all your life", and if there is a person whose money is more important than his body therefore it says "with all your wealth"
119.24: "With all your life", this means even to take your own life.
119.25: The Rabbis taught in a braita"
119.26: Once upon a time, the evil empire decreed that the Jews could not deal with studying Torah. Came Papus the son of Yehuda and found Rabbi Akiva who was gathering large groups in public and learning Torah.
119.28: Akiva, are you not scared of the government?

119.31: from what are you running away?
119.33: from the nets that people are throwing upon us
119.35: What you want is to rise up on the dry land, and you and I will live the way that our ancestors lived
119.37: You are the one that people say are the wisest of all the animals.
119.38: You are not wise, rather you are dumb.
119.39: In a place where we live, we are fearful, in a place where we will die, even more so (we will be fearful)
119.40: (Rabbi Akiva talks now) So too we, now are sitting and learning Torah, as it says: "For Torah is your life and a way to live a long time", therefore if we veer away and stop learning Torah, even more so we will die.
119.42: It was only a few days until they caught Rabbi Akiva and tied him up in jail. They caught Papus the son of Yehuda and tied him up.
119.46: He said to him (Papus said to Akiva)

119.55: A heavenly voice came out and said:
119.56: Praiseworthy are you Rabbi Akiva, that your soul left your body at "One"
119.57: The angels in heaven said to Gd:
119.58: This is Torah? This is its reward?!
119.59: From men, by Thy hand, O LORD, From men of the world, whose portion is in this life
119.62: A heavenly voice came out and said
119.63: Praiseworthy are you Rabbi Akiva, that you are invited to the world to come.

119.65: Rab Judah said in the name of Rab :

119.67: It has been similarly reported : R. Abba b. R. Hijya. b. Abba said : Thus declared R. Johanan :

119.71: R. Jose, however, permits it [in any direction] because he used to say that

120.4: "Wert thou so impudent with thy master?"
120.6: "It was a matter of Torah and I wished to learn."

120.9: I learnt that we should not evacuate East or West, but North or South. I learnt that we should not expose ourselves standing but sitting. I also learnt that we should not wipe ourselves with the right hand but with the left.
120.11: "Wert thou so impudent with thy master?"
120.13: "It was a matter of Torah and I wished to learn."

120.16: "Abba's mouth is like that of one who has never sipped a dish."
120.19: Go out ; for it is not proper!"
120.21: "It is a matter of Torah and I wished to learn."

120.25: as it is said, "At His right hand was a fiery law unto them" (Deut. xxxiii. 2).
120.27: Because it is near the mouths.
120.29: Because he binds the Tefillin with it.
120.31: Because he points to the accents of the Torah with it.

120.37: Because he points to the accents of the Torah with it.

120.40: from serpents, scorpions and evil spirits ;
120.41: some say : Also his dreams will be such that his mind will be set at ease.
120.42: There was a privy in Tiberias which if two people entered, even by day, they came to harm. R. Ammi and R. Assi entered it separately and no harm befell them.
120.46: "We were taught a charm: a charm for the privy is modesty and silence ; a charm against sufferings is silence and prayer,"
120.47: Abbai reared a lamb to accompany him into the privy.
120.48: But he should have roared a goat!
120.49: A satyr may be changed into a goat.
120.50: Before Raba was appointed Principal [of the Seminary], the daughter of Rab Hisda used to rattle a nut in a flask for him; but afterwards when he ruled [over the Seminary] she made an aperture for him [in the wall] and placed her hand upon his head.
120.52: Behind a fence one may ease himself immediately; but in an open place [he may do it] so long as he can break wind without anybody hearing it.
120.53: Issi b. Nathan taught as follows : Behind a fence [he may ease himself] so long as he can break wind without anybody hearing, but in an open place so long as nobody sees him.
120.55: They may go out from the entrance of the olive-press and ease themselves behind a fence, and they remain in a state of ritual purity !
120.56: They take a more lenient view in connection with [those who supervise] ritual purity.
120.58: [It has been taught:] To what distance may they go and remain clean? So long as one can see them!
120.59: It is different with food-stuffs whose purity [must be supervised], because the Rabbis take a more lenient view in such a case.
120.61: What means "so long as nobody sees him," as stated by Issi b. Nathan? So long as his neighbour cannot see the exposed part of the body, but he may see the man himself.
120.62: A certain funeral-orator who went down [to deliver an address] in the presence of Rab Nahman said,
120.63: "How modest was [the deceased] in his habits!"
120.65: "Didst thou ever go into a privy with him that thou knowest whether he was modest or not?
120.66: For there is a teaching : He only is called modest who is so in a privy."
120.67: But what had Rab Nahman to care about in this matter?
120.68: Because there is a teaching : As the dead are called to account [for their deeds], so are the funeral-orators and they who respond ["Amen"] after them called to account.
120.70: Who is modest ? He who relieves himself at night in the same place where he relieves himself by day.
120.72: For lo, Rab Judah said in the name of Rab :
120.73: A man should always accustom himself [to perform his natural functions] morning and evening so that it will be unnecessary for him to go far [and find a secluded spot].
120.74: And further, Raba used to go as far as a Mil by day ; but at night he would say to his attendant,
120.75: "Prepare for me a place in the street of the town."
120.76: Similarly used R. Zera to say to his attendant,
120.77: "See whether there is anybody behind the Seminary, as I wish to relieve myself"!
120.78: Read not [in the Baraita] "in the same place," but read "in the same manner that he relieves himself by day."
120.80: Even if thou retainest the words "the same place" [there is no contradiction, because it means,] it is only necessary [to proceed] to a corner.
120.81: It was stated above : "Rab Judah said in the name of Rab :
120.82: A man should always accustom himself [to perform his natural functions] morning and evening, so that it will be unnecessary for him to go far [and find a secluded spot]."
120.83: There is a teaching to the same effect : Ben 'Azzai says :
120.84: Rise early and go out, and act likewise after dusk so that thou needest not go a distance ;
120.85: feel the need and then sit down, but do not sit down and then [wait to] feel the need, for whoever does so, even should they practise sorcery in Aspamia it will befall him.
120.86: But should he through forgetfulness act thus, what is his remedy ?
120.87: On rising, let him say as follows,
120.88: "Not to me, not to me ; no Tahim and no Tahtim ; not these and not from these ; no charms of a sorcerer and no charms of a sorceress."

121.0: There is a teaching : Ben 'Azzai says :
121.1: Lie upon any couch but not on the floor ; sit upon any seat except a beam.
121.3: Sleeping at dawn is like a steel edge to iron ; evacuation at dawn is like a steel edge to iron.
121.4: Bar Kappara used to sell proverbs for denarii :
121.5: "While thou art hungry, eat ; while thou art thirsty, drink ; while the cauldron is still hot, pour out."
121.6: "When the horn is sounded in [the market of] Rome, O son of a fig-seller, sell thy father's figs."
121.8: When you pass through the alleys of a town to go into the country, look neither to the one side nor the other, lest women be sitting there, and it is not proper to gaze at them.
121.9: Rab Safra entered a privy. R. Abba came and emitted a sound at the door. Rab Safra said to him,
121.11: After leaving, R. Abba said to him,
121.12: "So far thou hast not brought in the demon ; but thou hast received the tradition about the demon.
121.13: Have we not learnt thus in the Mishnah :
121.14: There was an open fire-place there [in the Temple-court], and a splendid privy ; and this was its splendid feature :
121.15: if it was found locked, it was known that somebody was in there, but if it was found open, it was known that it was vacant.
121.17: it is not proper [to speak in a privy]!
121.19: it was dangerous; for there is a teaching : Rabban Simeon b. Gamaliel says :
121.20: If the fecal discharge is kept back it causes dropsy,
121.21: and if the fluid in the urinary duct is kept back it causes jaundice.
121.22: R. Eleazar entered a privy ; a certain Roman came and pushed him. R. Eleazar got up and went out ;
121.23: and a serpent came and tore out the [Roman's] gut. R. Eleazar applied to him the verse :
121.24: "Therefore will I give a man under thee" (Is. xliii. 4) — read not adam "a man" but Edom "an Edomite."
121.25: "And he said to kill thee, but it spared thee" (I Sam. xxiv. 11). "And he said"!
121.26: It ought to be "And I said";
121.28: It ought to be "but I spared."
121.29: R. Eleazar said : Thus spake David to Saul,
121.30: "According to the Torah, thou art liable to be put to death, because thou art a pursuer ; and the Torah declares that
121.31: if one comes to kill thee, kill him first.
121.32: But the modesty which is manifest in thee has spared thee." In what did [Saul's modesty] consist? For it is written, "And he came to the sheep-cotes by the way, where was a cave ; and Saul went in to cover his feet" (ibid. 5:4).
121.34: it was a fence within a fence and a cave within a cave.
121.36: This teaches that he covered himself like a booth.
121.37: "Then David arose, and cut off the skirt of Saul's robe privily" (ibid. 5:5).
121.38: R. Jose b. R. Hannina said :
121.39: Whoever deals contemptuously with garments will in the end derive no benefit from them ; as it is said, "Now King David was old and stricken in years ; and they covered him with clothes but he could get no heat" (I Kings i. 1).
121.40: "If it be the Lord that hath stirred thee up against me, let Him accept an offering" (I Sam. xxvi. 19). R. Eleazar said:
121.41: Thus spake the Holy One, blessed be He, to David, Thou callest Me a "stirrer-up,"
121.42: behold I will cause thee to stumble in a matter which even school-children know ; for it is written, "When thou takest the sum of the children of Israel, according to their number, then shall they give every man a ranson for his soul unto the Lord... that there be no plague among them, when thou numberest them" (Exod. xxx. 12).
121.43: Immediately "Satan stood up against Israel" (I Chron. xxi. 1); for it is written, "He stirred up David against them, saying, Go, number Israel and Judah" (II Sam. xxiv. 1).
121.44: But when he numbered them, he took no ransom from them ; and it is written, "So the Lord sent a pestilence upon Israel from the morning even to the time appointed" (ibid. v. 15).
121.46: Samuel the Elder, the son-in-law of R. Hannina, said in the name of R. Hannina :
121.47: From the time of slaying the continual offering until the time of the sprinkling of the blood.
121.50: "And He said to the angel that destroyed the people, It is enough [rab]" (ibid. v. 16). R. Eleazar said: Thus spake the Holy One, blessed be He, to the angel,
121.51: Take for me the chief [rab] among them, so that through him I can punish them for their sins.
121.52: At that moment Abishai b. Zeruiah died, who was equal [in worth] to the majority of the Sanhedrin.
121.53: "And as he was about to destroy, the Lord beheld, and He repented Him" (I Chron. xxi. 15). What did He behold?
121.55: He beheld our father Jacob ; for it is written, "And Jacob said when he beheld them" (Gen. xxxii. 3).
121.57: He beheld the ashes of [the sacrifice substituted for] Isaac ; as it is said, "God will provide Himself the lamb" (ibid. xxii. 8).
121.59: He beheld the money of the atonement; as it is said, "And thou shalt take the atonement money from the children of Israel" etc. (Exod. xxx. 16).
121.61: He beheld the Temple ; for it is written, "In the mount where the Lord is seen" (Gen. xxii. 14).
121.62: R. Jacob b. Iddi and R. Samuel b. Nahmani differ in this matter; one declaring that
121.63: He beheld the atonement money, the other declaring that
121.65: The more probable view is that of him who said that He beheld the Sanctuary ; because it is said, "As it is said to this day, In the mount where the Lord is seen."
121.66: Nor may one enter the Temple Mount with his staff"...; nor may he use it as a short cut [koppendaria].
121.69: A short cut, as the word implies.
121.70: But Rab Hanna b. Adda said in the name of Rab Samma b. R. Mari:
121.71: It is as people say, "Instead of going round the row of houses, I will go through it"
121.72: Rab Nahman said in the name of Rabbah b. Abbuha:
121.73: If one enters a Synagogue not for the purpose of making it a short cut, he may use it in that manner.
121.75: If it was originally a public path, it is permitted [as a short cut for all].
121.76: R. Helbo said in the name of Rab Huna:
121.77: Who enters a Synagogue to pray is allowed to use it as a short cut ; as it is said, "But when the people of the land shall come before the Lord in the appointed seasons, he that entereth by the way of the north gate to worship shall go forth by the way of the south gate" (Ezek. xlvi. 9).
121.78: And to expectorate on the Temple Mount is forbidden a fortiori.
121.79: Rab Bebai said in the name of R. Joshua b. Levi :
121.80: Whoever expectorates on the Temple Mount in this time is as though he expectorates into the pupil of his eye; as it is said, "And Mine eyes and My heart shall be there perpetually" (I Kings ix. 3).
121.82: Expectoration is allowed in a Synagogue, because it is analogous to [the wearing of] a shoe —
121.83: just as [the wearing of] a shoe is prohibited on the Temple Mount but is permitted in a Synagogue, so is expectoration forbidden on the Temple Mount but permitted in a Synagogue.
121.84: Rab Pappa said to Raba (other versions : Rabina to Raba ; Rab Adda b. Mattena to Raba) :
121.85: Why should one derive it [by analogy] from a shoe ; let him derive it from the short cut !
121.87: The Tanna derives it from the shoe, and thou sayest [it should be derived] from the short cut —
121.90: A man must not enter the Temple Mount with his staff in his hand, his shoe upon his foot, and his money tied up in his cloth or in his money-bag thrown over his shoulder, nor may he make it a short cut ; and [the prohibition of] expectoration is derived a fortiori from the shoe — as in the case of a shoe which is not in itself contemptible the Torah declares, "Put off thy shoes from off thy feet" (Exod. iii. 5), must not expectoration, which is in itself contemptible, be all the more forbidden !
121.92: [This reasoning] is unnecessary ; for it is stated, "For none might enter within the king's gate clothed with sackcloth" (Esther iv. 2) — and is there not here an a fortiori deduction :
121.93: If it is thus with sackcloth which is not a disgusting thing in the presence of human beings, must not expectoration, which is disgusting in the presence of the supreme King of kings, be all the more prohibited !
121.94: [Rab Pappa] answered : This is the position I take up :
121.95: Let us derive a strict conclusion from the instance, [of the shoe] and also from the instance [of the short cut]

122.1: with reference to the Temple Mount where [the wearing of] a shoe is forbidden, let one derive [the prohibition against expectoration] from a shoe; but with reference to the Synagogue where one is permitted [to wear] shoes, instead of deriving permission [to expectorate, by analogy] from a shoe, let him derive a prohibition [against expectoration, by analogy] from the short cut !
122.4: is analogous to his own house — as a man is concerned about anybody using his house as a short cut but is not concerned about expectoration or [the wearing of] shoes, so also with the Synagogue,
122.5: as a short cut it is prohibited, but expectoration and [the wearing of] shoes are allowed.
122.6: At the conclusion of every benediction in the Sanctuary they used to say "For ever," etc.
122.7: "Why all this? Because the response "Amen" was never made in the Sanctuary.
122.8: Whence is it that "Amen" was never used as a response in the Sanctuary? As it is said, "Stand up and bless the Lord your God from everlasting to everlasting" (Nehem. ix. 5),
122.9: and it continues, "And let them say: Blessed be Thy glorious Name, that is exalted above all blessing and praise" (ibid).
122.10: It is possible to think that all benedictions should have one praise; therefore there is a teaching to state, "Above all blessing and praise" — for each benediction give Him praise.
122.11: It was further ordained that a man should greet his friends by mentioning the Divine Name, etc.
122.14: Boaz mentioned [the Divine Name in his salutation] of his own accord, come and hear: "The Lord is with thee, thou mighty man of valour" (Judges vi. 12).
122.16: it was an angel that spake to Gideon, come and hear : "Despise not thy mother when she is old" (Prov. xxiii. 22).
122.17: And it is stated, "It is time for the Lord to work ; they have made void Thy Law" (Ps. cxix. 126).
122.19: This verse is to be explained from the first clause to the second, and from the second to the first.
122.20: It is to be explained from the first clause to the second, thus :
122.21: "It is time for the Lord to work" ; why? Because "they have made void Thy Law."
122.22: It is to be explained from the second to the first, thus:
122.23: "They have made void Thy Law"; why? Because "It is time for the Lord to work."
122.24: There is a teaching : Hillel the Elder says :
122.25: When people collect [learning], do thou scatter ; when they scatter [learning], do thou collect.
122.26: If thou seest a generation to which Torah is dear, do thou scatter ; as it is said, "There is that scattereth, and yet increaseth" (Prov. xi. 24); but if thou seest a generation to which Torah is not dear, do thou collect ; as it is said, "It is time for the Lord to work ; they have made void Thy Law."
122.28: "If goods are cheap, hasten and buy them." "In a place where there is no man, be a man."
122.29: Abbai said ; Infer from this that
122.30: where there is a man, do not be a man.
122.32: No, it is necessary for the case where the two of them are of equal standing.
122.34: Which is a brief Scriptural passage upon which all the principles of the Torah depend? "In all thy ways acknowledge Him, and He will direct thy paths" (ibid. iii. 6).
122.36: Even for a matter of transgression.
122.38: A man should always teach his son a clean and light trade.
122.42: There is a teaching: Rabbi says :
122.43: A man should never multiply friends in his house; as it is said, "There are friends that one hath to his own hurt" (Prov. xviii. 24).
122.44: There is a teaching : Rabbi says :
122.45: Let not a man appoint a steward over his house ; for if Potiphar had not appointed Joseph steward over his house, he would not have experienced the incident [of his wife's temptation].
122.46: There is a teaching : Rabbi says :
122.47: Why does the section of the Nazirite adjoin the section of the woman suspected of adultery? To tell thee that whoever sees such a woman in her disgrace should separate himself from wine.
122.48: Hezekiah b. R. Parnak said in the name of R. Parnak in the name of R. Johanan :
122.49: Why does the section of the woman suspected of adultery adjoin the section of the offerings and tithes ? To tell thee that
122.50: whoever has offerings and tithes and does not hand them to the priest will in the end require the services of a priest in the matter of his wife; as it is said, "And every man's hallowed things shall be his" (Num. v. 10) and next to it is, "If any man's wife go aside" (ibid. v. 12).
122.51: Not only that, but in the end he will be in need of the offerings and tithes ; as it is said, "And every man's hallowed things shall be his."
122.53: Should he duly hand them over, in the end he will grow rich ; as it is said, "Whatever any man giveth the priest, it shall be his" (Num. v. 10) — i.e. much wealth shall be his.
122.54: Rab Huna b. Berekiah said in the name of R. Eleazar ha-Kappar :
122.55: Whoever associates the name of Heaven with his trouble, his substance will be doubled for him ; as it is said, "And the Almighty be thy treasure, and precious silver unto thee" (Job xxii. 25).
122.57: His sustenance will fly to him like a bird ; as it is said, "And precious silver unto thee."
122.58: R. Tabi said in the name of Josiah :
122.59: Whoever relaxes from words of Torah will have no strength to stand in the day of trouble; as it is said, "If thou faint in the day of adversity, thy strength is small indeed" (Prov. xxiv. 10).
122.60: R. Ammi b. Mattenah said in the name of Samuel :
122.61: Even [if he relax from] a single commandment ; as it is said, "If thou faint" — i.e. in any single instance.
122.62: Rab Safra said : R. Abbahu related that
122.63: when Hananyah, the nephew of R. Joshua, went to the Diaspora, he used to intercalate the years and fix the new moons outside the [Holy] Land.
122.64: They sent two disciples of the wise to him, R. Jose b. Kippar, and the grandson of Zechariah b. Kabutal.
122.65: When he saw them, he asked,
122.70: "These men are the famous men of the generation and their fathers ministered in the Temple ; as we have learnt :
122.72: 'Often have I read from the Book of Daniel before [the High Priest]'."
122.73: Hananyah began to declare certain things unclean, and they pronounced them clean ; he forbade certain things, and they declared them permissible.
122.75: "These men are worthless and men of no standing [and their fathers defiled the High Priesthood]."
122.77: "Thou hast already built up [our reputation here] and thou canst not pull down ; thou hast already raised a fence and thou canst not make a breach."
122.79: "Why, when I declare something unclean, do you pronounce it clean, and when I forbid you permit?"
122.81: "Why dost thou intercalate years and fix new moons outside the [Holy] Land?"
122.85: "Keep R. 'Akiba out of it, because he left not his equal in the land of Israel."
122.87: "I also have not left my equal in the land of Israel."
122.89: "The kids which thou didst leave behind have grown into goats with horns; and they have sent us to thee, saying to us
122.91: if he obeys, well and good ; but if not, let him be excommunicated.

123.0: Tell also our brethren in the Diaspora;
123.1: if they obey, well and good ; but if not, let them ascend a mountain, let Ahiyyah build an altar and Hananyah play the harp, and let them all repudiate [their Judaism], declaring that
123.2: they have no lot with the God of Israel'."
123.3: Immediately all the people broke forth into loud weeping and said,
123.5: We have a lot with the God of Israel."
123.7: Because it is said, "For out of Zion shall go forth the law, and the word of the Lord from Jerusalem" (Is. ii. 3).
123.8: It is quite right that Hananyah declared something unclean and they pronounced it clean ; that is merely taking the stricter view. But how could he declare anything unclean and they pronounce it clean?
123.9: For lo, there is a teaching:
123.10: If a Sage declares anything unclean, his colleague is not allowed to pronounce it clean ; and if he declares it forbidden, his colleague is not allowed to pronounce it permissible!
123.12: so that the people may not be led by him.
123.14: When our Rabbis entered the vineyard of Jabneh, there were present R. Judah, R. Jose, R. Nehemiah and R. Eliezer, the son of R. Jose of Galilee. They all began to expound Torah in honour of the hospitality [which had been extended to them].
123.15: R. Judah, the chief of orators in every place, began with the honour of the Torah and expounded :
123.16: "Now Moses used to take the tent and pitch it without the camp" (Exod. xxxiii. 7). Can we not use here an a fortiori argument : If of the Ark of God, which was never more than twelve Mil distant, the Torah declares,
123.17: "Everyone that sought the Lord went out unto the tent of meeting, which was without the camp" (ibid.), how much more so, the disciples of the wise who go from city to city and from province to province to study Torah!
123.18: "And the Lord spoke unto Moses face to face" (ibid. v. 11).
123.20: The Holy One, blessed be He, spake unto Moses,
123.21: "Moses, I and thou will discuss aspects of Halakah."
123.22: Another version : Thus spake the Holy One, blessed be He, unto Moses,
123.23: "In the same manner that I have shown thee a cheerful countenance, do thou likewise show Israel a cheerful countenance, and restore the tent to its place."
123.24: "And he would return into the camp" etc. (ibid.).
123.25: R. Abbahu said : The Holy One, blessed be He, spake to Moses,
123.26: "Now will they say, The Master is angry and the disciple is angry; what will become of Israel?
123.27: If thou wilt restore the tent to its place [within the camp], well and good ; but if not, Joshua the son of Nun, thy disciple, will minister in thy stead."
123.28: That is what is written, "And he would return into the camp."
123.30: Nevertheless the word did not go forth from Him in vain ; as it is said, "But his minister Joshua, the son of Nun, a young man, departed not out of the tent" (ibid.).
123.31: And Rabbi Yehudah further interpreted in honor of Torah and explained
123.32: (Deuteronomy 27:9): “Pay attention and listen, Israel, this day, you have become a people.”
123.33: Was it on this day that Torah was given to Israel?
123.34: Was it not on that day that was at the end of the forty years [of wandering? This seems to be a contradiction! How can Israel be made a people twice?]
123.35: Rather, this comes to teach you
123.36: that Torah is beloved for those who learn it every day. And [therefore] every day is like it was given on Mt. Sinai.
123.37: R. Tanhum b. R. Hiyya, of the town of Acco, said :
123.38: Thou mayest know from this that should a man recite the Shema' morning and evening, but omit it a single evening, he is like one who has never recited it at all.
123.39: "Attend [hasket]" — i.e. "form classes" and occupy yourselves with Torah, because Torah is only acquired in a class.
123.40: This is in accord with the statement of R. Jose b. R. Hannina who said :
123.41: What means that which is written, "A sword is upon the boasters [baddim] and they shall become fools" (Jer. 1. 36)? A sword is upon the enemies of the disciples of the wise who sit separately [bad wa-bad] and study Torah.
123.42: Not only so, but they become foolish ; for it is written here "And they shall become fools" and in another passage it is written, "For that we have done foolishly" (Num. xii. 11).
123.44: If thou wilt I can quote the following: "The princes of Zoan are become fools" (Is. xix. 13).
123.46: "Attend [hasket] and hear, O Israel" (Deut. xxvii. 9) — i.e. submit to blows [kattetu] on behalf of the words of Torah ; according to the statement of R. Simeon b. Lakish
123.48: Whence is it learnt that the words of Torah endure only with him who would suffer death on its behalf? As it is said, "This is the law : when a man dieth in a tent" (Num. xix. 14).
123.50: "Attend [hasket] and hear, O Israel": Be silent [has] and then discuss [kattet];
123.51: according to the statement of Raba who said :
123.52: A man should always study Torah first and afterwards meditate thereon.
123.53: The school of R. Jannai said :
123.54: What means that which is written, "For the churning of milk bringeth forth curd, and the wringing of the nose bringeth forth blood ; so the forcing of wrath bringeth forth strife" (Prov. xxx. 33)?
123.55: With whom dost thou find the cream of Torah? With him who spat out for its sake the milk which he sucked from his mother's breast.
123.56: "And the wringing of the nose bringeth forth blood" — a disciple with whom his master is the first time angry but he remains silent [under the rebuke] is worthy to distinguish between impure and pure blood.
123.57: "So the forcing of wrath bringeth forth strife" — a disciple with whom his master is the first and second time angry but he remains silent [under the rebuke] is worthy to distinguish between suits involving money and suits involving life.
123.58: For there is a Mishnaic teaching: R. Ishmael says :
123.59: Who wishes to grow wise should study money-suits, for there is no branch of Torah more [complex] than these ; they are like a well.
123.61: What means that which is written, "If thou hast done foolishly in lifting up thyself, or if thou hast planned devices [zamam], lay thy hand upon thy mouth" (Prov. xxx. 32)? Everyone who makes himself foolish for the sake of words of Torah will in the end be lifted up ; but if he muzzles [zamam] his mouth, he will have to put his hand to his mouth.
123.62: R. Nehemiah began [to speak] in honour of the hospitality and expounded :
123.63: What means that which is written, "And Saul said unto the Kenites, Go, depart, get you down from among the Amalekites, lest I destroy you with them ; for ye showed kindness to all the children of Israel, when they came up out of Egypt" (I Sam. 15:6)? Can we not use here an a fortiori argument :
123.64: If Jethro, who only befriended Moses for his own honour, is treated with so much consideration, how much more so one who entertains a disciple of the wise in his house, giving him to eat and drink, and allowing him to enjoy his possessions!
123.65: R. Jose began [to speak] in honour of the hospitality and expounded :
123.66: "Thou shalt not abhor an Edomite, for he is thy brother; thou shalt not abhor an Egyptian, because thou wast a stranger in his land" (Deut. xxiii. 8). Can we not use here an a fortiori argument?
123.67: If the Egyptians are not to be abhorred, who only befriended the Israelites for their own needs — as it is said, "And if thou knowest any able men among them, then make them rulers over my cattle" (Gen. xlvii. 6) — how much more so, one who entertains a disciple of the wise in his house, giving him to eat and drink, and allowing him to enjoy his possessions!
123.68: R. Eliezer, the son of R. Jose of Galilee, began [to speak] in honour of the hospitality and expounded :
123.69: "And the Lord blessed Obed-Edom and all his house...because of the Ark of God" (II Sam. vi. llf.). Can we not use here an a fortiori argument?
123.70: If the Ark which neither ate nor drank, but which Obed-Edom swept and besprinkled, brought him a blessing, how much more so one who entertains a disciple of the wise, giving him to eat and drink, and allowing him to enjoy his possessions !
123.71: What was the blessing wherewith He blessed him ?
123.73: It refers to Hamot and her eight daughters-in-law who each bore six children at one birth ;

124.0: as it is said, "Peullethai the eighth son" (I Chron. xxvi. 5), and it is written "For God blessed him" (ibid.), "All these were the sons of Obed-Edom, they and their sons and their brethren, able men in strength for the service ; threescore and two of Obed-Edom" (ibid. v. 8)[3].
124.2: Whoever forces fate[5], fate will force him; but whoever yields to fate, fate yields to him. So was it with Rabbah and Rab Joseph ;
124.3: for Rab Joseph [was nicknamed] "Sinai[6]" and Rabbah "the uprooter of mountains[7].
124.4: "The time needed them[8]; so [the electors] sent [a message] there[9],
124.5: "Of 'Sinai' and 'the uprooter of mountains,' which should be given preference?"
124.7: "'Sinai' should be preferred, because all stand in need of an owner of wheat[10]."
124.8: Nevertheless Rab Joseph did not accept the offer, because the Chaldeans[11] told him,
124.10: Rabbah ruled two and twenty years[13], and then Rab Joseph two and a half;
124.11: but all the years that Rabbah ruled he never called a cupper to his house[14].
124.12: R. Abin the Levite also said :
124.13: What means that which is written, "The Lord answer thee in the day of trouble; the name of the God of Jacob set thee up on high" (Ps. xx. 2)? The God of Jacob, but not the God of Abraham and Isaac ! From this we learn that the owner of a beam should go in with the heaviest part of it[1].
124.14: R. Abin the Levite also said :
124.15: Whoever partakes of a meal at which a disciple of the wise is present is as though he partakes of the lustre of the Shekinah; as it is said, "And Aaron came, and all the elders of Israel, to eat bread with Moses' father-in-law before God" (Exod. xviii. 12).
124.17: Was it not before Moses that they ate?
124.18: But it means to tell thee that
124.19: whoever partakes of a meal at which a disciple of the wise is present is as though he partakes of the lustre of the Shekinah.
124.20: R. Abin the Levite also said :
124.21: One who takes leave of his friend should not say to him, "Go in peace" but "Go to peace";
124.22: because in the case of Jethro who said to Moses "Go to peace" (Exod. iv. 18), the latter advanced and prospered ; but in the case of David who said to Absalom "Go in peace" (II Sam. xv. 9), the latter went and was hanged.
124.23: R. Abin the Levite also said :
124.24: One who takes leave of the dead should not say to him, "Go to peace" but "Go in peace" ; as it is said, "But thou shalt go to thy fathers in peace" (Gen. xv. 15).
124.26: He who goes out from the Synagogue and enters the House of Study to occupy himself with Torah is worthy to receive the presence of the Shekinah; as it is said, "They go from strength to strength, every one of them appeareth before God in Zion" (Ph. Ixxxiv. 8).
124.27: R. Hiyya b. Ashe said in the name of Rab[3] :
124.28: The disciples of the wise have rest neither in this world nor in the world to come; as it is said, "They go from strength to strength, every one of them appeareth before God in Zion."
124.29: R. Eleazar said in the name of R. Hannina:
124.30: The disciples of the wise increase peace in the world; as it is said, "And all thy children shall be taught of the Lord ; and great shall be the peace of thy children" (Is. liv. 13). Read not banayik "thy children" but bonayik "thy builders[1]"
124.31: "Great peace have they that love Thy law; and there is no stumbling for them" (Ps. cxix. 165). "Peace be within thy walls, and prosperity within thy palaces" (ibid, cxxii. 7). "For my brethren and companions' sakes, I will now say, Peace be within thee" (ibid. v. 8). "For the sake of the house of the Lord our God, I will seek thy good" (ibid. v. 9). "The Lord will give strength unto His people ; the Lord will bless His people with peace" (ibid. xxix. 11)[2]
124.32: May we return unto thee : He who beholds! And finished is the Tractate Berakot.
